item.title: Pfizer Is Vying To Acquire Indian Specialty Injectable Business
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Strides Acrolab's specialty injectable unit Agila appears to be up for sale, with a potential buyers rumoured to be Pfizer, a company with whom the parent company already has a US distribution partnership.
Agila has the highest number of generic injectable approvals by the FDA and therefore is viewed as a potentially attractive acquisition for any pharmaceutical company which to expand its generic business, something Pfizer appears keen to do through its Established Product Division.
Agila's sales in 2011 were reportedly $185 and are forecast to expand to $250m by FY2013. Hence the cost of acquiring the company is likely to be around $1.6 to $2bn.
The slides below illustrate Agila's activity and capability profile.

item.title: Priority Review Granted by FDA to Zytiga for Pre-Chemo Setting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Zytiga sNDA submission is based on the efficacy and safety results of an international Ph3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical study that evaluated the drug + prednisone vs. placebo + prednisone in 1,088 asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic men with mCRPC who had not received chemotherapy.
Please see Oncology8342: J&J Intends to Extend the Use of Zytiga Earlier in the Course of Prostate Cancer.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Preliminary Results of the Ph1 Assessing Versartis' Once-Month rhGH for AGHD
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: To date 39 of 50 planned participants have received placebo or VRS-317 doses, and there have been no study withdrawals due to AEs. Findings show that the drug stimulates IGF-I at GH equivalent doses below the conventional GH doses used in GH deficiency adults.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Humira's Label To Expand To Potentially Include Ulcerative Colitis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: An FDA panel on Tuesday backed the approval of Abbott's anti-TNF drug Humira (adalimumab) for the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis voting 15:2 in favour that the benefits of treatment outweigh any risk for patients who fail to respond to conventional therapy.
However, the panel agreed by a 14:2 vote that higher doses of the drug need to be evaluated in a post approval setting to further understand the need and potential for the drug. A final decision regarding approval is expected by the year-end.
A company spokesperson Elizabeth Hoff reportedly stated that the new indication is expected to generate incremental sales of around$1bn. Humira had sales of $8bn last year and is already approved for six indications.
source: www.abbott.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novartis to Start Acromegaly Trial in Japan with Pasireotide LAR
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The newly listed Ph2 trial in clinicaltrials.gov will recruit approx. 30 participants with medication naïve and inadequately controlled acromegaly. The primary endpoint is to assess the total-group effiacy of the drug on the reduction of mean GH levels to 2.5 µg/L, and the normalization of IGF-1 at 3 months of study treatment.
Dosage (enrollment): Three experimental doses will be tested: 20mg (10 patients); 40mg (10 patients); 60mg (10 patients).
Start date: Sept. 2012 / Completion date: Sept. 2015 (final data collection for PE).
Protocol: IM administration of pasireotide LAR will be repeated every month for 12 months in core phase.
Location: Japan (9 sites).

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: On Aug 28, the company held a briefing presentation on its emerging market business. Management reported China, Russsia/CIS and Brazil to be its top priority markets for future growth. When it comes to the integration of Nycomed, it was reported that the acquisition provided an immediate financial contribution. A selection of key slide is provided below.

item.title: AstraZeneca Appoints New CEO
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pascal Soriot, COO since 2010 of Roche's Pharma Division, will take up his 'challenging' new job on October 1st. His mission will be to review the pipeline and do more deals in order to grow sales and face past development setbacks, current pressure on prices, and future patent losses.
- Nationality: French (aged 53)
- Studies: Veterinary Surgeon; MBA with major in Finance (HEC Paris)
Snapshot
Mr. Soriot served as the Chief Executive Officer of Genentech Inc. since 2009.
He served as Head of Commercial Operations at Roche Holding AG since December 2006 and Head of Strategic Marketing Pharma division
From March 1, 2006 to December 2006. he served as Senior Vice President of Commercial Operations, United States of Sanofi-aventis since August 2004 and Chief Operating Officer since 2002 ...

item.title: re: NICE Revises Amgen's Xgeva Guidance
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
NICE Revises Amgen's Xgeva Guidance 
Comment: Last March, NICE recommended the drug for breast and prostate cancer patients whose disease has spread to the bone. But in light of new information from clinical experts, the agency has reported it no longer believed the drug represented a cost-effective treatment.  ...

The U.K.’s NICE issued a final appraisal determination (FAD) recommending the use of Xgeva denosumab from Amgen to prevent skeletal-related events (SREs) in patients with bone metastases from breast cancer; and in patients with bone metastases from solid tumors other than breast and prostate cancer for whom zoledronic acid would be indicated. The recommendation, which is contingent on Amgen providing Xgeva at an undisclosed discount under a patient access scheme, does not recommend Xgeva to prevent SREs in patients with bone metastases from hormone-refractory prostate cancer (HRPC). Final guidance is expected next month.

Source : BioCentury for the week of August 27, 2012

View thread Oncology8322: NICE Revises Amgen's Xgeva Guidance

item.title: Merz Strengthens its Neuro Business in the US
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has acquired (from Shionogi) CUVPOSA® (glycopyrrolate), an oral solution for ped. patients (aged 3-16) with chronic severe drooling associated with neuro conditions, such as cerebral palsy (CP). The drug is the only FDA-approved treatment for this condition.
- Background: On April 2011, Shionogi announced the US commercial availability of the drug.
- Supply: 1mg/5ml clear, cherry flavored oral solution.
- MOA: anticholinergic that reduces the rate of salivation by preventing stimulation of acetylcholine receptors that are located on certain peripheral tissues such as salivary glands
- FDA approved: July 28, 2010
  • Approval was based on the results of a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Phase III study which showed that 75% of children and adolescents treated with CUVPOSA™ experienced an improvement in symptoms, versus 11% who received placebo (NCT00491894).
- Commercially available: April 2011
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (16,5 KB)

item.title: Debiopharm Enrolls First Patient in Triptorelin 6-M Trial for CPP
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The open-label Ph3 study will recruit approx. 44 chilren from the US, Chile and Mexico. Primary EP will assess the efficacy/safety of the drug in decreasing LH to prepubertal levels at month 6 in children with central precocious puberty (CPP).
Completion date: Oct 2014 / Nov 2014
Protocol: 2 injections at D1 and D169.
Total study duration: 12 months (48 weeks).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Bavarian Nordic Reportedly at Risk Of Financing Difficulties
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company's ongoing phIII trial with its Prostvac VF vaccine may be in jeopardy as Bavarian Nordic failes to receive a $500m replacement order from the US Department of Health & Human Services (HHS) for its smallpox vaccine.
Reportedly the purchase by the US authorities should have been made in June but has so far failed to materialise. The vaccine in question is known as Imvamune and it is used in patients known to be at risk of adverse reactions to the standard smallpox vaccine.
According to a report on Bloomberg
  • In 2007, the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) awarded Barvarian Nordic a $500 million health contract for 20 million doses of Imvamune.
  • Barvarian Nordic and HHS agree that the current vaccine is beginning to lose potency (i.e., it is reaching its “past due” date) and needs to be replaced.
  • The company has been expecting HHS to order replacement vaccine since June.
Since 95% of Bavarian Nordic's revenues are derived from Imvamune, it is likely to face a major shortfall in funding if an order does not materialise soon.
The lack of any repeat order is seemingly due to problems with the federal government reaching any conclusions about HHS funding at the moment.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New Study Is Assessing QOL of Patients with CD Treated with BOTOX®
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new observational study sponsored by Allergan. The PE will assess change from baseline in Cervical Dystonia Impact Profile Questionnaire Score. Approx. 250 patients are to be recruited in Canada.
Completion date: Oct 2017 / Nov 2017

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Amgen's AMG-479 (ganitumab) Fails in Pancreatic Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has discontinued the Ph3 GAMMA (gemcitabine + ganitumab) in metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, as well as a separate ongoing Ph2 in local advanced pNETs. AMG-479, an IGF-1R antagonist, has also previously failed in other tumor types, including NSCLC.

The addition of ganitumab to gemcitabine is unlikely to demonstrate a statistically significant improvement in the PE of OS compared to gemcitabine alone.

There were no safety concerns raised in the DMC review of the study.

AMG-479's inability to show an OS benefit in pancreatic cancer should not come as a surprise given previous failures of this class of agents.

Results presented at ASCO showed the drug was well tolerated, however lacked efficacy in pNETs.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Another RNAi Deal With Prostate Cancer As Part Of The Focus
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Silence Therapeutics has signed an agreement with Asutralian group MiRiven Ltd to assess the delivery potential of Silence's proprietary delivery systems with MiRiven's novel microRNA-based therapeutics in models of prostate and lung cancers and melanoma.
Background
MiRiven's aim is to develop and commercialise discoveries made the the Western Australian Institute of Medical Research, notably to evaluate the potentia of miR-7.
MiRiven reportedly has developed a body of preclinical evidence supporting the potential of miR-7 to suppress tumour growth particularly in cancers controlled by the EGFR signalling pathway.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of the agreement Silence will formulate a miR-7 mimetic with its proprietary AtuPLEX, DACC and DBTC delivery systems in order to evaluate the molecule in varioius cancer models. Silence will undertake the in-vitro and in-vivo assessments.
Silence's Technology Platform/Development Pipeline
Silence's most advanced delivery technology is AtuPLEX. It has demonstrated braod system delivery to the vascular endothelium and has been used to formulate Atu027, Silence's first clinical development candidate (phase I is ongoing).
DACC is closely related to AtuPLEX and is a novel lipid drug delivery system that enables the delivery of RNAi therapeutics to the pulmonary epithelium and DBTC is similarly a lipid based formulation that targets the liver.
source: www.silence-therapeutics.com
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (106,3 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan Expands Global Partnership to Develop Novel Therapy for Eye Diseases
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan has announced expanded agreement with privately held Molecular Partners AG in the field of serious ophtalmic diseases. Companies will further develop single-agent anti-VEGF DARPin® (Designed Ankryn Repeat Proteins), a new class of protein drugs that blocks both VEGF and PDGF. Wet-AMD is a $3B+ global market, dominated by off-label Avastin and Lucentis.
Molecular Partners AG will receive combined upfront payments of $62.5M under the 2 agreements (1/exclusive license agreement and 2/exclusive discovery alliance) and is eligible to receive additional success-based payments, including up to $1.4B in aggregate development, regulatory and sales milestones, and tiered royalties up into the low double-digits for future product sales.
Allergan's Full PR > http://agn.client.shareholder.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=701294
Advantages
PK data suggest higher binding affinity, higher clinical dose and longer vitreous half life than Lucentis.
Acc. to Allergan, DARPin® has the potential to be administered once every 3-4 months (vs 1 month for Lucentis).
Ongoing Ph2b Program
Design: Randomized, double-blind trial in previously untreated wet-AMD.
Protocol: 2 doses of DARPin vs. Lucentis.
Data expected in 2013.
Source: Allergan; Molecular Partners; Thomson One

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: PhaseBio's Glymera™ Has Entered Ph2b for T2DM
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Glymera™, a once-weekly GLP-1, has the potential to show less nausea than what has been reported with other GLP-1 analogues as the onset of nausea appears to be related to the rapid release of GLP-1 agonist into the circulation.
Recruitment: approx. 522
Inclusion criteria: participants inadequately controlled with diet and exercise, metformin, sulfonylurea or a combination of metformin/sulfonylurea.
Design: randomized, placebo and active comparator controlled
Completion date: 3Q:13
Location: USA (72 sites)
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (41,9 KB)

item.title: Æterna Zentaris - Update on Major Programs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During the Q2:12 results' webcast the company provided an update on the status of its key pipeline products. Ozarelix, an LHRH antagonist partnered with Spectrum, has entered the second part of the Ph2 comparative study vs Zoladex (goserelin) in men with PCa for whom hormonal treatment (HT) is indicated. New data on AEZS-120 (oral PCa vaccine), AEZS-108 (for CRPC) and AEZS-130 (diagnostic test for AGHD) are provided below. Æterna Zentaris also announced its plans to eliminate 16% of its German workforce over the next year in an effort to reduce overall spending.
Juergen Engel, President & CEO, started the presentation with the new strategy for perifosine. Following an 'unexpected negative outcome' of the Ph3 in colorectal cancer, the company has decided to contunuing the Ph3 development study in multiple myeloma.
On Aug. 14th, Spectrum announced initiation of patient enrollment in the Ph2b of ozarelix in men with PCa for whom HT is indicated.
Study Details - (NCT01252693 or See Oncology6993: Spectrum's Ozarelix Versus Goserelin Depot (Zoladex®) in Men With Prostate Cancer)
Objective: to assess safety and efficacy of a monthly dosing regimen administered SC vs Zoladex.
Protocol: patients will be randomized in a 2:1 ratio to either the ozarelix or goserelin arm, respectively.
  • Eligible patients randomized to the ozarelix arm will receive a loading dose of SC ozarelix, followed by a lower maintenance dose on days 28 and 56.
  • Eligible patients randomized to the goserelin arm will receive SC goserelin at randomization followed by two doses of goserelin on days 28 and 56.
  • All patients will be followed for 84 days.
Primary outcome: to assess the percentage of patients who achieve the level of testosterone < = 0.5 ng/mL from day 28 through day 84.
Recruitment: approx. 150.
Locations: multiple sites in the U.S, as well as in India (through Spectrum's subsidiary, OncoRx).
Preclinical development was financed by a grant from the German Government for approx. 50% of the total costs.
The company is in the planning process to file a CTA in EU, in order to initiate a Ph1 trial in late 2012/early 2013.
The Ph1/Ph2 study is funded by a $1.6M NIH grant, and conducted by Dr Jacek Pinskin Associate Professor at the Norris Comprehensive Cancer Center at USC (in Los Angeles).
" ... The primary objective of the Phase II portion is to evaluate the clinical benefit of AEZS-108. The trial will enroll >55 patients for both portions. So far 15 patients have been recruited. We expect to be providing some updated results at upcoming scientific conferences".
Diagnostic
Represents an interesting business opportunity for Æterna Zentaris. As such, the company is planning to perform additional marketing analysis that would contribute to its discussion for future partnerships, or in deciding to market AEZS-130 itself.
Therapeutic
Dr. Jose Garcia, Assistant Professor at Baylor College and VA Medical Center in Houston, is currently conducting a Ph2a trial assessing the safety and efficacy of repeated doses of AEZS-130 in 18 to 26 patients with cancer cachexia.
Source: Æterna Zentaris; Thomson One

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Diminishing Doctor Contact With Sales Reps - UK Survey Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Doctor.net.uk surveyed more than 1,000 GPs in April this year and reportedly found 52 per cent of GPs did not see any pharmaceutical sales representatives in a typical week, while 26 per cent only saw one pharma sales rep during that period.
Lack of time was the most common reason cited by GPs for not seeing pharma sales reps (38 per cent), but other reasons given included practice policy and a perceived lack of reps’ impartiality.
At the same time the UK online doctors’ network said doctors are turning to digital channels for independent product information.
Nearly a quarter (23 per cent) of the GPs surveyed said they preferred to find their own product information via “independent online resources”.
The research would appear to be inline with more general trends among healthcare professionals for content consumption and interaction.
European online physician networks continue to see significant growth, a trend that has been particularly pronounced in the UK – along with Germany and Scandinavia.
Meanwhile, European doctors’ use of iPads and other mobile devices is increasing, and in March a survey by Booz & Co found European and US pharma execs expects to increase their future spending on digital marketing channels.
Doctors.net.uk said its findings follow earlier studies it conducted that show only 3 per cent of doctors think online pharma resources are credible and 42 per cent never visit pharmaceutical websites.
http://www.pmlive.com/digital_intelligence_blog/archive/2012/aug_2012/uk_doctors_pharma_sales_reps_digital

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Algeta Reported Commercial Preparations Underway for Alpharadin (radium-223 dichloride)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside its financial results for the second quarter 2012, the company confirmed the EU/US launch of Alpharadin to occur in Q2/Q3:13, with first sales in Q3:13. Management also provided information on logistics and administration, and the drug clinical development program.
In Europe, 156 sites have now been approved, and patients are currently being treated.
In the US, some 50 sites have been approved. Alpharadin is currently available at c60 more sites than we previously assumed, which should help facilitate the launch and add upside to initial sales.
Algeta will present data from the ALSYMPCA trial on the 1) Quality of Life; and 2) safety of chemotherapy use after Alpharadin during the ESMO at the end of September. The quality of life, in addition to increased survival, is a key selling point for Alpharadin.

item.title: re: UK Drug Pricing Negotiations to Start in September 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
UK Drug Pricing Negotiations to Start in September 2012 
Comment: The UK’s Department of Health and the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry have outlined details of their forthcoming negotiations on the implementation of a value-based pricing system and in a joint statement set out some of the key points to be addressed.  ...
The ABPI has announced the members of a team that will negotiate with the U.K.'s Department of Health for the country's proposed value-based pricing system. John Kearney, U.K. and Ireland general manager at Amgen Inc will chair the group, which will include Peter Butterfield, executive director at Alliance Pharma; Erik van Snippenberg, general manager and SVP for the U.K. at GlaxoSmithKline; Jon Emms, managing director for the U.K. at Pfizer; and Matthew Speers, managing director, British and Irish Isles at UCB Group.

item.title: Novartis To Start Expanded Development Of BEZ235 In pNET
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As of September/October, Novartis plans to initiate two new phII randomised trials with its new investigational agent BEZ235 an mTOR/PI3K inhibitor. The first will be a head to head comparison against everolimus in paitents with advanced neuroendocrine tumours and the second in a similar group of patient who have failed on mTOR therapy.
Head To Head Comparison In Advanced NET
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01628913
The study will evaluate the treatment effect of BEZ235 relative to everolimus on progression-free survival (PFS) over 18 months and will enroll 140 mTOR naive patients.
Secondary endpoints will include safety and tolerability, objective response rate, overall survival and time to treatment failure.
BEZ325 will be administered as an oral dose of 400mg b.d. and compared with a 10mg bd dose of everolimus
Patients will be expected to have advanced progressive disease and measurable disease per RECIST criteria.
Patients will be excluded if they have received prior treatment with an m-TOR or PI3K inhibitor or chemotherapy, targeted therapy or biotherapy within the last 4 weeks.
The trial will be conducted at 8 sites within the US. It was first referenced at ENETs this year (see Endocrinology6883: ENETS Intelligence Part 2 - Novartis & Pfizer Symposia Plus Key New Trials).
BEZ235 In M-TOR Failure pNET Patients
ClinicalTrial Identifier: NCT01658436
This second trial a two stage trial evaluating BEZ235 plus best supportive care (BSC) versus placebo plus BSC in patients with advanced pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNET) after failure of mTOR inhibitor therapy.
The primary endpoint will focus on PFS at 16 weeks in stage I and up to 30 months in stage II
The secondary outcome measures will evaluate frequency and severity of AEs, Overall response rate, disease control rate, duration of response and overall survival.
Enrollment of 130 patients will start in October with the study scheduled to complete in February 2015. Stage I which will be open-label will enroll 30 patients and stage II (randomised) 99.
BEZ235 will be supplied in 200mg, 300mg and 400mg sachets. These will be taken twice daily after food.
Eligible patients:-
  • Unresectable or metastatic, histologically confirmed low or intermediate grade pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor with radiological evidence of disease progression since last treatment
  • Refractory disease to treatment with mTOR inhibitor
  • Measurable disease per RECIST Version 1.1 using Computed Tomography (CT) or Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
  • Prior or concurrent therapy with SSA is permitted; a stable dose at least 2 months prior to study start and must continue on the stable dose while receiving study treatment
  • WHO PS ≤ 1
  • Adequate bone marrow function or organ function

Exclusion Criteria:

  • Previous treatment with any PI3K or AKT inhibitor
  • Discontinuation prior mTOR inhibitor therapy due to toxicity
  • Poorly differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma, high-grade neuroendocrine carcinoma, adenocarcinoid, goblet cell carcinoid and small cell carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic chemotherapy, targeted therapy, immunotherapy, radiotherapy, or major surgery within 4 weeks prior to enrolment in the study
  • Hepatic artery embolization within the last 6 months (1 month if there are other sites of measurable disease), or cryoablation/ radiofrequency ablation of hepatic metastasis within 2 months of enrollment
  • More than 3 prior systemic treatment regimens
This study will be a European study and include 3 centres in France (Dijon, Lyon and Villejuif), one in the Netherlands (Rotterdam) and two in Poland (Warsaw).
Source: Clinical Trials.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Drug Delivery Company Unigene Faces Financial Difficulties
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In its Q2 earnings statement Unigene noted that it will need to obtain significant funding to be able to continue operations with a debt payment looming in September.
The news follo

Unigene said its cash flow will fund operations into 4Q12. At June 30, Unigene had $1.7 million in cash and a six-month operating loss of $3.1

Unigene’s Ostora oral recombinant salmon calcitonin, to which Tarsa Therapeutics has worldwide development and commercialization rights outside of China, is in Phase III testing to treat osteoporosis.

Tarsa is evaluating opportunities to appeal the CHMP recommendation and plans to discuss the situation with FDA. Because the osteoclast inhibitor is not yet approved in Europe, the companies do not have the right to formally appeal the recommendation.

Tarsa originally planned to submit an NDA to FDA this year and an MAA in Europe shortly thereafter. Tarsa said that plans to submit the NDA are ongoing, but could not disclose details regarding the MAA.

Unigene said regulatory authorities, including FDA, could take action as a result of the recommendation, including the withdrawal of calcitonin-containing products from the market or limiting their use. The company said this could reduce or eliminate osteoporosis drug Fortical calcitonin sales and royalties. The osteoclast inhibitor is marketed by Upsher-Smith Laboratories in the U.S. to treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women

Unigene also said in its earnings that due to a lack of funds it has placed a hold on preclinical candidate UGP281 to treat obesity. The company had planned to start Phase I testing of the anorexigenic amylin receptor agonist in 1H13

Source: www.unigene.com


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Leading MicroRNA Company Finalizes Two Deals
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Leading MicroRNA Company Finalizes Two Deals 
Comment: Regulus Therapeutics a company founded by Alnylam Therapeutics and ISIS to focus on non-coding microRNAs has announced two deals in two days one with Biogen-Idec the other with Astra Zeneca.  ...
Last week, Regulus filed to raise up to $57.5 million in an IPO, becoming the first preclinical company to do so since cancer stem cell play Verastem went public in January. The filing capped a week in which Regulus announced deals with Biogen-Idec and AstraZeneca
Regulus's pipeline of single-stranded oligo- nucleotides includes a compound target-ing microRNA-21 (miR-21) that is partnered with Sanofi. The compound is in develop- ment for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and kidney fibrosis. The pipeline also includes an HCV compound targeting miR-122 that is partnered with GSK.
Regulus has at least one unpartnered compound targeting miR-10b, which is in development for glioblastoma. The biotech has stated it hopes to file its first IND in 2014.
Source: Biocentury


Add a Comment on this Article

View thread PharmaWorld10011: Leading MicroRNA Company Finalizes Two Deals

item.title: PhIII Results of the AFFIRM Trial Published In NEJM
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Astellas highlighted today the publication of the phIII AFFIRM study results in the August 15th online version of the NEJM.
As a recap, the study showed that enzalutamide exhibited a statistically signficant benefit in overall survival compared to placebo. Men treated with enzalutamide had a median overall survival of 18.4 months (95% confidence interval 11.3-15.8) compared to 13.6 months (95% confidence interval 11.3 -15.8) for men treated with placebo ( HR 0.063; p<0.0001), representing a 37% reduction in the risk of death.
The drug also demonstrated a favourable side-effect profile with the three most common side-effects observed being fatigue, diarrhea and hot flushed. Seizure was reported in less than 1% of patients treated with enzalutamide. Serious AEs occurred at lower rate in the enzalutamide group than in the placebo group.
In its press release, Astellas noted that the FDA has accepted its NDA for enzlutamide but did not pass comment on the European application which was submitted in June but not listed in the latest (July 26th) list of products submitted for approval by the EMA
source: http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1207506

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Leading MicroRNA Company Finalizes Two Deals
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Regulus Therapeutics a company founded by Alnylam Therapeutics and ISIS to focus on non-coding microRNAs has announced two deals in two days one with Biogen-Idec the other with Astra Zeneca.
Biogen-Idec
This collaboration with look identify microRNA biomarkers in blood from multiple sclerosis patients as a means of optimising patients selection and monitoring disease progression in future clinical trials. Deal terms have not been disclosed.
AstraZeneca
This microRNA collaboration is focused on preclinical therapeutic agents against three targets directed against cardiovascular, metabolic diseases and cancer.
Under the terms of the agreement, AstraZeneca will make a $28M payment which includes an equity investment and an upfront payment to Regulus.
The two companies will initially focus on Regulus’ lead cardiovascular/metabolic disease program targeting microRNA-33 for the treatment of atherosclerosis.
Regulus will lead preclinical development and, if successful, could receive pre-clinical milestone payments. AstraZeneca will lead and fund the clinical development and commercialization of these programs.
In addition, Regulus could also receive clinical milestones based on the successful development of microRNA therapies in each target area.

Comments
Last week, Regulus filed to raise up to $57.5 million in an IPO, becoming the first preclinical company to do so since cancer stem cell play Verastem went public in January. The filing capped a week in which Regulus announced deals with Biogen-Idec and AstraZeneca
Regulus's pipeline of single-stranded oligo- nucleotides includes a compound target-ing microRNA-21 (miR-21) that is partnered with Sanofi. The compound is in develop- ment for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and kidney fibrosis. The pipeline also includes an HCV compound targeting miR-122 that is partnered with GSK.
Regulus has at least one unpartnered compound targeting miR-10b, which is in development for glioblastoma. The biotech has stated it hopes to file its first IND in 2014.
Source: Biocentury
The company amended its IPO, and now plans to sell 4.5 million shares at $10-12 per share. An 11$ price would raise $50M, and value the company at $239M.
Regulus said several partners have expressed interest in participating in the offering. Sanofi plans to purchase up to $10M, Isis Pharm.and GSK plan to purchase up to $2M each.
Source: Biocentury

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: PhII Results For New Ulceratice Colitis Drug Published By Pfizer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Data published in the latest edition of the NEJM shows that the highest dose of oral tofacitinib from Pfizer.met the primary endpoint in a Phase II trial to treat moderate to severe active ulcerative colitis.
Study Design

194 adults with moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis were treated in a double-blind randominsed phII study. Patients were randomly assigned to receive tofacitinib at a dose of 0.5 mg, 3 mg, 10 mg, or 15 mg or placebo twice daily for 8 weeks. The primary outcome was a clinical response at 8 weeks, defined as an absolute decrease from baseline in the score on the Mayo scoring system for assessment of ulcerative colitis activity (possible score, 0 to 12, with higher scores indicating more severe disease) of 3 or more and a relative decrease from baseline of 30% or more with an accompanying decrease in the rectal bleeding subscore of 1 point or more or an absolute rectal bleeding subscore of 0 or 1.

Key Findings

A twice-daily 15 mg dose of the oral pan-Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitor significantly improved clinical response rate from baseline to week eight vs. placebo (78% vs. 42%, p<0.001). However, twice-daily 0.5, 3 and 10 mg doses of tofacitinib missed the endpoint. Two patients receiving the 10 mg dose of tofacitinib had serious adverse events from infection.

The 8-week trial was conducted at 51 centers in 17 countries (Belgium, Brazil, Chile, Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Hungary, Israel, Italy, Mexico, the Netherlands, Poland, Slovakia, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, and the United Kingdom) from January 2009 through September 2010.

Current Status

Tofacitinib is currently in Phase III testing to evaluate its benefit as a maintenance therapy for US. The trial listed in ClinicalTrials.gov as starting in July 2012 is due to complete in April 2015 and is scheduled to ernoll 654 patients.
An NDA for tofacitinib to treat rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is under FDA review with an Aug. 21 PDUFA date. The product is under review for RA in the EU and Japan as well. Tofacitinib also is in Phase III testing to treat moderate to severe plaque psoriasis
Scource: New England Journal of Medicine & ClinicalTrials.gov

item.title: My NET Manager App
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The NET Alliance a patient education initiative supported by Novartis Oncology announced yesterday the launch of a new mobile app for patients with neuroendocrine tumours.
The new app is designed to help individuals track symptomss, set reminders, view important dates, share information and manually input test results if a provider does not have electronic medical records.
Initial user reviews suggest that the app is being well received by patients.
source: http://www.caringforcarcinoid.org/news/mynet-manager-app

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New Technology Delivers Sustained Release Of Drugs For Up To Six Months
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Scientists at the University of Cambridge have announced details of a new hydrogel drug delivery technology that can release drugs for up to six months.

Researchers. Dr Oren Schermen, Dr Xian Jun Loh and PhD student Eric Appel have developed injectable, reformable and spreadable hydrogels which can be loaded with proteins or other therapeutics. The hydrogels contain up to 99.7% water by weight, with the remainder primarily made up of cellulose polymers held together with cucurbiturils - barrel-shaped molecules which act as miniature 'handcuffs'.

The hydrogels protect the proteins so that they remain bio-active for long periods, and allow the proteins to remain in their native state but importantly, all the components can be incorporated at room temperature.

The team are currently working with researchers from the Brain Repair Centre in the Department of Clinical Medicine on how the technology might be used as a possible treatment for brain cancer.

The research was published recently in the journal Biomaterials and has been patented by Cambridge Enterprise, the University's commercialisation group.

source: http://www.enterprise.cam.ac.uk/news/2012/8/new-technology-delivers-sustained-release-drugs-si/


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Spectrum Initiates PhIIb Study With GnRH antagonist Ozarelix
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Spectrum has announced the initiation of its phIIb programme for ozarelix which will compare the safety and efficacy of this monthly subcutaneous therapy with Zoladex in patients with prostate cancer for whom hormonal therapy is indicated.
Study Design
150 patients will be randomised in a 2:1 ratio to either ozarelix or goserlin.
Ozarelix patients will receive a loading dose followed by a lower maintenance dose on days 28 and 56. Zoladex will be simiilarly administered. All patients will be followed up for 84 days.
Primary outcome - % of patients who achieve a testosterone level of < = 0.5 ng/ml from day 28 to 84.
Secondary outcome will evaluate the no of patients who experience a testosterone surge during the first two weeek, effect on PSA levels and safety.
Location
The study will be conducted at multiple sites in the US as well as in India through Spectrum's subsidiary OncoRx.
Source: spectrum.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Allergan To Expand Manufacturing Plant At Westport
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Allergan To Expand Manufacturing Plant At Westport 
Comment: Allergan has announced today its intention to expand its manufacturing facility at its Westport Site in County Mayo creating 200 new jobs as part of a €350 million investment designed to meet future demand for Botox and the next generation of biological products.  ...
Following the announcement in January that Allergan was to expand its biologics manufacturing capacity at its Westport facility in a $350 million investment, Allergan Pharmaceuticals have published a notice today signalling their intention to apply to Mayo County Council for permission for the development at Gortaroe, Westport (to the rear of the existing plant).
The notice outlines that the development will consist of the construction of an overall floor area of 15,677 sq meters, consisting of a three-storey office block with a floor area of 3456 sq meters and a height of 16 meters, a production hall and plant rooms with a floor area of 8,705 sq meters, and a warehouse and ancillary accommodation.
The notice also states that the works will incorporate the relocation of an existing local access road and the construction of a new circulation route to the existing Allergan facility, together with the provision of 223 car parking spaces. Other cycle and pedestrian lanes will also be developed, along with a pedestrian link bridge of 140 sq meters and a height of 8.8 meters to the existing multi-agency enterprise building.
Approximately 200 jobs will be created by Allergan when this new facility is operational, along with up to 250 indirect jobs locally, during the construction period.

item.title: Promising Results From New Drug For Polycystic Kidney Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Scientists at UC Santa Barbara have produced experimental evidence of the effectiveness of a new rapamycin analogue in treating polycystic kidney disease. The technology platform associated with this product has already acheived POC in platinum resistant ovarian cancer leading to one of the highest valued deals in oncology this year, namely Merck's $1bn deal for Endocyte's vintafolide.
Previous work with the rapamycin analogue everolimus (Afinitor) in patients with polycystic kidneys has produced somewhat disappointing results despite interesting observations in mice.
Recognising the unmet need for a novel therapy, Endocyte pharmaceuticals decided to pusue a more targeted approach by conjugating a small molecule to the folate receptor.
It has chemically synthesized a new version of rapamycin called folate-conjugated rapamycin (FC-rapa). UC Santa Barbara has tested this new drug and found that it is highly effective in preventing kidney cyst growth in mice with PKD, but that it has fewer systemic side effects compared to regular rapamycin.
Next Steps
Endocyte intend to try and repeat the FC-rapa tests in the company lab and test some other similar drug to try and identify a compound to move forward with into phI development.
Company Success With Folate Targeted Approach
Endocyte has already achieved POC with a folate receptor targeted drug achieving one of the best responses seen so far in platinum resistant ovarian cancer. The impressive result prompted Merck to in-license worldwide rights to the drug earlier this year. Based on these findings and the presence of folate receptors in other tumour types Endocyte has developed a portfolio of projects based on folate conjugate technology including as mentioned above the folate rapamycin based analogue.

item.title: Novo Nordisk Earnings Call - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During its earnings call Novo Nordisk provided more detail on developments within the GLP-1 market, including the approval of Victoza in China and commented on the sales performance of NovoSeven which is being impacted by a biosimilar Factor VII from Russia.
Hemophilia
Commenting on Novoseven's performance, Kare Schulz noted
With regard to NovoSeven, we have a situation where the market is basically saturated in the industrialized world because basically all patients that are in a situation where they need NovoSeven, so they have inhibitors, the Factor VIII or Factor IX, they are getting therapy, and we have roughly a 70% market share up against Pfizer. In emerging markets, you have two categories of markets. You have some markets that are so poor that nobody really gets treated with Factor VIII or Factor IX. That means nobody develops inhibitors and there is no market. That is maybe the LDC countries, the poorest 50 countries of the world. Then you have a big middle category of markets where we actually do see increasing demand and where we do see increasing sales. However, that is, this year for instance, being offset by the fact that NovoSeven has run out of patent in basically all these markets, and we’ve seen a generic product, a biosimilar product come up in Russia without any real good clinical data or anything. But anyway, it’s come, it’s pretty similar to NovoSeven, and it has taken over the Russian market. So it’s that dynamic that results in flat sales. So we actually do have volume increase in the treatment of people with Factor VIIa in emerging markets, but we’ve been losing out in Russia, and so that’s the balance

item.title: Sun Pharma Is Chasing Acquisitions in Brazil, Mexico and Russia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Economic Times has reoprted that Sun Pharma is searching for acquisitions in certain emerging markets in order to develop access and presence.
Sun Pharma already sells branded generics in these markets and has recently established manufacturing plants in Mexico and Brazil.
Looking ahead the company stated that its emphasis is on registering more complex generics such as anticancer injectables.
Amongst such developments candidates are long-acting formulations of goserelin and octreotide LAR. Dossier to conduct phI PK/PD US study with octreotide LAR formulation was planned to be submitted in April 2012. Priority development is the US which will then be followed by EU submission.
The Mumbai-based drugmaker reported Q1 net profit of 7.96 billion rupees ($143.88 million) up from 5.01 billion rupees a year earlier, a figure that significantly beat street estimates. Sales rose 62.5 per cent to 26.58 billion rupees helped by the robust busiiness of Israeli unit Taro Pharma.
Analysts, on an average, had forecast net profit at 6.82 billion rupees on sales 23.65 billion rupees.
Source: www.sunpharma.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Corcept Therapeutics Secures $30m in Financing To Support Product Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Corcept granted a Pharmakon Advisors fund rights to receive up to $45 million in royalties on Corcept’s products in exchange for $30 million in cash.

In April, Corcept launched Korlym mifepristone its first marketed product — in the U.S. to treat Cushing’s syndrome. Second quarter sales of Korlym were $875,000.

The fund, Biopharma Secured Debt Fund II Sub S.a.r.l, is eligible for 20% on net product sales beginning with 2Q13. Payments will be capped at $2.3 million per quarter in 2013, $3 million per quarter in 2014 and $3.8 million per quarter in 2015. There will be no quarterly caps starting in 2016 and beyond.

Additionally, the fund is eligible for 20% of upfront, milestone and other contingent payments received under co-promotion and out-licensing agreements. The fund’s royalty rights expire when it has received a total of $45 million.

Commenting on the deal Joseph Belanoff Corcept's CEO stated "This innovative transaction will provide Corcept with a significant amount of low-risk, non-dilutive capital that will help broaden and accelerate development of our product pipeline, including mifepristone for the treatment of psychotic depression and our extensive library of next-generation selective GR-II antagonists."
Source: corcept.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Tokai Appoints CMO and VP of Medical Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Tokai says that Dr Senderowicz brings valuable expertise to the development of its lead candidate, galeterone (TOK-001), which recently won an FDA fast-track designation from for metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.
Dr Adrian M Senderowicz has previously served as medical director of oncology clinical development at AstraZeneca. In this role he oversaw the US FDA approval of Caprelsa (vandetanib) for advanced medullary thyroid carcinoma. Before joining AstraZeneca, he held various senior positions at the FDA Division of Oncology Drug Products in the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research.
Source: Scrip 10 August 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: UK: NICE-backed Drugs Must be on NHS Contracts from April 2013
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinical Commission Groups will have to publish a list of all the treatments they provide on the NHS by April next year and will not be allowed to add any restrictions on NICE-approved treatments, under plans revealed by the head of the NHS.
In a letter to PCT, CCG and SHA chief executives NHS chief executive Sir David Nicholson said that PCT clusters and CCG leaders will have to publish information online in a ‘clear' and ‘transparent' way that sets out which NICE Technology Appraisals are included in their formularies.
The letter is at:
wp.dh.gov.uk/publ…
Source: PMLive/GPOnline 10 August 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: The Largest Product Growth Drivers of H1 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Therapy areas driving most growth in the first half of 2012 versus the same time period in 2011 are Oncology, Inflammation and Diabetes. Zytiga delivered the highest level of sales during this time period (out of the top 20 products described).
The top twenty products with the highest growth rates (within this time period) are listed below.
The most dominant area is Oncology accounting for six of these products. Zytiga delivered the highest level of absolute growth for the first six months of the year versus the same period in 2011 at $378million. In addition to Zytiga, BMS’s melanoma treatment, Yervoy generated $316million for the first six months following is approval in March last year.
The immunology/imflammation therapy area has seen the biggest challenge during this period with the threat of biosimilars with a version of Remicade launching in South Korea and approvals expected in other developed markets. It is understood that over 79 biosimilar MAbs are in development globally.
South Korea is rapidly becoming the hot bed of biosimilar activity as they have had a simple and well defined regulatory pathway which has been in place since 2009. It is understood that there are 13 on-going clinical trials in Korea for biosimilars in various therapy areas.
The products making up this list are dominated by products that were either launched as first in class therapies or offered substanical improvements in safety and efficacy. Providing further evidence of the heightened R&D challenge faced by the pharma industry with regards to the payors pushing for truly innovative or incrementally effective rather than simply new is going to be on the increase.
Source: FirstWord 9 August 2012
  1. table.jpg  (103,9 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Medivation's Second Quarter Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The second quarter update on Medivation’s Enzalutamide (formerly MDV3100) detailed recent milestones and clinical achievements. Interesting updates on clinical trial status but the majority has been previously published.
  • Enzalutamide PUDFA date is November 22, 2012
  • MAA submitted to the EMEA
  • Positive P3 AFFIRM results presented at ASCO 2012
  • Completed recruitment of sales and medical affairs personnel to support US launch this year - Medivation will provide 50% of field force (60 sales force from Medivation and approximately 100 from Astellas - selling additional products as well as Enzalutamide)
  • Completed target enrolment of PREVAIL (pre-chemo) = 1,680 patients
  • Enrolment is on-going for EU/USA based TERRAIN (370 metastatic patients) and US based STRIVE (400 metastatic/non-metastatic patients)
  • Completed patient enrolment (67) in an open-label clinical trial designed to evaluate the effect of Enzalutamide in advanced prostate cancer patients who have not had any previous hormonal therapies. Primary Endpoint is PSA
  • ASPIRE trial is opening with the aim to recruit 150 CRPC patients who are eligible to receive chemotherapy but have elected not to do so. Primary endpoint is rPFS
  • Enrolment has begun with Enzalutamide as neoadjuvant therapy in approximately 50 men prior to prostatectomy. Primary endpoint is pathological complete response rate
  • Enrolment is still on-going for a study looking at Enzalutamide when dosed in combination with docetaxel in 18 men
  • Phase I trial opened in breast cancer in 24 patients who have failed prior hormonal therapy
Revenue for the second quarter was $42.9million. Medivation became entitled to receive a $10 million milestone payment from Astellas upon the FDA's acceptance for filing of the Enzalutamide NDA with an expected additional $35 million in development milestone payments from Astellas in 2012. Medivation is required to share 10% of all development milestone payments received with the licensor of its Enzalutamide technology

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Medicis Second Quarter Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: DYSPORT® did exceptionally well this quarter with the Non-Acne products reporting an increase of 40.5% in sales while Acne products reported a decrease of 24%.
Medicis recorded revenues of approximately $81.1 million for the three months ending June 30, 2012 for their Non-Acne products range. This increase is due primarily to increased sales of DYSPORT®, the RESTYLANE® franchise, ZYCLARA® in the United States and ALDARA® in Canada.
Dysport in particular had its strongest quarterly demand since launch and saw a 5% increase in units sold compared to Q2 2011. This was mimicked by the RESTYLANE® franchise, enjoying its strongest second quarter since 2007.
Discussion in the Q&A session revolved around the Acne products and whether or not Medicis will stay independent to which Jonah Shacknai responded “In terms of whether we remain independent, I hope so. But at the end of the day we are here to serve the interests of our shareholders…we, like any other company; has an absolute obligation to consider offers from legitimate and credible parties. It isn’t my dream personally that that would happen, but I can assure you that my personal wishes would never interfere with a thoughtful consideration of something that came along again from a legitimate party….So I can’t predict our independence…But I think we have to operate with an expectation that we are an independent company and that we will remain so”
Medicis have 18 pipeline products and the company hopes to file an NDA for a therapeutic dermatology product in Q1 2013. No further information was disclosed regarding pipeline products.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: BMS To Acquire Amylin For $7bn & Then Integrate Products Into AZ Collaboration
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
BMS To Acquire Amylin For $7bn & Then Integrate Products Into AZ Collaboration 
Comment: BMS has today announced the acquisition of Amylin. Following the completion of the purchase, the company will then enter into a collaboration with AstraZeneca , based on their existing diabetes alliance, regarding the development and commercialisation of Amylin's portfolio of products.  ...
Bristol-Myers Squibb announced on 9 August 2012 that it has completed its $5-billion purchase of Amylin and its diabetes franchise.
AstraZeneca has also informed Bristol-Myers Squibb of its intention to exercise its option to acquire certain additional governance rights over key strategic and financial decisions regarding Amylin’s portfolio. The right to exercise this option will become effective once applicable anti-trust and competition approvals are received by AstraZeneca. Upon the exercise of the option an additional payment of $135 million will be made to Bristol-Myers Squibb.
Source: Pharmiweb 9 August 2012

item.title: Antisense Therapeutics Initiates PhII Acromegaly Programme
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has announced that Dr Peter Trainer Professor of Endocrinology at The Chrisite Hospital in Manchester will be the principal investigator for its forthcoming phII study of ATL1103 in acromegaly.
ATL1103's Profile
ATL1103 is a second generation antisense drug designed to block growth hormone receptor expression and thereby reducing the levels of IGF-1 in the blood.
PhII Study Status
ATL1103' PhII trial protocol has now been finalised and CRO ANP has been appointed to conduct the trial in Europe. First patients are expected to be dosed in Q42012.
Study Design
The phII trial will be a randomised, open-label parallel group study evaluating from a primary endpoint perspective the safety, tolerability, PK and efficacy of two subcutaneous doses of ATL1103 in 24 adult patients with acromegaly dosed with ATL1103 for 13 weeks. A secondary endpoint will be the impact of ATL1103 on serum IGF-1 levels.
Patients will either be treatment naive or have a washout period from acromegaly medication ranging from 6 weeks to 4 months depending on previous treatment. They will also be required to have a serum IGF-level> 1.3 x the upper limit of normal and a GH of >1ng/ml after an oral glucose tolerance test
The two subcutaneous dosing regimens to be evaluated will be:-
1. ATL1103 200mg three times in the first week then once weekly in weeks 2 through to week 13 for a total of 15 doses or
2. ATL1103 200mg three times in the first week then twice weekly in weeks 2 through to weeek 13 for a total of 27 doses.
Recruitment
The 11 sites envisaged for recruitment will include the folllowing countries:- UK Poland, Germany, France, Spain, Czech Republic and Lithuania.
Recruiting treatment naive patients may prove to be the easiest way forward for Antisense as there are two PhIII trials already ongoing in Europe one targeting inadequate responsders (pasireotide trial n=186) and the second stabilised SSA patients (oral octreolin n=150).
The main geographic overlap of all three trials will be in the UK, Germany, Italy and Romania. Please do feedback any information to the CI department on progress with recruitment if anything comes to your attention.
Source: www.antisense.com.au

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Inclusion of Octreotide In SmPC Harmonisation In 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
re: Inclusion of Octreotide In SmPC Harmonisation In 2012 
What are the potential and more concrete consequences ? Thanks in advance for any contribution on that. 
Further thoughts from Roz on the relevance of this development are outlined below:-
It will be of interest for us to monitor existing national Sandostatin & Sandostatin LAR claims that are retained and lost (if any) through the harmonisation process
  • The Sandostatin & Sandostatin LAR SmPCs that would emerge from the harmonization process would be expected to form the basis of the SmPCs for the generics/hybrids to follow for octreotide now it is off patent.
  • While the balance of Sandostatin claims retained or lost will depend primarily on the strength of Novartis' data, it's also likely to be a good indicator for the level of defence that could be needed for the Somatuline claims if/ when a harmonization is triggered for our own product(s)
It also suggests that wew should consider the timings one might anticipate for such a process to be triggered for Somatuline? Potentially, this could occur:-
  • due to a trigger from a national agency, in light of Sandostatin harmonization, if there's a high level of SSA class claims being made for Somatuline
  • following Somatuline patent expiry if there's the pressure of lanreotide generic and /or hybrids
  • a voluntary trigger on the part of Ipsen if, when bringing forward a new lanreotide product, it's considered advantageous for a new product in the range to be approved through a pan-European procedure such as the decentralised procedure (DCP)

item.title: GTx Q2 Earnings - Development Status Of Oral Prostate Cancer Programme
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: GTx is to begin screening patients this month for its phII study of Capesaris its oral selective estrogen receptor alpha agonist as a secondary hormonal therapy in men with metastatic CRPC.
The study will be an open-label trial conducted in 75 men to test three lower doses of Capesaris than previously tested (125mg, 250mg and 500mg) sequentially in cohorts of 25 patients.
This phII trial is deisgned to assess the effect of Capesaris on serum PSA response and prostate cancer progression. The study is expected to provide confirmation of the MOA of the drug in terms of its ability to lower serum free testosteron by increasing serum SHBG.
The safety and tolerability of these lower doses will also be evaluated with particular reference to the incidence of thromboembolic events, the side-effect that led to the drug being put on a clinical hold last year. It is looking to establish a VTE event rate of no higher than 3.8%
Efficacy and safety data from this study is expected to become available by the summer of 2013.
GTx's Financial Position
Financial highlights for the quarter ended June 30, 2012
The net loss for the quarter ended June 30, 2012 was $10.4 million compared to a net loss of $10.7 million for the same period in 2011.
Revenue for both the second quarter of 2012 and 2011 was $1.6 million and consisted of net sales of FARESTON® (toremifene citrate) 60 mg, approved for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women.
Research and development expenses for the quarter ended June 30, 2012 were $9.2 million compared to $7.6 million for the same period in 2011. General and administrative expenses for the quarter ended June 30, 2012 were $2.6 million compared to $4.5 million for the same period in 2011.
At June 30, 2012, GTx had cash and short-term investments of $55.9 million.
Source: http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c=148196&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1723612&highlight=

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Significant New Radiopharmaceutical Agreement
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: ImaginAb, Inc. a developer of in vivo molecular imaging agents has announced the signing of a MSA with Singapore Radiopharmaceuticals Pte Ltd, a company with an established track record in custom radiochemistry and cGMP product manufacturing. The agreement should help to accelerate the development of ImaginAb's cancer (prostate and pancreatic) and immunology imaging programs.
Nature Of The Technology
ImaginAb’s technology enables antibodies to be re-engineered into smaller proteins (fragments) with fast kinetics suitable for diagnostic imaging, while maintaining target biospecificity. In this way, true companion in vivo diagnostics can be rapidly developed that enable target expression to be profiled in tissues in a non-invasive, whole-body manner.
Company Financing
The company has been seed funded by a Series A financing – led by Novartis Venture Funds which raised $12.5m back in March this year.
The oversubscribed Series A round includes Merieux Developpement, Nextech Invest, Cycad Group and existing seed investor Momentum Biosciences. Novartis Venture Funds and Merieux Developpement have both appointed Directors as representatives of the Series A investors
Development Pipeline
ImaginAb has so far over a dozen development programs with global biopharma companies to develop companion diagnostic imaging agents to therapeutic antibody drugs (in Phase I to BLA), as well as an internal pipeline targeting unmet clinical needs, such as the staging of metastatic prostate and pancreatic cancer.
About Singapore Radiopharmaceuticals Pte Ltd
Founded in 2008 and part of the RadLink Group Asia, SRP provides GMP-compliant radiopharmaceuticals production using the GE 16.5 MeV PETtrace cyclotron and synthesis modules. Bespoke radiolabeling services include the use of Zirconium-89, Iodine-124 and Indium-111 isotopes. The company specializes in cGMP manufacture of proprietary tracers for clinical trials. SRP is dedicated to supplying beyond FDG tracers to all government and private hospitals in Singapore whilst supporting drug discovery programs for the pharmaceuticals industry.
Source: www.imaginab.com

item.title: re: Inclusion of Octreotide In SmPC Harmonisation In 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Inclusion of Octreotide In SmPC Harmonisation In 2012 
Comment: The latest list agreed by the CMDh and published in July includes Sandostatin & Sandostatin LAR. Its selection at this time is most likely linked to the product going off patent and the potential approval of generics/hybrids in due course.  ...
What are the potential and more concrete consequences ? Thanks in advance for any contribution on that.


Comments
Further thoughts from Roz on the relevance of this development are outlined below:-
It will be of interest for us to monitor existing national Sandostatin & Sandostatin LAR claims that are retained and lost (if any) through the harmonisation process
  • The Sandostatin & Sandostatin LAR SmPCs that would emerge from the harmonization process would be expected to form the basis of the SmPCs for the generics/hybrids to follow for octreotide now it is off patent.
  • While the balance of Sandostatin claims retained or lost will depend primarily on the strength of Novartis' data, it's also likely to be a good indicator for the level of defence that could be needed for the Somatuline claims if/ when a harmonization is triggered for our own product(s)
It also suggests that wew should consider the timings one might anticipate for such a process to be triggered for Somatuline? Potentially, this could occur:-
  • due to a trigger from a national agency, in light of Sandostatin harmonization, if there's a high level of SSA class claims being made for Somatuline
  • following Somatuline patent expiry if there's the pressure of lanreotide generic and /or hybrids
  • a voluntary trigger on the part of Ipsen if, when bringing forward a new lanreotide product, it's considered advantageous for a new product in the range to be approved through a pan-European procedure such as the decentralised procedure (DCP)

Add a Comment on this Article

View thread Endocrinology7047: Inclusion of Octreotide In SmPC Harmonisation In 2012

item.title: Exelixis Q2 Earnings - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Having received a fast-track designation from the FDA for cabozantinib in medullary thyroid cancer, managment noted its intention to file in Europe for the same indication in Q4 2012. The company refused to elaborate on its commerialisation strategy for MTC at this juncture, presumably because of restrictions associated with yesterday's announcement of a proposed public offering of 20 million shares of common stock and $225m of convertible senior subordinated notes due in 2019.
Updated on CRPC Programme
Exelixis's goal is to have about 280 sites for COMET-1 and about 50 sites for COMET-2. COMET-1 is designed to enroll 960 patients with CRPC, while COMET-2 is designed to enroll 246 patients. Both trials will enroll men, who have previously been treated with docetaxel and abiraterone and/or enzalutamide in any sequence. Expediting the initiation of clinical sites and enrollment of patients in the COMET study was claimed to be "a tough priority" for Exelixis, particularly as it is in addition to completing the NDA process in MTC and working on various combination studies in CRPC covering usage with docetaxel, but also one with abiraterone trials that will eventually pave the way forward into earlier CRPC treatment settings. Exelixis confirmed that it expects to have the first set of top line data in the first half of 2014.
Alongside its comments on CRPC, Exelixis also expanded on the nature of its CRADA agreed with the NCI covering 13 trials.
The first trials it will prioritize are six randomized Phase II trials in the settings of first line renal cell cancer, second line hepatocellular cancer, platinum resistant/refractory ovarian cancer, ocular melanoma, and two trials in non-small cell lung cancer.
Secondly, it will focus on other indications for further studies including single-arm Phase II trials in endometrial cancer, bladder cancer, sarcoma and differentiated thyroid cancer.
Thidly other trials, including Phase I combination trials in additional tumor types including CRPC in combination with docetaxel, melanoma in combination with Vemurafenib as well as a trial to evaluate cabozantinib in pediatric malignancies.
It was noted that for many of the randomized Phase II trials, detailed protocols have been developed by investigators and are being reviewed by CTEP and Exelixis. The expectation is that a most of these protocols will be completed soon and start the IRB approval process during the next several months paving the way for initiation later this year. In fact, CTEP has recently submitted the IND for the first study.
Then with regard to Exelixis own IST program it now has 10 ongoing ISTs including the more recently announced two additional ISTs in non-small cell lung cancer and multiple myeloma.
It claims that the IST program allows the company to evaluate cabozantinib in a variety of new indications quickly,a process which may faciliate new indications or combination regimens
Data Presentations In The Second Half
Data will be presented at both ESMO in September and at the European Thyroid Association Annual Conference and the American Thyroid Association Meeting, both of which also take place in September 2012. The planned presentations include further data from our ongoing Phase II trial in CRPC, as well as additional analysis from the EXAM in MTC.
Source: www.exelixis.com

item.title: Inclusion of Octreotide In SmPC Harmonisation In 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The latest list agreed by the CMDh and published in July includes Sandostatin & Sandostatin LAR. Its selection at this time is most likely linked to the product going off patent and the potential approval of generics/hybrids in due course.
The products selected for review (6 in total) takes into account criteria agreed by the CMDh mainly with regards to signficant differences in core parts of their SmPCs.
Thanks to Ros Eijgenhuijsen for drawing this to our attention.
http://www.hma.eu/fileadmin/dateien/Human_Medicines/CMD_h_/CMD_subgroups_working_groups/SPC_Harmonisation/2012_Draft_List_SmPC_Harmonisation.pdf

Comments
What are the potential and more concrete consequences ? Thanks in advance for any contribution on that.

Further thoughts from Roz on the relevance of this development are outlined below:-
It will be of interest for us to monitor existing national Sandostatin & Sandostatin LAR claims that are retained and lost (if any) through the harmonisation process
  • The Sandostatin & Sandostatin LAR SmPCs that would emerge from the harmonization process would be expected to form the basis of the SmPCs for the generics/hybrids to follow for octreotide now it is off patent.
  • While the balance of Sandostatin claims retained or lost will depend primarily on the strength of Novartis' data, it's also likely to be a good indicator for the level of defence that could be needed for the Somatuline claims if/ when a harmonization is triggered for our own product(s)
It also suggests that wew should consider the timings one might anticipate for such a process to be triggered for Somatuline? Potentially, this could occur:-
  • due to a trigger from a national agency, in light of Sandostatin harmonization, if there's a high level of SSA class claims being made for Somatuline
  • following Somatuline patent expiry if there's the pressure of lanreotide generic and /or hybrids
  • a voluntary trigger on the part of Ipsen if, when bringing forward a new lanreotide product, it's considered advantageous for a new product in the range to be approved through a pan-European procedure such as the decentralised procedure (DCP)

item.title: Recordati Buys Poland's Farma-Projek
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Recordati is to acquire Poland's Farma-Projekt, as part of its plans to expand in central and eastern Europe. The Polish company mainly markets cardiovascular and urology treatments, both key areas of therapeutic focus for Recordati from a commercialisation and development perspective.
Deal Terms

The Italian drugmaker is paying 71.0 million zloty (about 17.3 million euros) to get hold of the Krakow-headquartered company which has been in operation since 2003. Farma-Projekt employs around 135 staff, 84 of which are in sales and marketing. Turnover last year reached about 47 million zloty.

Chief executive Giovanni Recordati said the acquisition of Farma-Projekt is "another step forward in our strategy to increase our business in the central and eastern European markets which are growing at interesting rates”.

He noted that the Polish pharmaceutical market is the second largest in the area and in the last five years has been growing at an average annual rate of 6.8%. "In particular, the market for self-medication products has grown at an average rate of 11.2% per year", he concluded.

Recordati is already present in Poland, having set up a subsidiary in 2011. The transaction is set to close before the end of the year, subject to conditions.

Recordati's Urology Presence

The company's urology focus is commercially concentrated on the BPH market, its key product being Urorec (silodosin).

From a development standpoint, however, 50% of its development candidates have a urology focus, the most advanced being the phIII in-licensed BPH product Nymox (REC0482). Interestingly, the group has 3 overactive bladder/incontinence programmes including one focusing on spinal cord patients.

News of the acquisition comes a week after Recordati posted revenues of 419.9 million euros for the first six months of 2012, a rise of 4.7%. Net income edged up 1.5% to 63.3 million euros, helped by strong performances in Turkey and Russia.

source: www.recordati.com

item.title: Deal Making In Oligonucleotide Therapeutics Hots Up
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The eveolving interest in oligonucleotide chemistry continues with two more deals in this space, the first between Marina Biotech and Novartis the other. between Baylor College of Medicine and the private biotechnology company Gradalis Inc
Marina's Agreement
The agreement with Novartis covers its conformationally restricted nucleotide technology for the development of both single and double-stranded oligonucleotides. Marina will receive $1m in upfront fees for non-exclusive use.
Marina's current pirplien includes a clinical programm in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (a precancerous syndrome) and two preclinical programms in bladder cancer and malignant ascites, the former part of an exclusive development and commercialisation agreement with Debiopharm. The goupr also has agreements in place with Mirna therapeutics and Monsanto biotech.
Baylor College (BCM) Agreement
