item.title: Study - Poor Response of Children with Short Stature to Growth Hormone Therapies. Potential New Condition Definition and Treatments Guidelines
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:The incidence of insufficient responses to GH therapies have forced clinicians to find a more appropriate definition of “poor response” and to modify current drug treatments.
The review describes the relevant parameters for a correct definition of “poor response” taking into account History and physical examination, Hormonal status, Radiological assessment and Genetic assessment.
The relevant parameters of poor response to the GH therapy are also described. They concern: Growth during the first year of GH therapy, Age-dependency of responses, Reference data reported on NCGS and KIGS databases, Response related to diagnosis, Definitions of poor response, Definition of clinical benefit and Biomarkers of GH response.

Strategies for treatment of children with poor response to GH therapy
The authors summarize some general rules for approacing the patient treatment: the GH therapy should be assessed throughout the 12 months. In the case of poor response they show several options as described by the algorithm of the Fig. 5 (file attached).
Conclusions
Best recognition of poor response helps the clinicians to recognize the variability of growth disorders applying more individualized therapy that contributes to more appropriate treatment strategies.

The authors of this article are members of the advisory board for Ipsen.
Source:
Peter Bang, S. Faisal Ahmed, Jesu´s Argente,, Philippe Backeljauw, Markus Bettendorf, Gianni Bona, Regis Coutant, Ron G. Rosenfeld, Marie-Jose´ Walenkamp and Martin O. Savage
Identification and management of poor response to growth-promoting therapy in children with short stature.
Clinical Endocrinology (2012) 77, 169–181.
Full Text online here:
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2265.2012.04420.x/pdf

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Study - 2-years Results of Octreotide LAR for Severe Polycystic Liver Disease: Results after 2 years
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: An open-label extension for one additional year to assess safety and clinical benefits of continued use of OctLAR for 2 years (O→O) and examined drug effect in the placebo group who crossed over to OctLAR in Year 2 (P→O). Us Mayo clinic team.
Somatostatin analog therapy for severe polycystic liver disease: results after 2 years.
Background: We showed in a randomized double-blinded placebo-controlled clinical trial that octreotide long-acting repeatable depot.® (OctLAR(®)) for 12 months reduces kidney and liver growth in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney patients with severe polycystic liver disease (PLD) and liver growth in patients with severe isolated PLDMethods: The primary end point was change in total liver volume (TLV) measured by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); secondary end points were changes in total kidney volume (TKV) measured by MRI, glomerular filtration rate (GFR), quality of life (QOL), safety, vital signs and laboratory parameters.
Results: Forty-one of 42 patients received OctLAR (n = 28) or placebo (n = 14) in Year 1 and received OctLAR in Year 2 (maximum dose 40 mg). Patients originally randomized to placebo (P→O) showed substantial reduction in TLV after treatment with OctLAR in Year 2 (Δ% -7.66 ± 9.69%, P = 0.011). The initial reduction of TLV in the OctLAR group (O→O) was maintained for 2 years (Δ% -5.96 ± 8.90%), although did not change significantly during Year 2 (Δ% -0.77 ± 6.82%). OctLAR inhibited renal enlargement during Year 1 (Δ% +0.42 ± 7.61%) in the (O→O) group and during Year 2 (Δ% -0.41 ± 9.45%) in the (P→O) group, but not throughout Year 2 (Δ% +6.49 ± 7.08%) in the (O→O) group. Using pooled analyses of all individuals who received OctLAR for 12 months, i.e. in Year 1 for O→O patients and Year 2 for P→O patients, average reduction in TLV was -6.08 ± 7.58% (P = 0.001) compared to net growth of 0.9 ± 8.35% in the original placebo group. OctLAR-treated individuals continued to experience improvements in QOL in Year 2, although overall physical and mental improvements were not significant during Year 2 compared to Year 1. Changes in GFR were similar in both groups.
Conclusion: Over 2 years, Oct LAR significantly reduced the rate of increase in TLV and possibly the rate of increase in TKV.
Nephrol Dial Transplant. 2012 Jul 6. [Epub ahead of print] Somatostatin analog therapy for severe polycystic liver disease: results after 2 years.Hogan MC, Masyuk TV, Page L, Holmes DR 3rd, Li X, Bergstralh EJ, Irazabal MV, Kim B, King BF, Glockner JF, Larusso NF, Torres VE.
43rd Annual Meeting Renal Week 2010, Denver, CO, USA, November 16 – 21 2010 [F-PO1823] Somatostatin Analog Therapy for Severe Polycystic Liver Disease: Results after Two Years
J Am Soc Nephrol. 2010 Jun;21(6):1052-61. Randomized clinical trial of long-acting somatostatin for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney and liver disease.Hogan MC, Masyuk TV, Page LJ, Kubly VJ, Bergstralh EJ, Li X, Kim B, King BF, Glockner J, Holmes DR 3rd, Rossetti S, Harris PC, LaRusso NF, Torres VE.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Intelligence From The ADA Meeting In June - The Popularity Of The GLP-1 Analogues
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Pascal Birman (Drug Development Director), we have interesting feedback on development activities with the GLP-1 analogues, following his recent attendance at the US ADA meeting. Importantly, he noted how
New Guidelines
New hyperglycaemia treatment guidelines for type 2 diabetes were released by the EASD/ADA in April 2012. The key messages were:-
  • Adopt a patient centered approach with individualized decisions
  • Target a HbA1c <7% with key criteria for decision
  • 1st line medical treatment should be metformin
  • 2nd line medical treatment should include 1 of 5 option including a GLP-1 analogue.
  • The decision should be made with the patient focusing onn his/her preferences needs and values
The guidelines are published by Inzucchi et al in Diabetes Care 2012
GLP-1 Class Perception
GLP-1 analogues are considered as the most potent antidiabetic drugs with a good safety profile offering an excellent improvement in HbA1c similar or greater than other drugs plus moderate weight loss which is a unique efficacy parameter amongst anti-hyperglycaemic drugs.
  • Liraglutide is considered the most potent
  • Exenatide bid provides the best effect on post prandial hyperglycamia
  • Exenatide LAR (Bydureon is the best tolerated)
  • Lixisenatide OD will come soon submitted to the EMA Q411 and to be submitted to the FDA Q412. It is less potent than liraglutide but has been effectively combined with insulin.
The attached presentation Pascal has compiled highlights:-
  1. Recent data on lixisenatide in combination with insulin the GETGOAL studies
  2. Data on Albiglutide (GSK) in combination with insuln
  3. Other new areas for GLP-1
The last topic highlights:-
  • The development of a new oral formulation Zyogi by Zydus research;
  • The development of a new weekly subcutaneous version of exenatide;
  • Interest in the use of GLP-1 analogues in pre-diabetes stage (Novo Nordisk is conducting a study); and,
  • The future development of small molecules to target G-protein receptors that may stimulate the endogenous secretion of hGLP1.
Finally, there is a slide on some key developments with insulin and comments on some of the other new molecules in development such as the SGLT2 inhibitors.

item.title: French HAS Plans to Introduce New HTA Index for P&R
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: France's Transparency Commission (Haute Autorité de Santé, HAS) on 6 July confirmed plans to introduce a new way of evaluating medicines in order to set their price and reimbursement status. The commission is working on the elaboration of an index that would replace the SMR (Service Médical Rendu) and ASMR (Amélioration du Service Médical Rendu) ratings currently used to respectively inform the reimbursement rate and price of medicines in France.
The new index, the Relative Therapeutic Index, could be introduced at the beginning of 2013 as part of the next Bill on Financing Social Security (LFSS). More details will be provided towards the end of September 2012.
According to Jean-Luc Harousseau, president of the HAS, the new index would allow the French public insurance and its pricing committee, CEPS, to determine the reimbursement and price of pharmaceuticals based on a comparison versus alternatives that are currently available on the market (source: lepharmacien.fr). The LFSS 2013 could also include an amendment that would render systematic the delisting of drugs that are deemed to have an insufficient therapeutic value (SMR).
This confirms that the French pricing and reimbursement system is expected to become less generous in the near term, with drugs brining no improvement in terms of therapeutic value set to suffer the most from upcoming reforms.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: UK: Doctors Banned from Remotely Prescribing Cosmetic Injectables
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: New guidance has been issued by the General Medical Council (GMC) and comes into effect on 23 July 2012. Doctors who continue to prescribe Botox or similar products remotely will be putting their registration at risk.
The change means that doctors must have face-to-face consultations with patients before prescribing Botox and other injectable cosmetics to ensure they fully understand the patient’s medical history and reasons for wanting the treatment.
A copy of the new remote prescribing guidance is at: www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethical_guidance/13594.asp
Source: GMC 12 July 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: AstraZeneca To Invest Over $150 Mn in a Manufacturing Hub in Russia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : AZ to join a group of other pharma companies on a hub that should starts producing before this year end.
The hub will start with six residents — Denmark’s Novo Nordisk, British-Swedish AstraZeneca, Germany’s Stada and Italy’s Menarini, as well as domestic drugmakers –Nearmedic and SpheraPharm- that already have a presence in the region, having jointly invested more than $500 million in their production facilities, creating 1,500 new jobs.
AZ plant will encompass a full production cycle, from medicine component preparation to packaging and is understood to include AZ oncological, cardiological, gastroenterological, psychiatric product ranges.
The overall investment by foreign companies in Russia’s pharmaceutical industry over the last three years has exceeded 800 Mln € ($992 Mln), according to the head of the Industry and Trade Ministry. This includes various types of investment, with foreign drugmakers setting up manufacturing, buying into local companies or establishing J-Vs with them.
The country’s pharma industry grew 17 percent last year and is expected to maintain this growth rate in 2012, and the industry’s total revenue might reach $23 Bn this year.
Source : The Moscow Times / RT News Network

item.title: WW Regulatory Filing of GSK's Once-Weekly GLP-1 Planned Early 2013
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Human Genome Sciences and partner GSK have reported positive data from the Ph3 Harmony 8 trial. Results show albiglutide was superior to sitagliptin (Januvia) on the primary endpoint of reducing HbA1c from baseline to week 26.
The remaining 5 trials are expected to complete in early 2013.
Please see Endocrinology6902: Ph3 Results of GSK's Albiglutide (Once-Weekly GLP-1) Support Progression to Regulatory Filing.
Albiglutide will compete with Novo's Victoza, AZN/BMS' Bydureon/Byetta, Sanofi's Lyxumia and Lilly's dulaglutide.

item.title: Study - Oral Octreotide Absorption in Human Subjects
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : Already signalled in April as a preprint but now full pagination in JCEM. The authors conclude that the results support an oral octreotide alternative to parenteral octreotide treatment for patients with acromegaly. Please find the abstract below.
Oral Octreotide Absorption in Human Subjects : Comparable Pharmacokinetics to Parenteral Octreotide and Effective Growth Hormone Suppression.
Context:Oral administration of a novel octreotide formulation enabled its absorption to the systemic circulation, exhibiting blood concentrations comparable to those observed with injected octreotide and maintaining its biological activity.
Objectives:The aim of the study was to determine oral octreotide absorption and effects on pituitary GH secretion compared to sc octreotide injection.
Design:Four single-dose studies were conducted in 75 healthy volunteers.Intervention:Oral doses of 3, 10, or 20 mg octreotide and a single sc injection of 100 μ g octreotide were administered.
Main Outcome Measure:We measured the pharmacokinetic profile of orally administrated octreotide and the effect of octreotide on basal and stimulated GH secretion.
Results:Both oral and sc treatments were well tolerated. Oral octreotide absorption to the circulation was apparent within 1 h after dose administration. Escalating oral octreotide doses resulted in dose-dependent increased plasma octreotide concentrations, with an observed rate of plasma decay similar to parenteral administration. Both 20 mg oral octreotide and injection of 0.1 mg sc octreotide resulted in equivalent pharmacokinetic parameters [mean peak plasma concentration, 3.77 ± 0.25 vs. 3.97 ± 0.19 ng/ml; mean area under the curve, 16.2 ± 1.25 vs. 12.1 ± 0.45 h×ng/ml); and median time ≥0.5 ng/ml, 7.67 vs. 5.88 h, respectively). A single dose of 20 mg oral octreotide resulted in basal (P < 0.05) and GHRH-stimulated (P < 0.001) mean GH levels suppressed by 49 and 80%, respectively.
Conclusions:The results support an oral octreotide alternative to parenteral octreotide treatment for patients with acromegaly.

Authors: Tuvia S, Atsmon J, Teichman SL, Katz S, Salama P, Pelled D, Landau I, Karmeli I, Bidlingmaier M, Strasburger CJ, Kleinberg DL, Melmed S, Mamluk R.

Source: J Clin Endocrinol Metab 2012;97 2362-2369


Comments
....then ,it is possible to calculate the absolute oral bioavailability of the proposed formulation which is : 0.5% (0.1/20) , and as a consequence , novartis will probably need to build a new API plant to produce 100 times more peptide to treat the same volume of patients !!!....... and also have to support a huge manufacturing price increase !
it is simply not realistic !
Bruno

item.title: Slovak Health Minister Plans to Change the Country's International-Pricing System (IRP)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: It is reported by Slovak newspaper SME that changes may be made to the IRP. One possibility that has been discussed is for prices of drugs in Slovakia to be referenced to the average of the three lowest-priced markets in the EU. This is because some problems have materialised with the supply of some drugs as a result of the very low prices in the country.

The value of the Slovak pharmaceutical market in 2011 reached EUR1.193 billion (USD1.465 billion) in 2011, according to information provided by the Slovak National Health Information Centre. Based on the estimate of the market's value for 2010 given by the Statistical Office of the Slovak Republic (EUR1.118 billion), the Slovak pharmaceutical market grew by 6.71% year-on-year in 2011.
In volume terms, the total number of packages sold in 2011 is reported to have reached 126.672 million, of which some 90.631 million were prescription medicines. Health insurance funds provided a reported EUR897.525 million in reimbursement spending on these prescription medicines, while the total amount patients spent on them—in the form of co-payments—reached EUR175.751 million. The total value of the sales of non-prescription medicines reached EUR119.839 million, or 36.040 million packages in volume terms.

Meanwhile, according to data from the Healthcare Surveillance Authority (UDZS), there was an increase of 5.1% y/y in the amount of money spent by Slovaks on healthcare from their own pockets, with the total reportedly reaching EUR1.203 billion. The UDZS reports that in 2011, there was a 2.1% y/y increase in total healthcare expenditure to EUR4.904 billion, with public spending reaching EUR3.7 billion. Healthcare's share of GDP in Slovakia is reported to have increased from 7.3% in 2010 to 7.4% in 2011.
Looking at the top 10 pharmaceutical companies in Slovakia during 2011, based on data from IMS Health quoted by the Slovak Association of Research-based Pharmaceutical Companies, French major Sanofi occupied the first place, with sales of EUR121.71 million, bolstered by the strong position of its generic branch Zentiva on the Slovak market. The Swiss duo of Novartis and Roche were in second and third places respectively, at some considerable distance behind the market leader.

item.title: Ranbaxy to Enter the Biosimilar Space
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ranbaxy's plans is to launch at least 3 biosimilars mostly to treat cancer, in Indi by 2015. The company's strategy is to seek EU and US approvals 4 to 5 years after India launches.
The (undisclosed) biosimilar the company plans to introduce in India next year has the potential for global annual sales in "the hundreds of millions of dollars".
In 2008, DS acquired a majority stake in Ranbaxy (See PharmaWorld6632: Japan's Daiichi Sankyo to acquire majority stake in Ranbaxy).

item.title: Corcept Raises $46.4m in Financing
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Corcept raised $46.4m late Friday through the sale of 11 million shares at $4.22 per share in a placement organised by Credit Suisse. Corcept is marketing Korlym (mifepristone) in the US to treat Cushing's syndrome.
The money has been raised to support the group's ongoing R&D activities with its progesterone and cortisol receptor anatagonist in pychotic depression and to support the group's working capital and general corporate purposes.

item.title: Acino Is Confident to Have the First "Generic" Goserelin Coming to the Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a trading statement announcing its half-year 2012 sales result, Acino has reported that the goserelin 1M and 3M implant are expected to be launched H2:12 in several Middle Eastern and African countries. The company plans first EU approvals of goserelin and leuprorelin in late 2015. As reported in the company PR, goserelin is called 'generic' and not 'hybrid'.
In EU
In support of the EU filing, additional studies will be conducted with both drugs. With a delay of approx. 18 months for submitting the additional study results, Acino expects first approvals in late 2015.
In Japan
Clinical trials (performed by the licensee ? see DKPHybrids44: Acino Concludes Japanese Oncology Licensing Deal) expected to start by the end of 2012.
The company has announced total revenues grew by 98% to €128.9M (including 4 and a half months trading of Mepha and Cephalon business).
(please see DKPHybrids107: Why the Mepha/Cephalon Acquisition Represents a" Game Changer").
The half-year report 2012 will be published on August 2, 2012, accompanied by an investor conference call with webcast at 10.00 hrs.
Acino expects FY sales to reach €240 to 260M.

item.title: Trial to Assess Medical/Economic Impact of Urinary PCA3 Test in France
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Seven renowned French Professors will be assessing the medical and economic impact of Gen-Probe's Progensa introduction into medical practice in France. Primary endpoints will measure proportion of patients who inappropriately underwent prostate biopsies at end point.
Proposed in clinical practice in France as a commercial kit, Progensa is expensive, and not covered by health insurance. It is therefore essential to assess the medical and economic impact of its introduction into medical practice.
Condition: patients scheduled for prostate biopsy because of increased serum PSA and/or abnormal DRE
Recruitment: approx 650
Start date: June 2012 - Completion dates: June 2019 / Dec. 2019

Recruitment: approx. 122 participants

item.title: ENDO Intelligence - Part Three - NET & Octreolin
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The majority of the data on Octeolin had previously been presented and confirmation that Octreolin phase III safety and efficacy study has just started enrolling with a target of 150 patients (20mg — 40mb BID). Duration will be 7-9 months. NET sessions of interest again have previously been presented at ENETS and repackaged by Pavel.
It is understood that Pfizer are aiming to develop a PFS device for PegV similar to their mini-Quick used for their rhGH (Gentropin). They are currently in the process of obtaining feedback from their US advisors. We are unclear of the status in EU and ROW.
A big thanks to Christine Massien for helping collect information during the pasireotide poster sessions and to Neven Pessa for intelligence on PegV device.
As mentioned earlier, data from Octreolin has previously been published but a review of safety data and GH suppression is found below
During the NET session, Marianne Pavel walked us through the evolution of therapy, therapeutic options, targets and novel agents, results from placebo controlled trials, impact of novel agents on current therapy (discussed everolimus and sunitinib ) of NET and future perspectives. The content and slide set was a well presented but repackaged from previous congresses such as ENETS. The majority of the slides/data has been previously published on Traction.
Pavel only discussed publically known trials/data and did not allude to any real details of ongoing studies (a part from RADIANT-4 and COOPERATE -2 when she showed the study schema only (previously published on Traction).
During the discussion, Pavel highlighted pathways of interest, followed by a slide depicting developmental and avaliable drugs respective to their MOA.
She concluded the talk with a review of where the therapy stands and her views on future perspectives.
During Steven Libutti’s talk on the role of aggressive surgery in GI NETs, he presented a new study taking place at his centre — Albert Einstein College of Medicine (and others) - E2212: A Randomised Double Blind Placebo Controlled Phase II Study Of Adjuvant Everolimus Following The Resection Of Metastatic Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumours To The Liver. ECOG exec approval conditional was given in 2/2012, MET TF review was scheduled for 5/2012 and GISC submission goal is July 2012.
Background to the study followed by study schema and key eligibility criteria follows:
Poster: Pasireotide and Octreotide LAR Was an Effective Combination in a Patient With Small Intestinal NET With Hypokalemia and a High Level of VIP http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=a84c5
A case study with a 70yr old woman who underwent bowel and liver resection surgery for a small intestinal NET in 1991. In between 1991 — 200, she underwent radiofrequency ablation of liver metastases 6 times.
  • Interferon was initiated and then stopped in 2006 due to adverse events (depression and muscle pain)
  • Increasing bouts of diarrhea in 2007/8 (10 per 24 hrs)
  • Sc octretoide and potassium substitution were initiated
  • 2008, discontinued and started with pasireotide sc (1200 µg 2xdaily)
  • 2008 liver mets were confirmed and high levels of circulating VIP were detected during this time
  • IM octreotide LAR(30mg every 4th week) was added to pasireotide
  • This combination decrease the bouts of diarrhea to 3-4 times a day and need for potassium substitution decreased
  • VIP level decreased from 788pmol/L in October 2008 to the lowest level of 79pmol/L in October 2010
  • Patient is still alive

item.title: Alternative for the Future Development of Medy-Tox' MT10109
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Analysts @ Woori have reported that under completion of the POC trial (ongoing in Australia), Medy-Tox may plan to either pursue a licensing out deal with multinational pharmas based in the US and EU or opt to internally carry out the Ph3 trials. On June 18, Medy-Tox was listed by Korea's Ministry of Health & Welfare among the 43 innovative pharma firms. Incentives for the selected companies include R&D-related help and loan for drugs for export. Interestingly, we have noted that Daewoong, which recently started a Ph3 with its toxin, is part of the selection.
List of Companies
The government and pharmaceuticals industry participants will meet in July to discuss incentives, aiming to confirm details this year and put most benefits into effect from 2013.
On June 18, the company was selected as one of the 43 pharmas to participate in the Ministry of Health and Welfare's pharma program aimed at fostering innovative domestic pharmas.
Benefits of the Program
These firms will be give several incentives (including tax support, favorable drug pricing, R&D-related assistance, and financial loan support for drugs for export purposes).
Medytox is likely to receive extend loans (up to W100bn at an interest rate 0.5%p lower market lending rates over the next 8 years), equivalent to 90% of Ph3 clinical trials costs for its next-generation Meditoxin.
Indication: CD (Please see Neurology6371: New POC Trial of Medy-Tox' MT10109 Versus Botox(R) for Cervical Dystonia)
Indication: Glabellar Line (Please see Neurology6149: New Study of Medy-Tox' s New BTA Formulation Versus Botox(R) in Glabellar Frown Lines)
Indication: Glabellar Line (Please see Neurology6487: New Trial of Daewoong's Botulinum Toxin for Glabellar Line).
Of note, Daewoong is Peptron licensee for Luphere Depot (an hybrid of leuprorelin).

item.title: PhI Safety & Efficacy Data On The Combination of Pasireotide & Afinitor
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: PhI results from a combination study evaluating the safety and MTD of pasireotide and Afinitor (RAD-001) have been published in the journal of Endocrine Related Cancer. We believe the outcome from this study is what has underpinned the development of the Novartis sponsored COOPERATE I & II studies, recruitment for which is ongoing.
PhI Study Design
The study sponsored by the Dana Farber Cancer Institute (Jenifer Chan was the Primary Investigator) was initiated in 2008 and enrolled 21 patients with locally unresectable or metastatic neuroendocrine tumor. The study originally planned to enroll 32 patients and was due to complete in November this year.
Patients had confirmed low-grade or intermediate-grade neuroendocrine carcinoma. Patients with poorly differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma, high-grade neuroendocrine carcinoma, adenocarcinoid, goblet cell carcinoid, and small cell carcinoma were not eligible.
Cohorts of patients were treated with escalating doses of pasireotide 600-1200mg s.c. bd for 4 weeks followed by pasireotide LAR 40-60mg IM monthly and everolimus 5-10mg orally daily.
PhI Study Results
Dose limiting toxicities of grade 3 rash and diarrhoea were observerd but 12 patients were safely treated with the maximum protocol-defined dose level of each drug. Hyperglycaemia was a common feature, whilts other toxicities observed were consistent with the known safety profile of each drug.
From an efficacy standpoint, one patient had a partial response whilst 17 (81%) experiences some tumour regression.
The investigators conclude that combination therapy is feasible and showed some preliminary evidence of anti-tumour activity which warrents further investigation.
This is now underway in the shape of the COOPERATE I & II studies.
COOPERATE-I is a larger phI study sponsored by Novartis being undertaken in Germany in patients with a confirmed diagnosis of grade 1/2 advanced pulmonary or gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumor functioning and non-functioning patients. Those with non-functioning disease are required to have progressive disease within last 12 months.
The study design includes six treatment arms as follows which will thoroughly evaluate all possible combinations in both pre-treated and treatment naive patients.
  • Functional tumours, pre-treated - pasireotide followed by pasireotide & everolimus
  • Functional tumours, treatment naive (similar treatment schedule)
  • Nonfunctional tumours, pretreated 1 - pasireotide followed by pasireotide and eveolimus
  • Nonfunctional tumours, pretreated 2 - everolimus followed by pasireotide and everolimus
  • Nonfunctional tumours treatment naive 1 - pasireotide followed by pasireotide and everolimus
  • Nonfunctional tumours treatment naive 2 - everolimus followed by pasireotide and everolimus.
The study started in November 2010 and is scheduled to complete in May 2014 and the primary endpoint is safety and tolerability.
Key centres involved in the study include, Bad Berka, Berlin, Marburg, Muenster and Tumbingen.
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01263353
COOPERATE-2 an openn-label phII study will evluate combination treatment in patients with progressive advanced pNET in 150 patients. It started in June 2011 and is estimated to complete in September 2015. Its primary endpoint is PFS using RECIST criteria. This second study is a global study involving 59 centres across the US, Europe, Asia & Latin Amerca.
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01374451
source: http://erc.endocrinology-journals.org/content/early/2012/06/26/ERC-11-0382.abstract

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Merck's EXPAND Trial Fails To Meet Primary Endpoint in Gastric Cancer Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Erbitux in combination with cisplatin and capecitabine did not significantly increase progression-free survival in patients with advanced gastric cancer.
The combination was studied as a first-line treatment for patients with advanced gastric adenocarcinoma including adenocarcinoma of the gastro-oesophageal junction.
Patients with advanced gastric cancer currently have few treatment choices and a poor prognosis so the results are disappointing.
EXPAND was a multi-center, open-label, randomized, controlled trial in 904 patients at 150 centers in 25 countries across Latin America, Europe, Asia Pacific and Japan. Patients had unresectable advanced cancer and had received no prior treatment with chemotherapy or radiotherapy in this setting. Usually, these patients would receive palliative chemotherapy only.
Source: merckgroup.com

item.title: ENDO Intelligence - Part One - Pasireotide in Cushings Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Although Novartis did not hold a sponsored symposia, pasireotide posters were in abundance. Data from the B2305 core and extension study were presented with an oral session covering early response to treatment. Pasireotide in Cushings will launch in the US in November 2012.
At the booth, hand-outs included: CSOM230B2406 (SEASCAPE) trial — an open label, multi-centre expanded access study of pasireotide sc in patients with CD - target enrollment of 300 patients. Another hand-out was the phase III study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pasireotide LAR in patients with CD.
During the poster sessions, talk revolved around the side effect profile of pasireotide (hyperglycemia). It is clear that NVS had briefed all the presenters in how to handle these challenges. The message from NVS on this matter is focused on early detection followed by aggressive treatment. When speaking with K. Hermosillo, he declared that ‘we made a big mistake in that NVS did not communicate to the centres quickly enough to treat the patients aggressively, rather we told the Investigators to adopt a wait and watch position, it was not a good idea and we are paying for it now’
In order to address the hyperglycemia issue (which is more of a concern in CD patients), NVS are currently designing a trial in CD patients using incretins. The trial is expected to be up and running before the end of the year.
Interestingly there was a poster by HA Schmid demonstrating the PK and PD effects of pasireotide IR and LAR in rats and mice that showed pasireotide LAR appears to be associated with smaller and more transient elevations in glucose levels than paireotide sc in both
species.http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=6eb97
Data from on initial response to pasireotide treatment was presented by Andre Lacroix - results are from the B2305 core study.
The overall message from the session was that patients who do not respond biochemically within the first two months are unlikely to respond at a later time point. These patients who do have an early biochemical response, stay on treatment longer and approximately 50% continue to respond.
The results showed that pasireotide treatment leads to rapid and sustained decrease in mean UFC with a similar trend in ACTH and serum cortisol being observed. Early responders tend to have greater improvements in weight, BMI, blood pressure and cholesterol to those who are uncontrolled.
A reminder of the study schema is below:
Results are as follows:
Posters (see study design above)
Pasireotide Treatment In CD Is Associated With Significant Improvements In Hypertension: 12 Months Results From A Large P3 Study - http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=8a5c0
  • From baseline to month six, mean (±SE) SBP decreased from 133.5± 1.5mmHg to 125.5± 1.2mmHg (p=0.001), and mean DBP decreased from 86.3± 1.0mmHg to 82.8±1.0mmHg (p=0.0024). These decreases were maintained to month 12
  • Significant decrease in SBP and DBP were seen in the subset of patients whose UFC levels were controlled at month 6
  • Significant improvements in SBP and DBP from baseline to month 12 were seen in patients with baseline hypertension
Pasireotide Treatment Is Associated With Clinically Meaningful Improvements in Health Related QoL In CD: Results From A Large P3 Study http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=25f92
  • In both dose groups, HRQoL including weight improved from baseline to month 3 along with rapid and sustained decreases in UFC levels
  • By month 12, there was clinically meaningful improvement in HRQoL in patients whose UFC levels were controlled (n=29); mean improvement: 12.8, 95% CI: 7:1, 18.5) or partially controlled at month 6 (n=17); mean improvement: 10:7, 95% CI: 0.8, 20.5)
Long-Term Pasireotide Use Leads To Significant And Sustained Improvements In The Signs And Symptoms Of CD: 24 Months Results From A Randomized P3 Study
http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=39912
  • The mean percentage decrease in UFC that occurred during the core study(54.7%[95% CI: 37.6, 71.8]) was sustained throughout the extension phase: mean percentage decrease from core baseline to month 24 was 59.5% (95% CI: 50.5,68.6) for all patients who entered the extension (n=58)
  • Of the 58 patients, the proportion with UFC ≤ULN at 12,18,24 months was 38.5%, 46.2% and 30.8% in the 600μg bid group and 59.4%, 40.6% and 37.5% in the 900μg bid group respectively
  • Sustained mean reductions from baseline in serum cortisol and plasma ACTH levels were observed
  • Further improvements on SBP and DBP as well as weight decrease were observed
  • Mean change from baseline in total cholesterol levels was -8.5% and -5.8% at 12 and 24 months
Pasireotide As A Long-Term Treatment For Patients With CD: 24 Months Safety Results From A Randomized P3 Study http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=8cd91
  • AEs include diarrhea (56%), nausea (48.1%), hyperglycemia (38.9%) and cholelithiasis (31.5%)
  • Compared to the 12 months data cut-off - Mean increase in HbA1c increased from 5.8% at core baseline to 7.2 and 6.8% at months 12 and 24 respectively
  • Mean fasting glucose icreased from 97.8 mg/dL at core baseline to 117.7 and 119.5 mg/dL at months 12 and 24 respectively

item.title: Paper: Purified Botulinum Type A Neurotoxin in Patients with Urinary Incontinence and Prostatic Hyperplasia.
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The purified toxin was used to treat 49 patients with urinary incontinence, 36 patients showed significant improvement in symptoms. These beneficial effects were also observed in cases of prostatic hyperplasia.
The authors suggest that the purified toxin has less immunoenhancing activity.
Full text (open access) is at: http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jt/2012/648384/
Source: Journal of Toxicology epub 14 June 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Withdrawal of Co-Payment for 456 Drugs Expected to Increase Prices in Spain
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The withdrawal of governmental co-payment for 456 low-intensity illness drugs that came into force on 1 July in Spain is expected to increase the price of such drugs in the short-to-medium term as they will no longer be regulated under the government's co-payment scheme. The co-payment withdrawal is expected to save the government EUR440 million (USD 556 million).
According to La Opinion de Zamora, among those drugs to be affected are antacid tablets such as Almax (almagato); anti-haemorrhoidal treatments such as Synalar (fluocinolone acetonide); anti-inflammatory drugs such as Voltaren (diclofenac); mucolytics such as acetylcysteine; cough and cold mixtures; and artificial tears.
According to Jose Espinosa Navarro, president of the Zamora Pharmaceutical Association, cited by the source, with this move, the government plans to open up space for more innovative drugs to be inserted on the list of drug co-payments in the medium term. According to the source, although 456 drugs are expected to be affected by the new decree in the medium-to-long term, 426 drugs have been affected already. According to the source, the 456 drugs awaiting withdrawal cost the government EUR458 million in 2011, so the cuts are expected to save the government EUR440 million by end of 2012.

The withdrawal of the drugs from the national co-payment list is aimed at lowering Spain's healthcare expenditure and boosting the national healthcare budget together with the announced price increase of chronic illness drugs as well as the one-euro-per-prescription measure which has been enforced in some regions.
Although these measures are expected to benefit the government's coffers, they will most likely have a long-term negative impact on the revenues of pharmacies across the country as patients are expected to purchase less drugs as a consequence of possible rising prices for those drugs that have been withdrawn from the co-payment scheme.
The new set of austerity measures, including co-payment withdrawal of over-the-counter drugs as part of Royal Decree 16/2012, may be an effective relief to the strain on public healthcare in the short-to-medium term, but is not expected to be a sustainable option for the public in the long term as it will add a financial burden on the population as well as affecting pharmacy revenues.
Source: GlobalInsight

Comment: Algeta is about to file EMA and FDA in H2:12. The drug, which is likely to extend the 'chemotherapy-free' window, is anticipated to be approved in H1:13 in EU and US. Bayer expects the drug has potential to be a blockbuster.
Algeta will co-promote the drug (50/50 profit/loss sharing) in the US with bayer.

item.title: Ferring Acquires Licensing Rights for Albireo's GI Drug
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The agreement is one of the biggest investments made by Ferring for licensing rights of a product. Albireo's elobixibat is due to enter Ph3 for the CIC indication and Ph2b for the IBS-C indication shortly.
The company is looking to strengthen its position in the GI field.
On the Market
Ferring's gastroenterology portfolio includes PENTASA® for IBD and PICOPREP® for bowel cleansing.
In the pipeline
- Ferring has developed a 2-gram sachet of PENTASA® to facilitate intake for patients who require higher doses. A new device for the enema presentaton is under investigating changes.
- FE301 a new recombinant protein inhibitor of the IL-6 pathway for inflammatory conditions such as IBD (and rheumatoid arthritis).
Indications: Ferring has rights to develop and commercialise elobixibat for chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC) and irritable bowel syndrome with constipation (IBS-C).
Territories: The agreement gives Ferring rights to market the product WW with the exception of Japan and a small number of Asian markets.
Financial: Ferring will pay Albireo a significant upfront licensing fee, milestones and tiered double-digit royalties.
Development costs: Ferring will also be responsible for development costs in its territory.
Acts locally in the gut with minimal systemic exposure and modulates the enterohepatic circulation of bile acids by a partial inhibition of the Ileal Bile Acid Transporter (IBAT).
Focus: GI indications
Independent Swedish Biotech company based in Gothenburg
Spun-out of AstraZeneca in February 2008.
Financed by Phase4 Ventures and supported by TVM Capital and Scottish Widows Investment Partnership.
Source: Ferring; Albireo

item.title: BMS To Acquire Amylin For $7bn & Then Integrate Products Into AZ Collaboration
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: BMS has today announced the acquisition of Amylin. Following the completion of the purchase, the company will then enter into a collaboration with AstraZeneca , based on their existing diabetes alliance, regarding the development and commercialisation of Amylin's portfolio of products.

Comments
Bristol-Myers Squibb announced on 9 August 2012 that it has completed its $5-billion purchase of Amylin and its diabetes franchise.
AstraZeneca has also informed Bristol-Myers Squibb of its intention to exercise its option to acquire certain additional governance rights over key strategic and financial decisions regarding Amylin’s portfolio. The right to exercise this option will become effective once applicable anti-trust and competition approvals are received by AstraZeneca. Upon the exercise of the option an additional payment of $135 million will be made to Bristol-Myers Squibb.
Source: Pharmiweb 9 August 2012

item.title: re: Astellas Boosts its Foothold in Urology
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Astellas Boosts its Foothold in Urology 
Comment: The FDA has approved Astellas' mirabegron (once-daily pill) for OAB. The drug launch is set for Oct-Dec, and will be sold as Myrbetriq. The company expects the drug to drive synergy with Vesicare (which has top brand market share at 23%).  ...
According to FirstWord global sales of Myrbetriq are anticipated to reach approximately $600 million in 2016. The product is expected to be a key profit driver for Astellas, being both developed in-house and given the opportunity for it to be marketed in close conjunction with its other OAB treatment, Vesicare, and a number of other urology brands. US launch of the product is expected during the third quarter.
Analysts at JP Morgan had predicted a short delay prior to approval, due to concerns being raised about elevated heart rate at an FDA advisory panel meeting in April.
Approval of Myrbetriq is also notable given Astellas' relatively weak in house-R&D pipeline, said analysts at Morgan Stanley.
Source: FirstWord 29 June 2012

item.title: Biogen-Idec & Isis Form New Neuromuscular Disease Collaboration
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Biogen-Idec and Isis have entered into an exclusive worldwide option and collaboration agreement to develop and commercialise an antisense programme targeting the neuromusucular disease mytonic dystrophy.
How Does The Antisense Approach Work
DM1, the most common form of muscular dystrophy is caused by a genetic defect in the dystrophia myotonic-protein kinase DMPK gene in which a sequence of three nucleotides repeats ectensively creatin an abnormally long toxic RNA. This accumulates in cells and prevents the production of proteins needed for normal cellular function. Isis's DM1 antisense should block the production of this toxic RNA sequence thereby correcting the underlying disorder.
Deal Terms
Isis will receive an upfront payment of $12m and will be responsible for the identification of a lead antisense target. It is also eligible for up to $59m in milestone payments. Biogen-Idec has an option to in-license the product up to completion of phase 2 at which point Isis would receive another $200m in a license fee and regulatory milestones plus royalties on sales. If Biogen-Idex exercises its option it will take full responsibility for further development and commercialisation.
Source: biogenidec.com

Comments
The companies have signed a third global collaboration agreement under which they will discover and develop antisense drugs againt 3 undisclosed targets to treat neurological or neuromuscular disorders.
Terms of the Agreement
Under the terms of the agreement, Isis will receive an upfront payment of $30M and is responsible for the discovery of a lead antisense drug for each of the 3 undisclosed drugs.
Isis is eligible to receive substantial development milestone payments to support R&D of each program prior to the exercise by Biogen Idec of its option to license each program.
Biogen Idec has the option to license a drug from each of the three programs through the completion of Phase 2 trials. Isis could receive up to another $200 million in a license fee and regulatory milestone payments per program. In addition, Isis will receive double-digit royalties on sales of drugs. Isis will be responsible for development of the drugs through the completion of the initial Phase 2 clinical trial, with Biogen Idec providing advice and assistance on research and the clinical trial design and conduct and regulatory strategy for each program. If Biogen Idec exercises its option, it will assume global development, regulatory and commercialization responsibilities.

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: The AMBER study has been designed to assess the efficacy, safety, PK and PD of PGL2001 with concomitant, continuous norethisterone acetate for the treatment of pain symptoms suggestive of endometriosis. Primary outcome will measure non-menstrual pelvic pain.
Study Design - NCT01631981
Recuitment: approx. 132 participants
Start date: June 2012 - Completion dates: Oct 2013 / May 2014
Locations: Hungary (5 sites); Poland (10 sites); Romania (5 sites)

item.title: New Trial of Daewoong's Botulinum Toxin for Glabellar Line
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Just listed in clinicaltrials.gov, the Ph3 study which started in March is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Daewoong's DWP450 compared with Botox in patients with moderate to severe glabellar line. Whilst highlighted in a recent report dated June 28 by Tongyang Securities as a "2013 catalyst" for the company, there has been no previous published reference to this toxin that may allow its identification.
Reference is made to the toxin being a generic equivalent of clostridium botulinum toxin A
- Primary Outcome Measures: At 4 wks, glabellar line improvement rate at max. frown confirmed with investigator's live severity assessment.
- Secondary Outcome Measure: At 8,12 & 16 weeks glabellar line improvement rate at max. frown confirmed with investigators's live severity assessment
- Recruitment: approx. 268 participants
- Started in March 2012 - Completion date : Dec. 2012
Location: Rep of Korea (Chung-Ang U. Hospital)

Comments
At CPhI (Oct. 9th / Madrid), we have learnt that the toxin was produced by Daewoong (in Korea). DW BTX-A is expected to be registered by the Korean FDA in 2013 for GL.
Next Indications : Blepharospasm, sweating, CD, upper motor neuron syndrome and chronic migraine are part of the development program of the drug in a near future.
When questionned if the toxin may come from a patnership/technology transfer agreement with Medy-Tox, a representative of Daewoong denied, and accentuated that DW BTX-A is a proprietary product from its company.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Intelligence From MDS Part 1 - Botulinum Toxin Company Activity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Intelligence From MDS Part 1 - Botulinum Toxin Company Activity 
  ...
Very helpful. Nice job team. We need to tackle the Marchetti paper Allergan keeps using. Allergans position is paradoxical as we heard at their symposium in Dublin.
On one hand, they agree that there is no conversion ratio, on the other hand, they consistently show the Marchetti paper results in a way that implies that this is high quality clinical research (even though it is a retrospective review and that the dose conversion ratio is on average 4-5:1 or higher which is both dangerous for our patients and destroys our value proposition. I was glad to see the Korean study demonstrating 2.5:1 ratio with encouraging results in this meeting.
Overall at the MDS I felt the star of Ipsen and Dysport was shining. We had a full attendance to our symposia, best booth location and several posters from US affiliate with Anchor-CD study.

item.title: Astellas Boosts its Foothold in Urology
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The FDA has approved Astellas' mirabegron (once-daily pill) for OAB. The drug launch is set for Oct-Dec, and will be sold as Myrbetriq. The company expects the drug to drive synergy with Vesicare (which has top brand market share at 23%).
In Japan: launched on Sept. 2011 as Betanis
In EU: MAA filed on Aug. 2011
Ph2 studies on combined use with Vesicare are ongoing (completion estimated this month)
Enzalutamide/MDV3100 (prostate cancer) : US filing on May 21 - EU filing on June 26
Tivozanib (RCC): EU/US filing expected in Q3:12

Comments
According to FirstWord global sales of Myrbetriq are anticipated to reach approximately $600 million in 2016. The product is expected to be a key profit driver for Astellas, being both developed in-house and given the opportunity for it to be marketed in close conjunction with its other OAB treatment, Vesicare, and a number of other urology brands. US launch of the product is expected during the third quarter.
Analysts at JP Morgan had predicted a short delay prior to approval, due to concerns being raised about elevated heart rate at an FDA advisory panel meeting in April.
Approval of Myrbetriq is also notable given Astellas' relatively weak in house-R&D pipeline, said analysts at Morgan Stanley.
Source: FirstWord 29 June 2012

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: Astellas' Gonax 80mg/120mg (degarelix, sub; inj.) was granted Japanese marketing approval for prostate cancer.
End of 2010, Astellas submitted an application based on the results of Ph1 and Ph2 studies in Japan and abroad Ph3 data (skipping the Ph3 study in Japan).
Astellas holds exclusive rights to dev. and market degarelix for the treatment of prostate cancer in Japan.

item.title: Civitas Therapeutics Initiates PhII Study For Parkinson Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Civitas has announced the initiation of a phase 2 a clinical trial evaluating its pulmonary inhaled formulation of L-Dopa CVT-301 as an adjunctive treatment to oral L-Dopa. Funding for the study is being provided by the Michael J Fox Foundation.
Study Design

The Phase 2a study is a randomized, placebo-controlled, single dose, cross-over design that will characterize the safety and tolerability of CVT-301 and evaluate pharmacodynamic effects and L-dopa pharmacokinetics in patients with Parkinson’s disease with motor fluctuations

It is designed to establish the dose for future clinical trials with CVT-301. Patients will receive oral Sinemet®, inhaled placebo and CVT-301 which will be followed by serial evaluations of Ldopa pharmacokinetics, motor response and safety at each visit. Twenty-four patients will be enrolled.

What Is Different About CVT-301

it is an inhaled formulation of L-dopa designed to produce immediate relief from debilitating motor fluctuations associated with Parkinson’s disease. For symptomatic relief, patients receive oral L-dopa to maintain dopamine levels in the brain above the therapeutic threshold. However, the efficacy of oral L-dopa is significantly compromised by delayed absorption and excessive variability in the circulating plasma drug concentrations inherent to the oral delivery route.

CVT-301 has been developed utilising Civitas proprietary ARCUS Technology which is capable of

Place In Treatment Paradigm

As tomorrow's Traction review of PD therapeutics will demonstrate, there are many treatments trying to compete in the advanced disease PD space to improve control of motor fluctuations both oral treatments and more complex therapies such as DBS and LCIG. Interestingly, the latter may start to move forward into an earlier treatment paradigm. However, the beauty of the Civitas approach may be the simplicity with which it can be administered and the realiability of the response, something that not all oral therapies are capable of delivering.

Source:www.civitastherapeutics.com


Comments
Civitas has initiated a Ph2b for CVT-301 in the USA and EU to test the efficacy, safety and tolerability of the drug in the treatment of intermittent OFF episodes.
Recruitment: approx 80 patients
Preliminary data: H1 14
Drug Characteristics: ease of use; simple ARCUS(R) inhaler; allows whenever and whereever use.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Sales of Microrelin Temporiraly Suspended in Iran
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to our partner in Iran and Matthieu Raimbault (Director, Turkey & Iran Alliances) we have learnt that the Head of Drug Supervision and Evaluation of MOH has recently requested the recall of Microrelin 3.75mg from the market for "quality problems". Whilst the exact reasons have not been very well known yet, it is assumed that one possible might be the blocking of the needle during the injection. An update will be provided as soon as we capture more information.
One box of Microrelin contains the same syringe (for reconstitution AND injection).
The recall affecting the batch N°BPD111, from which all the sales since December 2011 have come from, temporarily prevents Pooyesh Darou from selling Microrelin 3.75mg.

item.title: re: NICE Reverses Opinion And Agrees To Fund Zytiga Under the NHS
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
NICE Reverses Opinion And Agrees To Fund Zytiga Under the NHS 
Comment: After further consultation between NICE and J&J during which J&J has agreed a revised patient access scheme with the Department of Health which makes abiraterone (Zytiga) available at a discount price, NICE has agreed to recommend the use of the drug for the treatment of post-docetaxel CRPC.  ...
On June 28th, NICE issued its final guidance recommending abiraterone (Zytiga, Janssen) in combination with prednisone for mCRPC post docetaxel.
Information provided by Janssen enabled the committee to recommend the drug for use on the NHS.

item.title: M Zügel to Leave Merz Next Month
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: M Zügel will be replaced by Philip Buchard. The transition will start on July 1, 2012.
- Began his professional career in the U.S. at Hoechst.
- After several assignments in Germany and abroad, he became Managing Director for Germany in 2002 at AstraZeneca, where he held various international positions over the past ten years.
He was responsible for marketing & sales WW, and his most recent position was Vice President Western EU.

item.title: re: Esmya(R) Granted EMA for Uterine Fibroids
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Esmya(R) Granted EMA for Uterine Fibroids 
Comment: The EC has granted marketing authorization to Richter/PregLem's Esmya(R) 5mg tablet for pre-operative treatment of moderate to severe symptoms of uterine fibroids.  ...
Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph3 trial which is to evaluate the sustained efficacy and safety of long term on-off treatment with Esmya (5 or 10mg doses) on uterine bleeding, myoma size, pain and quality of life.
Start date: June 2012 - Completion date: April 2015/June 2015
Recruitment: Approx. 600 pre-menopausal women with symptomatic uterine myoma(s) characterised by heavy bleeding
Locations: 13 EU countries
Source: NCT01629563

item.title: Third Ph2 Has Started with Kissei's GnRH Antagonist for Endometriosis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Efficacy and safety will be evaluated in approx. 20 Japanese participants. Primary oucome measures will assess the severity score of the pelvic pain.
Source: NCT01629420
The 1st Ph2 was initiated in July 2011, and the 2nde in February 2012.
(Please see Oncology8104: Kissei Has Initiated a Second Ph2 Study with its In-House GnRH antagonist for Endometriosis).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novartis to Start Head-to-Head Study Comparing BEZ2235 to Everolimus in mTORi Naive pNET
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph2 study, designed to evaluate the dual inhibition of mTOR and PI3K, was discussed during ENETS and is now listed in clinicaltrials.gov. Primary outcome measures will assess PFS.
Recruitment: approx. 140
Start date: Sept. 2012 - Completion date: April 2015
Locations: USA (8 states; 10 sites)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Roche to Cut Jobs and Close Site in the U.S to Free Up Resources
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The closure of Roche's Pharma Research and Early Development Unit in Nutley (NJ) will result in the loss of approx. 1000 positions. The R&D activities of the site will be consolidated in Basel (Switzerland), and Penzberg (Germany).
The closure of the Nutley site is part of a planned site consolidation and the streamlining of research activities.
According to the company, research activities will focus on oncology, virology, metabolism and neurology.
In 2013, a new Pharmaceuticals Translational Clinical Research Center is slated to open on the US East coast.
It is dedicated to support US-based clinial trials, early dev. programs and employ approx. 240 people.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Pfizer's New Long-acting rHGH
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pfizer has developed a new sustained-release formulation of growth hormone working with a resesarch group in China.
Detailed information on the formulation and a rat study undertaken to evaluate its PK, PD and safety profile are reported in the June 2nd issue of Journal of Molecular Pharmaceutics.
Its publication highlights a new rhGH-PEA microsphere system that has the potential to be clinically effective when administered once every two months. In rat studies the new formulation extended the release of rhGH for up to 56 days and showed better phamacological efficacy than daily administration after 6 days.
The PELA microspheres are apparently formulated using a combination of traditional and membrane emulsification methods.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Bid Speculation Circles Diabetes Company Amylin
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Bid Speculation Circles Diabetes Company Amylin 
Comment: Shares in Amylin have leapt by over 8% as a report on Bloomberg claimed that both Sanofi and Merck have made initial takeover bids for the diabetes drug specialist that markets and manufactures the GLP-1 analogues Byetta and Bydureon.  ...
As the auction for Amylin enters the last leg 5 companies are reported to be still interested in acquiring the company for a pirce tag of around $4.5bn. Interested parties reportedly include Novartis, Sanofi, BMS, Merck and AstraZeneca. Final bids are expected by the weekend.
Source: Rueters

item.title: MAA Submitted for Enzalutamide (ex MDV-3100) in Post-Chemo Setting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Astellas and Medivation have announced that they have submitted a MAA to the EMA for the treatment of men with mCRPC who have been previously treated with docetaxel.
The submissions (EU and US) are based on data from the late-stage AFFIRM trial, which was halted early.
Common side effects observed more frequently in enzalutamide as compared with placebo-treated patients included fatigue, diarrhea and hot flush.
In the AFFIRM trial, seizure was reported in less than 1% of enzalutamide-treated patients. Serious adverse events, adverse events causing patients to stop treatment, and adverse events causing death all were lower in the enzalutamide group than in the placebo group.
Astellas and Medivation will co-market the drug in the US, with Astellas having responsibility for commercialising the drug in all other markets.

item.title: re: Detailed Information On New Sandostatin LAR Device
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Detailed Information On New Sandostatin LAR Device 
Comment: Thanks to Claudia Limberger (Endocrinology Marketing Manager Germany), we have more details about Novartis's new Sandostatin LAR device. A copy of the visual aid is attached.  ...
Thanks to Susan Scott (Publications Director) at ENDO we have learnt that Novartis does not intend to launch new LAR device in USA for a couple of years at least, due to changing requirements to US regulations and study requirements.
The local US sales team stated " We are very happy with our current syringe and expect Pasreotide to be the next big thing" - " why would we launch a new device in USA when we have no competition in our biggest market NET."

item.title: Intelligence From MDS Part 1 - Botulinum Toxin Company Activity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
In terms of the XCiDaBLE data some of the baseline findings both in CD and Blepharospasm are shown below.
Finally one non-industry sponsored poster of interest worth highlighting is a small study that has evaluated the response to Xeomin in patients who were secondary non-responders to other toxins due to neutralising antibodies. It found no benefit with Xeomin treatment.

Comments
re: Intelligence From MDS Part 1 - Boutlinum Toxin Company Activity
Wonderful detailed information that will prove extremely useful in our promotion and defence of Dysport. Thank you
Very helpful. Nice job team. We need to tackle the Marchetti paper Allergan keeps using. Allergans position is paradoxical as we heard at their symposium in Dublin.
On one hand, they agree that there is no conversion ratio, on the other hand, they consistently show the Marchetti paper results in a way that implies that this is high quality clinical research (even though it is a retrospective review and that the dose conversion ratio is on average 4-5:1 or higher which is both dangerous for our patients and destroys our value proposition. I was glad to see the Korean study demonstrating 2.5:1 ratio with encouraging results in this meeting.
Overall at the MDS I felt the star of Ipsen and Dysport was shining. We had a full attendance to our symposia, best booth location and several posters from US affiliate with Anchor-CD study.

item.title: Positive Results from Ph1 of Versartis' Once-Monthly GH Presented @ ENDO 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During the oral discussion of the Ph1 results, G. Bright, VP of Medical Affairs, stated that a single dose of VRS-317 was "very well tolerated" in GHD adult patients.
AEs considered drug-related were primarily mild and transient.
No injection site lipoatrophy observed during the treatment.
More details @ http://www.versartis.com/content/newsandevents/releases/062512.htm
  • Design: 60-day double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled,single-ascending dose
  • Recruitment: 50 GHD adult patients
  • Locations: the US and EU
  • Primary outcome measures were to assess the safety and tolerability of a single sub (sc) dose of VRS-317
PC safety and efficacy data were recently published in The Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences (7 JUN 2012 | DOI: 10.1002/jps.23229).
Source: Versartis

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Quintiles Offers Jobs to Merck Serono's Employees Affected by the Restructuring
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Quintiles has committed to offer approx. 100 positions to Merck Serono's employees primarily working in the Global Development & Medical Function in Geneva.
Early July, Quintiles is to hold an information session for the employees and will conduct job interviews.
Primarily in clinical ops, biostatistics, clinical research, and drug safety.
To benefit from Merck Serono's talents and expertise.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Lexicon's Diabetes Drug Poised to Enter Ph3 in H1:13
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has announced positive results of LX-4211 Ph2b study for type 2 diabetes. The drug has shown favorable safety profile, and was well tolerated.
LX-4211 showed statistically-significant reductions in hemoglobin a1c in a Ph2 b trial.
Side effects were mild to moderate, similar to placebo (4 adverse events were reported during the trial, and were not treatment related).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New CRPC Treatments Are Likley To Prompt A Change In The Dynamic Equilbrium Between Urologists & Oncologists
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The latest edition of the British Journal of Urology highlights how the relationship between urologists and oncologists is likely to change as a result of evolving new treatment paradigms for the treatment of CRPC.
The paper suggests a redefinition of the respective roles of oncologists and urologists will occur and that a multidisciplinary team or co-ordinated care approach will become a necessity.
For copies of the article please contact Helen Rendell (Scientific Information Services)
BJU Int. 2012 Jun 19. doi: 10.1111/j.1464-410X.2011.10818.x. [Epub ahead of print)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: CHMP Adopted A Positive Opinion On Label Expansion For Novartis's Afinitor
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On Friday the European CHMP recommended approval of Afinitor (everolimus) for the treatment of certain patients with breast cancer. Specifically, for use in combination with Pfizer's exemestane (Aromasin) for the treatment of hormone receptor positive HER2/neu- negative postmenopausal advanced breast cancer.
It recommended use in women without symptomatic visceral disease after recurrence or progression following a non-steroidal aromatase inhibitor.
The CHMP's decision was taken based on data from the late-stage BOLERO-2 trial which Novartis reported last year. Novartis filed for approval of this indication in Q42011.
The BOLERO-2 study demonstrated that Afinitor plus Aromasin more than doubled median PFS to 7.8 months compared to 3.2 months iwth Aromasin alone.
Novartis noted that with this approval Afinitor will represnet the first major innovation in HR+/HER2 negative disease disnce the aromatase inhibitors were first introduced more than 15 years ago.
For Afinitor this will represent the third major approval for its usage with the drug already recommended for the treatment of renal cell cancer and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours.
source: www.novartis.com

Comments
re: CHMP Adopted A Postiive Opinion On Label Expansion For Novartis's Afinitor
On July 20th, the FDA expanded approval of Afinitor (everolimus) for postmenopausal women with advanced hormonr receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer. Novartis noted that the approval marks the &st time the US agency has approved mTOR inhibitor for this indication.
The approval calls for the drug to be used in combination with Aromasin (exemestane), after failure with Femara (letrozole) or Arimidex (anastrozole).
According to Evaluate Pharma this is an earlier than expected move from the FDA. Analysts think that the approval will deliver more than $1bn in additional sales by 2018, taking Afinitor firmly into blockbuster territory. This promise in breast cancer has not only helped Afinitor to be the number one growth driver for Novartis, it also goes some way to helping to offset the revenue gap that will be left when Diovan loses patent protection in September 2012. While approval in breast cancer is the biggest win for Novartis, there are studies in a number of other indications that could see sales forecasts grow further.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: ReNeuron's Stroke Drug Produces Early Evidence Of Functional Improvement
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:ReNeuron has reported further positive results from its dose-escalation PISCES trial in severe stroke patients with its neural stem cell therapy ReN001, including improvements in spasticity as measured by the Ashworth Scale

What is ReN001?

It is a cell therapy consisting of neural stem cells derived from ReNeuron’s c-mycER technology

What is PISCES?

PISCES is

from 5 patients with moderate to severe functional neurological impairments resulting from stroke in the open-label, dose-escalation, U.K. Phase I PISCES trial showed that single doses of intracranial ReN001 led to no cell-related adverse events or adverse immune-related responses at 3 (n=2), 6 (n=1) or 12 months (n=2) posttreatment.

There were minor procedure-related adverse events, including asymptomatic bleeds and superficial scalp infections at the implantation site.

Additionally, ReN001 improved neurological deficits, as measured by a reduction in National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) scores, with a median score of 4 points at 3 months posttreatment vs. 8 points at baseline. Furthermore, ReN001 improved spasticity, as measured by a reduction in Summated Ashworth Scale for affected upper and lower limbs scores, with a mean score of 21.8 points at 3 months post-treatment vs. 28.6 points at baseline.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Norgine Conducts Evaluation Study in Italy to Determine Patient's Acceptability of Bowel Cleansing Procedure
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In this Italian 'real life' study, approx. 600 patients will be recruited to measure the patients acceptability of the procedure. The second measures will assess the time to reach the caecum, and the adenoma detection rate.
Start date: Feb. 2012 - Completion date: June 2012
Recruitment: Male and female outpatients, aged ≥ 18, treated with bowel cleansing preparation the day before undergoing routine colonoscopy at selected participating centres
Location: IRCCS
Principal Investigator: Alessandro Repici, MD

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: AAA Reports Strong Growth In 2011 & Appointment Of New Chairman
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
I am delighted to have Claudio serve as Chairman as AAA increases its development efforts and international expansion. It is the next logical step for the company and will enable me to focus on the business at this important time of growth. Claudio's investment and business expertise will be a huge asset to us as we leverage the many opportunities within the Molecular Nucleur Medicine Market and drive the company towards its next stage of evolution. 
The 60 mg comparator dose of LAR is surprising as it is off label. Quite a few patients are treated with high off-label doses, but it doesn't seem to be appropriate for a potential registration trial. It would be really interesting to get some further information on the thinking behind this and the regulatory views.

item.title: Regional Debt to Pharma Companies in Spain Hits USD1.8 Bil. in June
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A repayment plan has been set by the Spanish central government for domestic and international pharmaceutical companies that are being affected by the wave of payment delays, but it has not yet become effective, and Spanish regions owe pharmaceutical companies a total of EUR 1.5 billion (USD1.8 billion) as of June.
- According to Reuters, the debt increased throughout the first months of 2011 with the figure standing at EUR6.3 billion by the end of the year.
- According to the source, the government repayment plan envisaged repayment beginning at the end of 2011, but this has not come into force.
- According to Spanish pharmaceutical association Farmaindustria's president Humberto Arnes, cited by the source, the 2012 debt is growing at a faster rate than in 2011. According to Arnes, the debt rate in 2012 has increased by 10 days of delayed payments per month.

Despite the government's repayment plan which was promised to domestic and international pharmacies operating in the country, the short-to-medium-term outlook on the situation will see most pharma companies cutting their medicinal supplies or setting credit limits to avoid further payment delays.
In the case of Swiss firm Roche, the company decided in May to set a payment credit limit for 12 Spanish hospitals in order to avoid further delays. Despite the recent reforms announced by the Spanish government to tackle healthcare debt and reduce the debt in order to be able to review the situation and keep up to date with payments, Spain needs to engage in a stricter repayment plan with the regional councils in order to be able to cope. Although a new financial mechanism to avoid systemic breakdown has recently been announced, this is still too recent to be able to assess its effects in the short-to-medium term.
Accruing EUR1.5 billion in debt to pharma companies may lead to further lack in pharmaceutical stock in pharmacies and hospitals across the country, especially with critical life-saving treatments, such as oncology or diabetes drugs. In order to avoid more financial strain on the overall national healthcare budget, the government recently proposed to withdraw the co-payment of over-the-counter drugs.
Source: GlobalInsight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Pioneering Antisense Approach May Offer Hope For Huntington's Disease Patients
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Scientists at the University of California have reported in the journal Neuron a potentially effective therapeutic strategy to combat Huntington's disease involving a DNA-based antisense drug.
A single injection of the drug slowed and partially reversed progression of the disease in mice and monkeys affected with the disease. Treated animals began moving better within a month and were physically back to normal within 2 months.The benefits, it is claimed persisted for nine months after treatment long after levels of the Huntingtin protein began to build again.
The lead researcher Professor Don Cleveland is quoted in the UK press as saying "Our approach is feasible for development now into a therapy for Huntington's disease in man"
Source: Neron , Vol 74 Issue 6 964-966 21 June 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: OXiGENE In-Licenses Angiogene Pharm's IP to Support Carcinoid Syndrome Studies
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: OXiGENE management reported that the in-licensing of IP and other assets from Angiogene is strategically important as it provides potential to significantly expand the commercial opportunity and patent protection for ZYBRESTAT, its lead vascular disrupting agent. OXiGENE believes the drug may provide clinical benefit in reducing circulating levels of serotonin or 5-HIAA, either by itself or in conjunction with drugs like Sandostatin(R).
OXiGENE believes that these in-licensed assets will provide a compelling therapeutic rationale to conduct a Ph2 clinical study in persistent carcinoid syndrome, potentially to be followed by advancing to a registration clinical program.
- Virtual" company with staff in both Europe and North America.
- Privately-held company owned entirely by its Directors.
- Technology http://www.angiogene.co.uk/technologies.html
Source: OXiGENE; Angiogene Pharm.
