item.title: Novo Stops Once-Weekly Liraglutide to Focus on Once-Weekly Semaglutide
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The strategic decision to pursue the once-weekly GLP-1 either with semaglutide or liraglutide depot was announced last year during the company 'Market Capital Day'. Semaglutide is slated to enter Ph3 for type 2 diabetes in H1:13.
Novo reported semaglutide has a better safety profile for once-weekly dosing compared to the once-weekly liraglutide formulation (which was in Ph1).
Novo plans to initiate the 1st Ph3 in the SUSTAIN™ programme.
The global clinical development programme is expected to include > 8,000 patients.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: EMA Reports on Roche Pharmacovigilance Deficiencies
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: An inspection by the MHRA found that Roche did not assess approx. 80,000 safety reports collected for its drugs, and did not report them to health authorities. EMA is requiring the company to submit a revised comprehensive action plan by June 27.
The company agreed that it did not fully comply with pharmacovigilance regulations, and reported it is working with health authorities to correct the issue.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: AAA Reports Strong Growth In 2011 & Appointment Of New Chairman
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Nucleur Medicine Company AAA reported strong growth in the year to
Sales for the year increased by 21.8% to Euro 33.4m, whilst the group spent Euro 13m on R&D. Net cash currently stands at Euro 29.8m.
2011 was a year of significant investment in manufacturing with the opening to two new sites in Spain and Italy. In April the group raised Euro 40m from existing and new investors to strengthen the company's growth potential.
Yesterday the group appointed Claudio Costamagna as Chairman of the board. He has been on the board since January 2010 and was previously Chairman of Goldman Sachs Investment Banking Division for Europe, Middle Ease and Africa.
Commenting on the appointment Stefano Buono Founder and CEO of AAA, commented
I am delighted to have Claudio serve as Chairman as AAA increases its development efforts and international expansion. It is the next logical step for the company and will enable me to focus on the business at this important time of growth. Claudio's investment and business expertise will be a huge asset to us as we leverage the many opportunities within the Molecular Nucleur Medicine Market and drive the company towards its next stage of evolution.
The 60 mg comparator dose of LAR is surprising as it is off label. Quite a few patients are treated with high off-label doses, but it doesn't seem to be appropriate for a potential registration trial. It would be really interesting to get some further information on the thinking behind this and the regulatory views.
Next Steps With Carcinoid Trial
AAA is poised to start recruitment its phIII trial which will compare PFS after treatment with 177Lu-DOTA0-Tyr3-Octreotate plus best supportive care (30 mg Octreotide LAR) to treatment with high dose (60 mg) Octreotide LAR in patients with inoperable, progressive (as determined by RECIST Criteria), somatostatin receptor positive, well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumours of the small bowel (midgut carcinoid tumours).
41 sites across Europe and the US are listed as participants in the trial which is being co-ordinated by the CRO Pierrel Research Europe GmbH. The study which will enroll 200 patients is scheduled to complete in terms of primary endpoint (PFS) by Dec 2014.
ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT01578239
http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01578239?term=Lu-dota&rank=1
Source: www.adacap.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: The Industry Combines Forces To Enhance Neuroscience R&D
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Announced today at the 2012 BIO International Convention, seven companies have joined forces to create the Masachusetts Neuroscience Consortium, an institution designed to fund preclinical neuroscience programmes at Masachusetts academic and research institutions.
The companies involved are Abbott, Biogen-Idec, EMD Serono, Janssen, Merck, Pfizer and Sunovion. Each has pledged $250,000 to create an initial fund of $1.75m.
The outcome of any research undertaken will be shared with all participants.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Main Takeaways from Forest's Analyst Day
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Already well established in the U.S and Canada, the company is poised to expand significantly in Europe and has expressed a particular interest in Brazil/Latin America. Management expects approval of linaclotide (for IBS-c) in September this year. The launch of Namenda XR (early 2013) is perceived as the preservation of the Namenda franchise post genericization.

item.title: Medy-Tox and Pacific Pharma Have Signed Joint Marketing Agreement
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The purpose of the agreement is to jointly sell Meditoxin (for cosmetic use) in the Korean market. Medy-Tox expects a boost from Q3:12 as a result.
To date, Meditoxin (cosmetic) has been exclusively sold by Pacific Pharma.
The company expects sales to reach W1.8bn, while SG&A to rise to W1.3bn on the recruitment of a new sale force.

item.title: re: Raptor Files For Approval of RP103
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: FDA has accepted for review an NDA from Raptor Pharmaceuticals for RP103 to treat nephropathic cystinosis. The company had requested Priority Review, but FDA assigned the product a standard review. Interestingly the same drug is also being developed by Raptor in a phII trial for Huntington's disease. 
Alongside the announcement of the acquisition of exclusve rights to IP related to cysteamine and related compounds in the potential treatment of PD from Universite Laval, Dr Patrice Rioux, Raptor's CMO, outlined that the company is currently conducting a Ph2/3 trial with RP103 in France for the treatment of HD.

item.title: Swedish Agency Refuses to Grant Reimbursement to Zytiga
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The TLV considers that the price of Zytiga is far too high when compared to the benefits it brings to patients. Thanks to Tommy Söderman (General Manager Ipsen AB) we have more details about the price. Janssen-Cilag have asked for a price of 30 000 SEK/month (approx. 3400€). The cost per QALY was calculated to 1,135M SEK (approx. 125K€). The agency normally accept if this cost is around 600K SEK.
Significance
The TLV acknowledged the slight overall survival benefit shown in patients with metastatic prostate cancer with Zytiga, but denied reimbursement to the medicine despite the need for novel prostate cancer treatments.
Overall, Janssen has been successful in securing positive reimbursement status for Zytiga in Europe. Even the UK's NICE approved its funding under the National Health Service (See Oncology8279: NICE Reverses Opinion And Agrees To Fund Zytiga Under the NHS).
Additional Source: GlobalInsight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New Trial with Bayer's Alpharadin for CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph3 multi-center early access program for the use of Alpharadin in CRPC patients diagnosed with bone metastasis. The fact that most of the selected sites are located in EU may lead us to believe that one of the purpose of this trial is for filing the drug in this zone. Primary outcomes measures will assess safety.
Recruitment: Approx. 2000
Start date: June 2012 - Completion dates: Feb. 2015
Location: 94 sites, mostly in EU
Protocol: One injection to be administered every 4 weeks

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Final Measures of Merck Serono's Efficiency Plan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Merck Serono has confirmed it will close the Geneva sites (mid-2013) and the Coinsins site (2014). The company has reported it will support potential start-ups by its employees through > to €30M financing fund. Additional measures are provided below.
Merck Serono will consolidate all headquarter functions on a Merck Serono campus in Darmstadt, Germany.
Focused in 3 hubs located in Europe (Darmstadt), the USA (Boston) and Asia (Beijing).
Out of the 1,250 positions currently located in Geneva, approximately 750 will be transferred to other sites (including 130 to the Canton of Vaud) and around 500 will be reduced to eliminate duplications and create a leaner, more agile organization. Approximately 80 positions will be made redundant in the sites located in the Canton of Vaud (Aubonne, Coinsins and Corsier-sur-Vevey).
Currently based in Coinsins, they will be relocated to Aubonne.
The biotech production sites located in Aubonne and Corsier-sur-Vevey will continue to manufacture leading medicines for the entire world.
Merck Serono’s new unit dedicated to biosimilars, a novel activity crucial for the future, will also be based in the Canton of Vaud.
The commercial operations based in Zug will continue to serve physicians and patients in Switzerland.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Second Deal Validates Protagonist's Peptide Technology Platform
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Zealand Pharma has entered into collaboration with Protagonist Therapeutics, which develops a validated and proprietary technology platform for the discovery and optimization of novel disulfide-rich peptides (DRPs). Those peptides are characterized by inherent stabilizing properties, which lead to improved PK profiles.
Zealand has identified the disease targets for the peptide drug discovery activities covered by the collaboration, and will be responsible for PC and clinical drug development of DRPs, discovered under the collaboration.
Zealand will fund the deal.
Protagonist will receive an upfront payment, and is eligible for milestones.
- Private
- Corporate HQ: Menlo Park, CA (USA)
- About the Platform: http://www.protagonist-inc.com/tech_main.html
- Business Dev: At the beginning of 2011, the company entered into a collaboration to discover novel peptides for potential development by Ironwood (http://www.protagonist-inc.com/news/2011/pr_011811.html)
- Investors: Lilly Ventures; qbf; Starfish Ventures; IMBcom

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Debiopharm to Develop Ascepion's Multikinase Inhibitor
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The drug (ASP-08126, called Debio 1144), in PC development, is expected to be effective in the treatment of various solid tumours as a mono agent or in combination with other anti-cancer therapies.
The drug is designed to inhibit specific signal pathway targets (tyrosine kinases), and has combined functions of bocking blood supply in solid tumours, and inhibiting tumour growth and stopping tumour spreading and metastasis.
Exclusive WW agreement.
Based in Suzhou, China.
Focus to the discovery and development of breakthrough small molecule drugs.
Pipeline http://www.ascepion.com/EN/zaiyanchanpin.html
Platform http://www.ascepion.com/EN/keyanziyuan.html
Sources: Debiopharm; Ascepion

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Denmark Accelerates Drug Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On June 19th, 'Invest in Denmark' will be organizing a roundtable @ BIO 2012 Conference to outline the Danish success of using translational medicine to bring new drugs faster to market.
The roundtable will be lead by Liselotte Hojgaard and moderated by Steven Burrill.
The focus will be on proven models of collaboration and infrastrcuture to improve R&D.
- Improve R&D: The country is among the top ones in the world producing biomedical research per capita.
- Opportunities for R&D: a National Biobank was just launched with > 15 million biologic samples/specimens
- Accelerate R&D: the country has the world's oldest cancer registry.
  • Agilent (which just acquired Dako)
  • Abbott (which bought a compound from Action Pharma)
  • Pfizer Consumer HC (which acquired Ferrosan)
Please see more @ http://www.investindk.com/News-and-events/Events/2012/BIO-International-Convention

item.title: Biotest to Officially Exit Greece
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The German company has reported that it would halt shipments to Greece next month, becoming the first drugmaker to announce it would leave the country because unpaid bills. As a medium-sized pharmaceutical company, Biotest is exactly the type of firm which may feel that it is unable to withstand the financial pressures which it is under in Greece, not able—unlike larger companies—to absorb the losses sufficiently.
According to management, in Italy customers are not taking any longer to pay their bills than they used to. In Spain, where the company's exposure is limited, Biotest does not participate in public hospital tenders because it could take 2 years to receive any payment.
Biotest, as a medium-sized pharmaceutical company with annual revenues of just over EUR400 million, may be a good example of the type of company which could see its position in Greece as untenable in the coming months, and, although in itself the withdrawal of the company is not majorly significant, its symbolic significance is much greater. This is because in all previous standoffs between the Greek authorities and pharmaceutical companies, such as Novo Nordisk and LEO Pharma (both Denmark) in 2010, and later ones involving Roche (Switzerland), Bayer (Germany) and others, there was never the suggestion that the company intended to withdraw all supplies from the market, and indeed, this possibility was studiously played down, considering the potential adverse publicity which could result from such a move.
However, once one company has made this move, it becomes easier for others—and it is more probable that this would be the medium-sized or smaller pharmaceutical companies, for whom a loss of several million euro in Greece is an important issue, rather than the pharma majors, which are more capable of absorbing such losses.
Meanwhile, the respite for Greeks seeking medicines in pharmacies will be limited in terms of its geographic scope, and if the Pharmaceutical Association of Attica opts to continue the protest, as predicted, then in Greece's most populous region, the protest will persist. Although there is a small glimmer of hope here, with promises of payments in order to get the pharmaceutical care system flowing again, the prospect of major protests by doctors puts any optimism on hold.
More broadly, the success of the pro-bailout New Democracy party in yesterday (June 17)'s parliamentary election means that at least there is some sense of stability restored to Greece, which may have a positive influence on the healthcare sector, especially if—as is widely predicted—there is a relative easing of the severity of the austerity measures the country is undergoing.
Sources: PRs; GlobalInsight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: J&J Intends to Extend the Use of Zytiga Earlier in the Course of Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has simultaneously submitted a type II variation to the EMA and a supplemental sNDA to the FDA. Both applications are intended to extend the use of the drug administered with prednisone for the treatment of patients with mCRPC who are asymptomatic or midly symptomatic after failure of ADT and before chemotherapy.
ZYTIGA in combination with prednisone was approved by the FDA in April 2011 and by the European Commission in September 2011 for the treatment of men with mCRPC who have received prior chemotherapy containing docetaxel.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Study: Fluorescent Cystoscopy Beats White Light in Bladder Cancer Surgery
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Forwarded by Anne Kornowski (Global Medical Director, Uro-Onco), this article outlines the findings of a controlled, prospective and randomized trial. Grossman and al reported "that fluorescent cytoscopy compared to standard white light cytoscopy detected more tumours, resulted in lower tumour recurrence rates and longer disease free intervals, and showed a trend toward increased bladder preservation".
551 patients were tracked for >9 months after surgery for bladder cancer; follow-up to a median of about 4.5 years in 516 patients.
Key Outcomes
  • Time to recurrence: longer in the fluorescence group (16.4 vs 9.4 months, p=0.04).
  • T2-T4 recurrences: fewer in the fluorescence group (3.1% vs 6.1%, p=0.066).
  • Tumour free:

H. Barton Grossman - "Long-Term Decrease in Bladder Cancer Recurrence with Hexaminolevulinate Enabled Fluorescence Cystoscopy" -

item.title: Lundbeck Restructuring EU Commercial Organization
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has cited increased pressure from healthcare reforms, generic competition and uncertainty regarding price and reimbursement in EU as the reasons of the restructuring, which will primarily affect sales reps who target GPs.
Lundbeck will reduce its EU commercial organization by approx. 600 (30%) to about 1,200.

item.title: Afinitor Approved for Full Reimbursement in Finland
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On June 6, Finland's Pharmaceuticals Pricing Board granted limited special reimbursement status to Novartis' Afinitor (everolimus). Afinitor will as of 1 September 2012 be reimbursed at 100% for advanced renal cell carcinoma, and for the treatment of advanced pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours when the cancer cells are well- or moderately differentiated and the cancer is getting worse.
The reimbursement verdict is good news for Novartis.
The drug is reimbursed at 42% since it entered the Basic Refund category in June 2010. Novartis has fixed the price of 30 doses of Afinitor in its 5mg formulation at EUR3,006.06 (USD3,766.86).
Last year, the health insurers spent a total of EUR1.3 million on Afinitor. The new reimbursement status of the drug should increase public expenditure by about EUR80,000 per year.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Raptor Files For Approval of RP103
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: FDA has accepted for review an NDA from Raptor Pharmaceuticals for RP103 to treat nephropathic cystinosis. The company had requested Priority Review, but FDA assigned the product a standard review. Interestingly the same drug is also being developed by Raptor in a phII trial for Huntington's disease.
Alongside the announcement of the acquisition of exclusve rights to IP related to cysteamine and related compounds in the potential treatment of PD from Universite Laval, Dr Patrice Rioux, Raptor's CMO, outlined that the company is currently conducting a Ph2/3 trial with RP103 in France for the treatment of HD.
What is RP103 & What Has Been Demonstrated So Far
RP103 is a delayed-release formulation of the degradation product of the amino acid cysteine. The existing formulation on the market has signficant compliance issues because it has to be taken every 6 hours through the night
Phase 3 trial
The PDUFA date is not disclosed but should be around January 2013. The product is also under review in the EU for the indication, with a decision expected in 1H13.
Development Status For Huntington's Disease
As a company Raptor is focused on improving the lives of patients with severe rare diseases.
Source:www.raptor.com

item.title: Study: Long-Term Outcome of Botox for Idiopathic and Neurogenic Detrusor Overactivity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: An article in BJU International note that at 3 years only one third of patients were still using Botox. The accompanying editorial notes the shortcomings of this retrospective study.

The authors of the study say that it has the merit of reporting a ‘real-life’ experience in a large teaching hospital in the UK National Health Service. The retrospective study is based largely on patient choice and results show that shows that most patients fail to persist with intravesical BT treatment, mainly due to tolerability issues.

Study Details

  • Over a period of 7 years, 268 patients were initiated on intravesical BT treatment for overactive bladder, with 137 followed up for ≥36 months, with 80 patients having ≥60 months follow-up after their first injection.
  • Almost two-thirds of patients (61.3%) had discontinued intravesical BT therapy at 36 months, with a 63.8% discontinuation rate at 60 months.
  • The main reasons for discontinuation were tolerability issues, mainly urinary tract infections and the need for clean intermittent self-catheterisation. Primary and secondary losses of efficacy were of secondary importance.

The study authors conclude that intravesical BY therapy is only effectve as a short-term treatment for OAB.

The authors acknowledge that shortcomings of the study: the use of an unlicensed treatment, the retrospective nature - with success being reported by patients rather than using a urological tool or questionnaire, all patients were in a single centre under the care of a single surgeon. Technical issues may have biased the results - lack of antibiotic prophylaxis and the use of relatively high doses in the early years.

The editorial notes thsese shortcomings and adds that if the 27% of patients who never had efficacy from their first treatment are removed from the calculations then the 'success rate' would be higher.

Source: BJU International published online: 6 JUN 2012


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Nymox Initiates Localised Prostate Cancer Study With NX-1207
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Nymox has enrolled the first patient in its phII study of NX-1207 for localised low risk prostate cancer. NX-1207 is currently in phIII development in the US and Europe for BPH and is licensed to Recordatti for development & commercialisation in Europe.
Preclinical studies with NX-1207 have shown activity against prostate cancer at higher dosage levels that are being studied for BPH.
The new study will test both high and low doses of NX-1207 and will have an efficacy readout at 6 weeks (see Oncology8140: New Prostate Cancer Indication for Nymox' NX-1207 Enters Ph2).
NX-1207 is administered directly into the prostate by a urologist in an office setting that does not require aneasthesia, sedation or catheterization. It takes only a few minutes to administer and in the BPH setting thus far has demonstrated none of the adverse sexual side-effects associated with some other medical therapies.
Source: nymox.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: ASCO Intelligence Update - Part V - HCC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Progress in HCC has been less dynamic although this not through lack of trying. There have been a number of high profile trial failures described in Andrews Zhu’s talk including AZ’s cediranib which has been terminated. The tivantinib study against this gloomy backdrop was considered a ray of sunshine, showing for the first time an OS advantage by inhibiting MET in HCC.
GSK’s foretinib showed promise in Phase II, and AG’s resminostat, generated some interest at the conference with the results of its Phase II Shelter study presented at ASCO as a poster. There was also some activity seen in the final clinical results of a single-arm phase II study of bevacizumab and everolimus which showed combination treatment of RAD001 and bevazicumab is tolerated acceptably. TTP and OS in the 1°/2°-line HCC patients on treatment is comparable to sorafenib monotherapy in the SHARP trial (1° line only).
In addition, a number of HCC studies were “scientifically advertising” themselves in poster format, abstracts reiterating their protocols and recruitment status. These can be found on clinicaltrials.gov.
A review of the Management of Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC): Standard Therapy and a Look to New Targets. Zhu’s discussed staging and general principles of the management of HCC, management of early and intermediate stage of HCC, sorafenib use in HCC and new targets and regimens under development.
Less than 30% of HCC patients are suitable for surgical resection with a medium survival of 30%. Currently there is no established adjuvant therapy with sorafenib currently being investigated in this context. Transplantation is considered to be a highly successful with overall survival and recurrence-free survival in the 80-90% range.
In addition to RFA and TACE novel local treatment modalities are evolving. DEB treatment with doxorubicin was specifically highlighted.
Many questions are still needing to be answered regarding TACE and other treatments for unresectable disease including, patient selection, optimal chemotherapy agents and how to incorporate sorafenib. A Phase III trial combining sorafenib with TACE unfortunately failed to meet its primary endpoint despite encouraging Phase I data. A Phase II trial combining DEB-TACE with sorafenib also failed to meet its primary endpoint.
Sorafenib is the only agent approved to treat HCC a situation that hasn’t change over the past 5 years.
Additional regimens are being trialled with existing and new agents but sadly, there has been a high risk of failure in both first and second line.
Next steps being considered for HCC
Silencing the expression of c-Met is generating exciting Phase II data with tivantinib being highlighted.
Combining molecule target agents such as VEGF + EGRF pathway inhibitors has been explored with some success. Dr Zhu pointed out the importance of patient selection with regard to single arm trials given the wide discrepancy of observed results
Dr Zhu concluded that biomarker lead tumour signatures will play an increasing role in guiding HCC treatment regimes and was very encouraged by tivantinib results.
Oral Abstracts of Interest
• Activity of Cabozantinib in HCC: Results from a phase II randomised discontinuation trial presented by Dr.Chris Verslype. Study design below. 41 advanced HCC patients , treated 12 weeks open label w/ cabozantinib, stratified in 3 groups
◦ PR or CR : extension open label ( 17%)
◦ SD : blinded & randomized placebo vs cabozantinib ( 54%)
◦ PD : discontinued (22%)
◦ population characteristics : 61 median age, 37% asian - 63% non asian, 73% extrahepatic spread
◦ Results :
▪ 4.4 months PFS regardless of prior treatment w/ sorfenib & 15.1 month median OS
▪ 35% AFP response in patients randomized
▪ 78% regression per RECIST
▪ increase in hemoglobin ( 3g/dl) over time
▪ 29% discontinued prior week 12
▪ AEs : fatigue grade 3+ : 10% & diarrhea grade 3+ : 20%
Discussion
• c-MET has some rationale , it does bad things as well ie proliferation...
• HCC is difficult population : frequent SD, heterogeneous etiologies
• vs tivantinib, cabozantinib has a second pathway ie VEGFR2 besides c-MET & a novel trial design ( randomized discontinuation)
• an issue was the high amounts of discontinuation
• PFS over 4 month suggests some effect while 15 month survival is encouraging.
• This is a highly selected patient group in a small study
A phenomena that happened during this trial is increases in haemoglobin but it is not yet known if this is a class or drug effect.
There is a randomised in depth phase II study at a lower dose of 60mg in 2nd line HCC is planned
Tivantinib (ARQ197) vs Placebo in Patients (Pts) with Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) Who failed One Systemic Therapy: Results of a Randomized Controlled Phase 2 Trial (Sponsored by ArQule Inc. and Daiichi Sankyo Co)
This study is the first randomized study to show overall survival advantage in MET HCC patients
107 patients enrolled in 23 sites in Europe and North America participated in the study from October 2009 — August 2011. Time to progression (TTP) was the primary study endpoint. The primary endpoint was met with a 56% improvement of patients receiving tivantinib verses placebo. OS, a secondary endpoint did not meet statistical significance.
MET High patients on placebo had twice the risk of dying verses those patients with MET low characteristics. Whereas, MET high patients (a pre-specified sub-group for statistical analysis) on tivantinib experienced 133% improvement in TTP verses placebo
The most impressive result of this trial was a 163% improvement in the overall survival of MET High patients receiving tivantinib verses placebo. For MET low patients receiving tivantinib both TPP and OS were statistical similar to placebo.
The higher dose of tivantinib resulted in higher haematologic event (neutropenia). This decreased when the dose was adjusted. A comparable clinical benefit was observed for both doses. A Phase III study in the MET Dx High HCC population is being planned.
Questions
The speaker was asked a question about the apparent increased in benefit of tivantinib in HCV + /HBV- patients. Dr Rimassa confirmed the analytical observation however commented that no statistical relationship could be found between MET status and viral status.
Dr Rimassa then answered the question “no” to additional unspecified factors influencing the outcome of the study as everything had been analysed that had the potential to unbalance the study.
In response to the significance of MET in the design of future trials Dr Rimassa stated that it was clear prognostic factor. She went onto to say the MET status should be assessed in all HCC studies where second line treatments were being studied.
Posters of Interest:
Safety and efficacy of MET inhibitor tivantinib (ARQ 197) combined with sorafenib in patients (pts) with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) from a phase I study.
A phase II trial of MEK inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in combination with sorafenib as first-line systemic treatment for patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) was also presented however, frequent dose modifications due to AEs might have limited the treatment effect of this combination.
Randomized phase II study of the x-linked inhibitor of apoptosis (XIAP) antisense AEG35156 in combination with sorafenib in patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). AEG35156 is a 2nd generation antisense oligonucleotide which targets XIAP; it is designed to lower the apoptotic threshold of cancer cells, enhancing their sensitivity to intrinsic death and chemotherapy, without harming healthy cells. The Phase II results presented were not very impressive

item.title: ASCO Intelligence Update Part IV - NET/pNET
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: New data was presented at ASCO although nothing earthshattering. Amgen’s AMG 479 did not fare so well in pNETs and doubts surround its use. Data from the RADIANT-2, RAMSETE, PAZONET, UKINETS and NCRI trials all are discussed.
Novartis presented a poster on multivariate analysis including biomarkers in the phase III RADIANT-2 study of octreotide LAR plus everolimus or placebo among patients with advanced neuroendocrine tumors (NET). This information has been previously reported. Dr Andrea Wang-Gilliam discussed this poster in a session and agreed with the authors conclusion that baseline CgA (Chromogranin A) is a strong prognostic factor for beneficial everolimus therapy. Given this data, she then posed the question should 24 hour urine samples to measure 5-HIAA still be collected and declared that RADIANT-3 should answer this question.
Amgen’s AMG 479 (a human monocolonal antibody against IGF1-R ) open label Phase II trial showed AMG479 was well tolerated however lacked efficacy in pNETs. Subgroup analysis to identify characteristics of patients who may have benefited from therapy with AMG 479 is ongoing.
RAMSETE: A single-arm, multicenter, single-stage phase II trial of RAD001 in advanced and metastatic silent neuro-endocrine tumours in Europe which evaluated the safety and efficacy of everolimus monotherapy was evaluated in pts with advanced nonsyndromic, nonpancreatic NET was presented.
82 patients were screened in 16 EU clinics, 73 were treated with everolimus monotherapy. 18 completed the study and 55 discontinued mainly due to disease progression and adverse events (31% respectively). Data showed that everolimus demonstrated a high rate of disease stablisation after primary tumor progression with favourable median PFS in this group of patients.
Updated results from a phase III trial of sunitinib vs placebo in patients with progressive, unresectable, well-differentiated PNETs — a retrospective analysis of PFS by Blinded Independent Central Review (BICR) along with 2 year updated OS results. The objective of the study was to determine whether BICR confirmed the investigator assessed PFS advantage for sunitinib and whether OS is prolonged in the sunitinib treatment arm compared with the placebo arm despite patient cross over.
BICR analysis of PFS showed a 6.8 month improvement in median PFS with sunitinib confirming the treatment effect reported with investigator assessment. At 2 years after study closure, OS based on the ITT population continued to favour sunitinib although this result was not statistically significant (treatment cross over and limited statistical power)
PAZONET: Results of a phase II trial of pazopanib as a sequencing treatment in progressive metastatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) patients (pts), on behalf of the Spanish task force for NETs was presented.
Patients with locally advanced or metastatic NETs derived either from digestive tract, bronchial, thymic, or pancreatic islet cell origin will recieve pazopanib 800mg/day until disease progression or intolerance. Patients could have previously received treatment with SSA, chemo, anti VEGF or mTOR inhibitors. 44 patients were enrolled between Jan 2011 and March 2012. Data cut off was in December 2011 with 33 patients evaluable for response per protocol. Primary endpoint was Clinical Benefit Rate.
This data showed:
  • Pazopanib either as a single agent or in combination with somatostatin analogue is an active option in patients with NETs
  • Pazopanib has shown activity in patients with NETs who have failed at least one previous systemic treatment based on mTOR or other multitarget agents
  • Pazopanib toxicity profile was similar to that reported with other types of solid tumors
  • Biomarker analysis using circulating tumour cells (CTC’s), circulating endothelial cells (CECs), circulating endothelial progenitor cells (CEPC’s), Tumor markers,metabolic polymorphisms and soluble angiogenic markers are ongoing.
  • Pazopanib derserves further studies in the sequencing strategy for those patients
UKINETS: Treatment of advanced neuroendocrine tumors: Results of the UKINETS and NCRI randomized phase II NET01 trial was presented, showing the novel Cap-strep ± cisplatin regimens were associated with overall disease control and survival durations consistent with published studies. Cap-strep was better tolerated than Cap-cist. Further prospective randomised studies are required to determine optimal NET chemotherapy.
A phase II study of bevacizumab, pertuzumab and sandostation for patients with Advanced NETS from the Sarah Cannon Institute was presented. The primary endpoint was to determine the OOR of patients with low grade neuroendocrine cancer when treated with the combination of of bevacizumab, pertuzumab and sandostation LAR. Secondary endpoints were looking at the DCR, TTP PFS and OS. The study showed that OOR of the combination was similar to previously described results with the response rates in carcinoid patients encouraging.
A discussion on the Current Therapeutic Approach for Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumours: Current and Future Directions is described below
Summary
  • Classification of pNETs is still and on going issue and not fully resolved. Evidence is emerging that AJCC pNET staging model included in the 7th edition of AJCC can be linked to prognosis.
  • A well-defined patient selection algorithm exists with the clinical focus being on metastatic progressive patients
  • Trials to answer the questions of whether biologic agent combinations improve outcomes as well as if somatostatin analogues have antitumor activity will soon report. Ipsen’s CLARINET was mentioned in this context.
  • A trial to help define a standard cytotoxic therapy is about to start evaluating temozolomoide and temozolomoide/capecitabine
  • Key recommendations from a 2009 NET clinical trials planning meeting have been realised over the past 3 years
Full consensus of how pancreatic NETS should be classified is still evolving with discrepancies between NANETS, WHO, ENETS and the AJCC. The AJCC has now included pancreatic NETs staging into its 7th Edition which was closely modelled on the pancreatic adenocarcinoma system. This has subsequently been validated with the staging being linked to disease prognosis.
The presenter followed on with the ideal sequencing of therapies is not yet known and went on to discuss chemotherapies and biologic agents. Stating overall survival for Everolimus has not yet been reached and with sunitinib, median overall survival has been reached although not statistically significant. Finally, alkylating agents such as temozolomide have demonstrated 18 month PFS with a 70% response rate in treating pNETS. The speaker then posed the question do biologic combinations improve outcome? An outline of the CALGB 80701 Phase II was described combining everolimus and octreotide.
Somatostatin analogues are known to have activity in mid gut NET however this has not yet been prospectively proven in pNETS. Two trials, Ipsen’s CLARINET and Novartis COOPERATE are poised to answer this question
An ECOG trial to help define a standard cytotoxic therapy is about to start evaluating temozolomoide and temozolomoide/capecitabine
Prognostic biomarkers have now been associated with longer survival
Whereas chromogranin A and neuron specific enolase (NSE) are associated with shorter PFS/OS. Data showing that MGMT deficiency is associated with a response to temozolomide in pNETS although patient numbers were small

item.title: EMA Draft Position Paper on Possible Medication Errors When Developing New Forms and Indications
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The position paper is intended to provide guidance on how potential medication errors should be addressed caused by confusion of a newly introduced medicinal product with an existing one, similar in active substance but different in some aspects.
The Agency says that changes introduced during the lifecycle of a medicine – such as a new indication, formulation, strength, or pack design – can have an impact on the product's use in clinical practice. The same applies when a competing product a generic or biosimilar) that refers to the originator product but differs in certain respects is marketed.
The EMA says that that in many cases, the benefits of the new product may outweigh the risk of errors. Examples of such benefits include improved stability, a reduction in excipients that can cause side-effects in some people, a different formulation not requiring dilution or liposomal forms that improve compliance.
The draft position paper is out for consultation until 30 November 2012 ema.europa.eu/doc…
Source: EMA/Scrip

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Biogen Idec Analyst Day Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On June 12th, Biogen Idec hosted an Analyst Day to provide an update on the company’s commercial strategy, select late and early-stage clinical development programs, as well as the revitalization of its R&D. Management provided greater visibility into the early pipeline, which consists almost entirely of agents discovered by the company scientists. Significant restructuring of R&D is underway, with the elimination of 'cardiology' and 'oncology' to focus on 'neurology', 'immunology' and 'hemophilia'. It was confirmed that both Ph3 hemophilia studies (A-LONG, B-LONG) are on-track for data in H2:12 (with no updates on timing). Interesting slides on the 'success factors' for their 'successful launch' are provided below.
Early stage Pipeline
Pipeline today

US and EU Regulatory Status and Requirements

item.title: Lilly Expands Stake In Chinese Manufacturer - Marketing Of Biosimilar Insulin In China Could Be Planned
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Having unveiled robust Phase II data for its new insulin treatment LY2605541, which unusually is associated with weight loss, Eli Lilly also announced on Tuesday that it had boosted its equity position in Chinese player Novast Laboratories. Lilly Could be the only established insulin manufacturer that pursues both branded and biosimilar insulins with potentially the commercialisation of biosimilar insulin focused on the emerging markets, notably China.
Lilly's Strategic Focus
According to Morgan Stanley analysts, Diabetes remains an integral area of investment to Eli Lilly in terms of revenue expansion via its R&D pipeline. It forecasts that one third of the company's 2020 pipeline revenue projection will be derived from this disease area.
Competitive Forces In The Insulin Market
Eli Lilly is gunning for Sanofi's Lantus, both in terms of trying to improve upon the drug's profile with LY2605541 and to produce a biosimilar equivalent phIII data for which will be available next year. Sanofi is current market leader in the long-acting insulin space. By the time Eli Lilly secures approval for its product, Novo Nordisk is also likely to have launched degludec. A clearer understanding of the commercial profile of LY '541 will emerge in 2014, when pivotal-stage results become available.
Chinese Focus
Assuming both make it to the market, exactly how Lilly's plans to strategise the commercialisation of competing products remains unclear but the biosimilar focus could be more geared towards emerging markets including China. Eli Lilly has stated that it believes a third of the global market could fall to biosimilars; an assertion that Sanofi management has dismissed.

item.title: ASCO Intelligence Update - Part II - Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Enzalutatimde, Abiraterone, Radium-223 and Orteronel all had a number of posters displayed during ASCO.
Janssen - Abiraterone Poster Discussions
Dr. Goodman presented an Exploratory Analysis of Survial Benefit and Prior Docetaxel Treatment in COU-AA-301, a phase II study of AA plus prednisone in mCRPC highlighting that the survial benefit with AA was maintained regardless of prior docetaxel timing, duration and reason for discontinuation. However, survival benefit for patients in the AA arm was signifcatntly less in patients who discontiued docetaxel treatment due to progressive disease versus all other reasons.
Janssen also held an invite only dinner where they basically detailed the summary of product characteristics of abiraterone, phase III post-chemo data,how to take the product and explained in detail why there is the need for steriods with this drug. There were about 55 delegates in attendence at the dinner.
Bayer — Radium 223 Oral Poster Discussions
Dr. Chris Parker discussed the updated analysis of the phase III ALSYMPCA trial. This update is after 528 events and was conducted before the cut-off in July 2011. It is understood that Bayer has filed Radium-223 and are expecting a first response from the FDA in the Autumn of this year. The source could not provide details on a filing in the EU. Due to the inclusion criteria, the label could be unusual in that it includes patients which are unfit for docetaxel. At least 45% of the patients on the trial ‘were considered unfit’. A reminder of the study schema is found below.
Primary endpoint is OS. Secondary endpoints include time to first SRE, time to total ALP progression, total ALP response, total ALP normalization, time to PSA progression, Safety and QOL (not presented at this meeting)
Results are as follows:
Off the back of this data, Dr. Parker stated that he was tempted to speculate that radium 223 might be more effective in this high alkaline phosphatase group
There was a modest increase in grades 3 and 4 thrombocytopenia and an increase in grade 1 and 2 diarrhea and vomiting. He concluded with radium 223 is the first alpha-emitter to be investigated and may also be studied in other cancers with bone metastasis.
In a discussion by Dr. Fizazi, he listed the pros and cons of Radium-223 and highlighted cost, lack of activity against non-bone metastases and disconnect between PSA/OS as the most pressing unanswered questions.
Medivation/Astellas — MDV3100 Posters
Medivation/Astellas have opened a new Phase II trial, a randomised open label study of MDV3100 alone or in combination with Leuprolide and Dutasteride as neoadjuvant therapy to PT in intermediate and high risk pCa. The study opened in May 2012 and is enrolling 40-50 patients at 2 sites each in the USA and Canada. Study design and endpoints are found below
A poster of the on-going TERRAIN Study, a phase II randomised trial looking at MDV3100 vs bicalutamide in men with mCRPC was shown. Planned enrolment of 370 patients in 90 sites across EU and USA. Study design is found below along with statistical methods for primary endpoint (PFS).
Takada/Millennium TAK-700 Posters
Takeda had three posters displayed at ASCO. Currently, there are no trials on-going in China and no plans as of yet to do so due to the difficulty of the regulatory environment. Trials are on-going in Taiwan, Korea, and Japan. The Japanese trial has about 25 — 26 patients currently and a lower dose is being investigated due to absorption differences in these patients. Takeda is now accepting TAK-700 in their IISR (Investigator Initiated Sponsored Research Study) Clinical Request System. Millennium have established an internal review committee to evaluate IISR proposals and are keen to receive submission for TAK-700 and Alisertib. See more on millennium.envisi…
1)Trial C21005 (post chemo) began in September and planned enrollment is 1,083 patients. Recruitment is at 85% and is expected to complete in October. It is understood C21004 (pre chemo) has completed enrollment.
2)Safety and activity of the investigational agent TAK-700 (orteronel) without prednisone in men with nonmetastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (nmCRPC) and rising prostate-specific antigen (PSA): Updated results of a phase 2 study
The primary objective of this study was to determine the percentage of patients achieving a PSA reduction to ≤ 0.2 ng/mL (undetectable levels). Patients with PSA values of 0.2ng/mL or less have been shown to have a greater survival advantage. Secondary objectives were to determine the safety of orteronel, PSA response rates at 3 months and 6 months (decline in PSA of ≥ 90 percent, ≥ 50 percent and/or ≥ 30 percent), the percentage of patients achieving a PSA reduction to ≤ 0.2 ng/mL after 6 months, time to PSA progression, time to metastases, duration of progression-free survival, and changes in endocrine markers.
Results from the study of 39 patients, which were presented by Dr. George, showed:
  • 16 percent of patients experienced PSA ≤ 0.2 ng/mL at three months, and 12 (32%) experienced PSA ≤ 0.2 ng/mL as their best response
  • 32 percent experienced a decline in PSA of ≥ 90 percent at 3 months 23 (61%) experienced a decline in PSA of ≥ 90 percent as their best response
  • 76 percent experienced a decline in PSA of ≥ 50 percent at 3 months, and 84 percent experienced a decline in PSA of ≥ 50 percent as their best response
  • Median time to PSA progression was 14.8 months
  • With a median follow-up of 7 cycles (8.3 months), only three patients developed metastatic disease; freedom from metastases was 97 percent at 6 and 12 months, and median time to metastases was not reached
  • Orteronel dosed without prednisone suppressed testosterone by 87-89 percent and the adrenal androgen DHEA by 85-89 percent
  • The most common adverse events were fatigue (62 percent), diarrhea (38 percent); and hypertension (38 percent)
  • The most common adverse events of grade 3 or higher were hypertension (15 percent); dyspnea (8 percent); and fatigue, hypokalemia and pneumonitis (each 5 percent)
3)Phase I results from a phase 1/2 study of TAK-700 with docetaxel and prednisone in mCPRC. Study design presented below
Results as follows:

item.title: PsychoGenics Is Seeking Partners for its Internal Neuro Program
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The preclinical CRO combines expertise in behavioral neurobiology with bioinformatics to discover treatments for major neuro/psychiatric disorders. Internal candidates include eltoprazine, a drug in Ph2 for Levodopa-Induced Dyskinesia (LID).
MOA: Eltoprazine is a selective 5-HT1A/1B partial agonist.
PC Data: eltoprazine effectively reduces LID at relatively low doses. Chronic administration of eltoprazine for 45 days shows not only suppression of LID and no tolerance but also protection from development of dyskinesias.
Study Results
Eltoprazine met the primary objective of the study by exhibiting a statistically significant reduction in LID at the 5 mg dose (p = 0.0007) and the 7.5 mg dose (p = 0.0467), without adversely affecting levodopa efficacy.
Eltoprazine was also well tolerated in this study and there were no serious AEs.
Study Design
Location: Conducted at 2 sites in Sweden
Recruitment: 22 patients
Protocol: single doses of eltoprazine and placebo along with a challenge dose of levodopa at each of the 5 treatment visits and assessed for parkinsonian and dyskinesia symptoms over a period of 3 hours post-treatment. The assessments were video-taped and scored by two independent blinded raters.
Primary efficacy: measured using the Clinical Dyskinesia Rating Scale (CDRS) and the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS).
Secondary endpoints: included the Rush Dyskinesia Rating Scale and evaluation of the patients' mood using the Hospital Anxiety & Depression Score (HADS) and Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS).
Support: The trial was partially supported by a grant from The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.
Source: PsychoGenics
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (28,5 KB)

item.title: Tokai's Galeterone Has Received Fast Track Designation for mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The drug is expected to enter Ph2 in H2:12. The company believes that galeterone’s unique triple mechanism of action may offer an important therapeutic advance as CRPC often becomes resistant to androgen deprivation therapy.
The Ph1 proof of concept study (ARMOR1), part of the ARMOR clinical dev. programme, was recently completed.
Presented recently at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting 2012 and the 2012 Annual Meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) the results show that galeterone demonstrated efficacy and was well-tolerated in patients with CRPC.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Astellas and Drais Set Up Second Virtual Company for Accelerating Drug Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This partnership is similar to the one Astellas and Drais entered into in April 2012 to transfer another Astellas compound (for UC). Those deals are part of Astellas' new 'Multi-Track R&D' approach, a strategy that enables to optimize costs and control risks.
  • Astellas to transfer to Seldar all rights and assets related to ASP147 (ready for an early-stage dosing trial)
  • Seldar to be responsible for all dev., manufacturing, and commercialization activies and their associated costs.
  • Astellas is entitled to receive milestone payment and royalties on future sales of the drug, and also has the right of first-exclusive negotiation for future partnering activities and the right for refusal for the Japanese market.
Both virutal companies were set up by the lead investors in Drais along with Astellas Management.
  • $13M will be invested into Seldar, which will provide a runway to further dev. the compound
  • Telsar is receiving $14M to fund the dev. of Astellas' ASP3291, a melanocortin receptor agonist in Ph2a for ulcerative colitis

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan Investors Can Proceed with BOTOX(R) Suit
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Two pension funds have claimed that Allergan's board failed to properly watch over executives who marketed the drug for unapproved indications, and gathered enough evidence to proceed with their demands. On June 11th, a judge ruled that investors can seek to hold Allergan's directors responsible for criminal sanctions and a $600M penalty that the company was ordered to pay in 2010.
In 2010, the Louisiana Municipal Police Employees Retirement System, which invested in Allergan’s shares, filed a so-called derivative suit against the company’s board over the BOTOX(R) marketing campaign. It later was joined in the suit by a Pennsylvania-based pension fund for restaurant workers.
Under such suits, any recovery from individual directors or insurance covering them would go to the company’s coffers rather than to individual shareholders.
Allergan agreed in Sept. 2010 to plead guilty by promoting BOTOX(R) for unapproved uses and to pay a total of $600M in fines and damages, and approved a payment of $375M in criminal fines and $225M to resolve civil claims (Please see Neurology5177: Allergan to Pay Fine to US Gov to Resolve Issues on BOTOX(R) Past Sales and Marketing Practices).

The case is Louisiana Municipal Police Employees Retirement System and UFCW Local 1776 & Participating Employers Pension Fund v. Pyott, 5795, Delaware Chancery Court (Wilmington).


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Detailed Information On New Sandostatin LAR Device
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Claudia Limberger (Endocrinology Marketing Manager Germany), we have more details about Novartis's new Sandostatin LAR device. A copy of the visual aid is attached.
The changes are mostly in line with what was previously reported (see Endocrinology6942: ECE Intelligence Part 2 - Cushing's & NET & Pituitary Adenoma Data) with the key features of the device as follows:-
  • easy: Quick-Link (Trademark) vial adapter makes the preparation of the suspension easier and offers the possibility to mix the suspension while the syringe is docked to the valve
  • safe: safety injection needle protects nurses against injuries
  • comfortable: 20% less injection volume (now 2 ml instead of 2,5 ml) for more patient comfort
  • efficient: improved suspension characteristics for the convenient usage of the application system
  • less pain: thinner injection needle (20 G instead of 19 G) for more patient comfort"
The key messages are mentioned are:
With a reduced filled volume this will have a direct impact on their CoG. Lower i suppose !
  • safe, due to new thinner safety needle (20G)
  • controlled, because it is injected by qualified personal
  • simple, thanks to easier and faster preparation
The new formulation is approved for both the treatment of Acromegaly and NET

Comments
Thanks to Susan Scott (Publications Director) at ENDO we have learnt that Novartis does not intend to launch new LAR device in USA for a couple of years at least, due to changing requirements to US regulations and study requirements.
The local US sales team stated " We are very happy with our current syringe and expect Pasreotide to be the next big thing" - " why would we launch a new device in USA when we have no competition in our biggest market NET."

item.title: Japanese Filing For Sanofi's New GLP-1 Analogue
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sanofi has filed for regulatory approval in Japan of its GLP-1 analogue Lyxumia (lixisenatide) for the treatment of adults with type 2 diabetes.
The company said that the submission to the Japanese MHLW is supported by data from its GetGoal Phase III programme which included a GetGoal-L Asian study.
Lyxumia, which is being developed under a licence from Zealand Pharma, has already been filed for regulatory approval in the EU, and was accepted by the agency in November. A submission in the US is expected in the fourth-quarter.
Source: www.sanofi.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: NICE Revises Amgen's Xgeva Guidance
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Last March, NICE recommended the drug for breast and prostate cancer patients whose disease has spread to the bone. But in light of new information from clinical experts, the agency has reported it no longer believed the drug represented a cost-effective treatment.
Please see Oncology8195: Amgen's Success With UK NICE.
The decision is due to revised thinking on the appropriate comparator treatments for the drug (which is an alternative to bisphosphonate drugs).

Comments

The U.K.’s NICE issued a final appraisal determination (FAD) recommending the use of Xgeva denosumab from Amgen to prevent skeletal-related events (SREs) in patients with bone metastases from breast cancer; and in patients with bone metastases from solid tumors other than breast and prostate cancer for whom zoledronic acid would be indicated. The recommendation, which is contingent on Amgen providing Xgeva at an undisclosed discount under a patient access scheme, does not recommend Xgeva to prevent SREs in patients with bone metastases from hormone-refractory prostate cancer (HRPC). Final guidance is expected next month.

Source : BioCentury for the week of August 27, 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Exelixis Reports Highly Significant Improvement in PFS in Medullary Thyroid Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At ASCO last week, Exelexis reported additional data from its international PhIII EXAM trial in 330 patients with locally advanced or metastatic medullary thyroid cancer with once daily oral cabozantinib demonstrating a 1 -year PFS rate of 47.3% vs 7.2% for placebo.
Last month Exelixis completed a rolling NDA submission to the FDA for the treatment of MTC, requesting a priority review. If approved it will market the product in the US. Its thoughts on commercialisation are noted below.
Results of the EXAM Trial
The EXAM study demonstrated a median duration of response of 14.6 months but at this point is not mature enought to demonstrate an improvement in overall survival.
Cabozantinib did significantly improve ORR, a secondary endpoint vs. placebo (28% vs. 0% p<0.0001).
When questioned about the commercial opportunity for a medullary thyoid cancer drug at the Goldman Sachs Conference Michael Morrissey CEO stated:-
"So our view on MTC is relatively simple. It's a small micro niche population. There is approximately 1000 or so patients in North America, about 1000 or so patients in Europe. A fraction of those patients have what's arguably advanced stage metastatic, really aggressive disease. Our clinical trial EXAM was designed to really ask the key question in that population. We had a IRF based inclusion criteria for active aggressive progressing disease. So we asked I think the right population – we asked the right question in the right population to really focus on the sub-population with the most clinical need versus the others who have relatively indolent disease for years or even a decade or more."
"So how that plays out commercially? We're going through that right now. We don't see this as a – as one that we'll invest heavily in. We certainly are interested in being able to use this to build up some level of infrastructure, get our kind of all of our ducks lined up in terms of what we need to do to be able to commercialize the compound, but it will not be a large spend from the standpoint of building out for MTC because that indication just doesn't warrant that."
"But that being said that, it's a great opportunity to get the compound potentially approved, which is no small feat for a company of our size and stature and to execute that across all the different components of what's involved is a very important point and with prostate, not too far behind. So it's one area that we're looking at very closely, but doing it in a very careful way and with an investment that matches the potential upside."
source: exelixis.com

Comments
Exelixis has been granted a priority review for cabozantinib for the treatment of medullary thyroid cancer. The FDA has set a review date of November 29th.

item.title: Monthly Administration of A GLP-1 Analogue Is Starting To Look Feasible
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment At the ADA meeting this weekend, Diartis Pharmaceuticals presented positive data from its recently completed Phase 1 multicenter clinical trial of VRS-859 (exenatide-XTEN). VRS-859, is a long-acting GLP-1 analog, that is being developed as a once monthly treatment for patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
The Diartis poster -- "Safety, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of a Single Subcutaneous Administration of VRS-859 in Patients with Type 2 Diabetes" highlighted how in the Phase 1 multicenter, blinded, placebo-controlled, single-ascending dose study statistically significant reductions in HbA1c levels were noted at 30 days after only a single 200 mg dose of VRS-859. A dose-proportional decreases in body weight was also observed within 30 days after a single treatment.
The study demonstrated that all doses administered (up to 200 mg) were well tolerated and no unexpected adverse events were noted. Furthermore, the PK of VRS-859 in these patients was dose linear and comparable to the profile predicted from preclinical studies, validating the half-life extension capability of the XTEN technology and supporting a once monthly dosing regimen for VRS-859.
Trial Design
The primary objective of the study was to determine the safety and tolerability of a single subcutaneous dose of VRS-859 in patients with T2DM. Secondary objectives included single dose pharmacokinetics, assessment to evaluate evidence of VRS-859 activity by measurement of fasting plasma glucose and response to oral glucose tolerance tests at selected times post-dose, as well as to evaluate post-challenge glucose excursions. Seventy T2DM patients concurrently on metformin were enrolled in the study: 18 patients received placebo and 52 patients received one of six dose levels: 12.5, 25, 50, 100, 150 and 200 mg.
Next Steps
The results support the company's plan to conduct a 6-month repeat dose study to determine a safe and efficacious subcutaneous dose of VRS-859 in patients with T2DM.
Source: www.diartispharma.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Lexicon's Presentation @ Jefferies 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lexicon provided some detailed data on LX4211, the only dual inhibitor of SGLT1 and SGLT2 in clinical development for diabetes. Management also confirmed that regulatory interactions with EMA and FDA are ongoing for the Ph3 preparation of LX1032 (for carcinoid syndrome), and that the Ph2 trial of LX1033 for IBS-d is expected to complete enrollment around year end (data expected Q1:2013).

item.title: Xeomin to be Evaluated in a Small Pilot Study for the Treatment of Rosacea
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In collaboration with Merz Pharm. LLC, the Ph2 will assess the safety and the change in rosacea as primary outcome measures. The pilot study will be conducted at DeNova Research Centre in Chicago (USA), which is specialized in aesthetic medicine, plastic surgery and dermatology.
Recruitment: approx. 10 subjects with rosacea of the cheek area.
Protocol: Upon entry, subjects will be randomized to receive either Xeomin or bacteriostatic saline to the cheek area.
At the 16 week visit, control subjects will enter the rescue arm portion of the study and all study subjects will receive treatment with incobotulinumtoxinA to the cheek areas.
Start date: June 2012 - Completion date: Dec 2012 / Feb 2013
Investigator: Steven H. Dayan, Medical Director (DeNova Research)

item.title: ASCO Intelligence Part 1 – New Treatment Paradigms For Hormone Therapy in Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Oncology8306: Highlights from the Abiraterone Ph3 Pre-Docetaxel Data - Feedback from ASCO

item.title: Joint Agreement Between Allergan and Endo for the Delivery of BOTOX®
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: American Medical Systems (AMS), an Endo company, and Allergan signed a co-development agreement to develop and seek regulatory approval for the delivery of BOTOX® using the JetTouch system(TM), a needle-free injection system, for the treatment of OAB.
Has the potential to enable needle-free injection into any area of the body reachable by endoscopic or percutaneous access.
The description provided to the USPTO is: Needle-less injection systems comprised of an injector tip, a fluid delivery lumen and user-console for controlling fluid quantity and pressure.
AMS will first develop JetTouch™ for general use in the bladder. Subject to the FDA approval of BOTOX® for injection by needle as a treatment for OAB, AMS, in collaboration with Allergan, will seek to add BOTOX®to the JetTouch™ label, and Allergan plans to seek regulatory advice to add the delivery of BOTOX® with JetTouch™ to the BOTOX® label.
Source: ENDO Pharm.;

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: EMA Biosimilar Guidance To Allow More Dosage Form Flexibility
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The EMA has joined the FDA in proposing to accept different biosimilar formulations anhd closures in revised draft guidance.
It has reworked sections of the 6-yr old EMA guidelines clarifying the level of flexibility biosimilar manufacturers have when choosing formulations for their drugs.
It has stated that:-
"The formulation of the bioisimilar does not need to be identifcal. If a different formulation and or container/closure system to the reference medicinal product is sellected its potential impact on the safety and efficacy should be appropriately justified"
This new wording is more in line with draft guidance issued by the FDA in February (see PharmaWorld9862: PhRMA Raises Concerns About FDA Biosimilar Flexibility)
Innovators have until November 30th to send comments to the EMA
A copy of the new draft guidance is attached to this article
  1. New EMA Draft Biosimilar Guidance.pdf  (160,3 KB)

item.title: Greece - Most Companies in Top 10 See Sales Decline in Q1:12
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sales of pharmaceuticals in Greece declined by a reported 6.7% year-on-year in the first quarter of 2012, while the problem of access to reimbursed medicines has become worse, as pharmacies continue to demand upfront payment.

Decline in Value, Volume of Greek Market in Q1

Pharmaceutical sales in Greece, excluding the hospital sector, declined by a reported 6.7% year-on-year (y/y) in the first quarter, amounting to EUR898.4 million (USD1.123 billion), according to data from IMS Health, based on sales from pharmaceutical companies to wholesalers and pharmacies, quoted by Greek newspaper Imerisia. The volume of the market fell slightly more steeply, by 8% y/y, to 97.7 million packages, the source reports.

Most Firms in Top 10 See Sales Decline

In terms of the top 10 pharmaceutical companies in Greece during this period, the first position was occupied by Swiss major Novartis, although the company's sales tumbled y/y in the period, to EUR76.6 million. In second place was United States major Pfizer, with an even larger sales slump of 17.4% y/y, to EUR71.9 million. The majority of the companies in the top 10 recorded falling sales during the period, although a number—including United Kingdom major GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) and German firm Boehringer Ingelheim—bucked this trend.

Source: IMS Health, Imerisia
In volume terms, Pfizer was the market leader in the period under review, although the number of packages it sold was down by 7.8% y/y to 7.99 million in the period, followed by GSK, which recorded a 0.9% y/y decline in volume terms to 7.50 million packages, and Sanofi, with a decline of 6.3% y/y to 6.90 million packages. In fourth and fifth position were Novartis, with a decline of 7.6% y/y to 6.65 million packages, and Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMS, US), with a reduction of 4.3% y/y to 5.87 million packages.
Additionally, the source reports that there was a decline in the volume of production of the domestic pharmaceutical industry in the first quarter, for the first time in some years, falling by a reported 0.6% y/y in the period under review.

Situation of Drug Supplies to Patients Deteriorates

Meanwhile, UK newspaper The Independent reports on the chaotic situation at pharmacies in Greece, with long queues outside pharmacies as patients seek to obtain lifesaving cancer drugs. Pharmacies continue to require upfront payment for reimbursed medicines, in protest against the substantial debts owed to them for reimbursed medicines supplied to patients insured under the National Organisation for Healthcare Provision (EOPYY). The source reports that Greece's prime minister, Panayotis Pikrammenos, has stated this week that the caretaker government cannot start to pay debts to pharmacies until the next loan is received from the country's international creditors.
Greek newspaper Ta Nea reports that after a meeting between the caretaker health minister Christos Kittas and the leader of the caretaker government, Alexis Tsipras, the situation with the supply of cancer medicine will "normalise". As the source reports, the Greek Ministry of Health has been in contact with pharmaceutical companies, which have agreed to a system under which they will be paid on delivery, and this solution will remain in place until the new government is elected.
Greek healthcare news provider Iatronet reports that Kittas is calling for 100 private pharmacies across Greece to co-operate with the EOPYY, admitting that with only four pharmacies in the Attica region supplying reimbursed medicines, the problem was serious. Understandably, representatives of pharmacists in Greece are opposed to such plans, with the head of the National Pharmaceutical Association quoted as saying that the solution should not involve a limited number of pharmacies, but all of them.

The decline in pharmaceutical sales in the outpatient sector is quite a lot less drastic than might be expected in Greece, considering the very difficult situation the country and its people are facing in economic terms. This reflects the fact that it appears to be an uphill struggle to combat the prescribing of "uneconomical" medicines—i.e., those more expensive than necessary—as has been shown by the fact that public spending on pharmaceuticals is still exceeding the levels set out in Greece's agreement with its creditors. With the much vaunted electronic prescription system not working in the way it was hoped, there are ongoing threats to the spending targets.
Meanwhile, the situation in pharmacies becomes more urgent by the day, and it appears the pharmacists are determined to hold out, in spite of the chaos. It should be emphasised that patients are able to obtain reimbursement once they have bought the medicines, but obviously, there are many people who are unable to afford to pay such sums of money upfront. Having only four pharmacies to be open in Attica supplying reimbursed medicines to those insured under the EOPYY is obviously hopelessly inadequate, and this also means significant downturns in drug sales.
From: Global Insight

item.title: re: Astellas - FY2011 Results - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Enrollment in the PREVAIL pre-chemotherapy trial should complete this month apart from in a few select Asian centres. Whether the study will report out at the interim stage remains to be seen as it has a co-primary endpoint of PFS and OS, the event rate for which is being independently monitored. 
On June 6th, Medivation and Astellas announced the completion of 1,680 patients in the PREVAIL (pre-chemo) trial apart in a few Asian centres, to gain additional information on this specific population.

item.title: Ph3 Trial of Elagolix for Endometriosis-Associated Pain Has Begun Screening for Enrollment
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In line with the forecasts, Neurocrine and Abbott have announced the initiation of the first pivotal trial, designed to assess the safety and efficacy of the GnRH antagonist in female patients with endometriosis.
  • Design: multinational, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
  • Recruitment: approx. 875 women (age 18 to 49) with moderate-to-severe endometriosis associated pain.
  • Location: 160 sites (U.S; Puerto Rico; Canada).
A 2nde Ph3 is planned with an NDA filing targeted in 2016.

item.title: re: AFFiRiS Starts Preclinical Development Of Its Parkinson's Vaccine
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
AFFiRiS Starts Preclinical Development Of Its Parkinson's Vaccine 
Comment: On successful conclusion of this preclinical evaluation, initial clinical testing could start in 2010/11.  ...
The WW 1st clinical trial has now been started by AFFiRiS AG. The trial will be conducted at the Confraternität Privatklinik Josefstadt (Vienna), and will involve > 32 patients.
Mechanism of Action
PD01A targets a protein called alpha-Synuclein (alpha-syn) which plays a key role in the onset and progression of Parkinson´s. The vaccination aims to educate the immune system to generate antibodies directed against alpha-syn
Partnership
Alzheimer's disease is the current lead indication. In Oct. 2008, GSK licensed the vaccine.

item.title: Focus on Merz & Allergan Spasticity Symposia @ the 18th ESPRM (Thessaloniki, Greece)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Eleni Bozika (Product Manager) key messages and comments on Allergan symposia are provided below, and most importantly the preliminary results of the Merz' SPACE study, which highlight a need for more research into the use of high-dose BoNT/A. Details of the TOWER study, which is currently investigating the safety of high doses of Xeomin, are outlined as well.
Note: The SPACE study was highlighted last year by Andrea Reissig (Scientific Manager) ahead of its posting on the clinical trial databases.
The symposium was based on the importance of therapeutic goals when managing patients with stroke and treated with BTX-A. At the center of the presentation was a video with a patient who had stroke and who described the problems, the management and the benefit of the therapy.
Some aspects of the BEST trial were presented, and in particular the GAS scale and how it is used.
Core message of the symposium was the need to use high doses of BTX (over the SPC recommendations).
Dr Julian P. Harriss (King's College Hospital - London, UK) presented an interim analysis of the SPACE, non-interventional study, which shows the need to treat with higher doses.
  • Objective of the study: 1/to improve knowledge of the actual use of BONT/A in daily clinical practice 2/ to collect data from daily clinical practice.
  • Design: WW, non-interventional study
  • Recruitment: aim 930 (current 505)
  • Inclusion criteria: patients with spasticity naïve to BoNT/A
  • Duration: Follow-up 2 years
  • Sites: 9 countries (115 centres)
Preliminary results
205 patients (57% male gender; mean age: 53.7 years) assessed for baseline data to date.
Clinical need for high doses
- many patients require treatment for multi-focal spasticity > 51.2% of patients have 4 or more locations; 44.4% of patients have upper and lower limb spasticity and 49.3% of patients have a spasticity in the elbow, wrist and fingers.
- up to 420U injected per pattern
Guideline Recommendations Vs Clinical Practices
Additional information to the article published in Traction on May 22, 2012 (Please see Neurology6414: Dose-Titration Trial of Xeomin for Spasticity in the Leg and Arm).
Protocol
150 subjects (naïve or pre-treated with BoNT/A or BoNT/B) to be recruited across in 35 sites WW across 8 countries:
Design

Comments
Tower study - In Italy, Principal Investigator is Dr. F. Molteni Costamasnaga Lecco.
Other Centers
Hospital Casa Solievo della Sofferenza San Giovanni Rotondo (Bari) Dr. M. Basciani
Hospital Passignano (Perugia) Dr. F. Sciarrini
Up to date: Received EC approvals. Planned initiation visits.

item.title: US District Court in Virginia Grants Allergan's Motion for a New Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to an article published in the Chicago Tribune, Allergan is granted a new trial, as Judge Robert Payne has ruled that the company could not include a boxed warning to BOTOX packing inserts regarding the potential health risks without obtaining prior FDA approval. The hearing is expected for June 9.
In April 2011, a plaintiff won a $212M jury verdict after alleging the BOTOX injections he took to treat movement disorder in his right hand (an off-label-use of the drug) rendered him disabled.
Allergan was accused of failing to alert doctors that the drug injections could cacause autoimmune reactions that lead to brain damage.
Source: Chicago Tribune
  • Full PR @ http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-06-01/lifestyle/sns-rt-us-allergan-botox-trialbre85019y-20120601_1_juvenile-cerebral-palsy-kristen-spears-allergan
Please see Neurology5177: Allergan to Pay Fine to US Gov to Resolve Issues on BOTOX(R) Past Sales and Marketing Practices.

item.title: Highlights from the Abiraterone Ph3 Pre-Docetaxel Data - Feedback from ASCO
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: One of the more anticipated results at this year's ASCO was the final data of the COU-AA-302, stopped early as independent monitors (DMC) reporting the drug was clearly effective. Thanks to Eric Chetaille, who attended the presentation, key results of the co-primary endpoints (OS;PFS) are provided below, as well as highlights from a discussion which questionned the decision of the DMC.
Presented by Dr Charles Ryan of UC San Francisco.
PFS and OS as co-primary endpoints
- positive results both in OS (27.2 months vs not reached yet estimated at 33 months i;e hazard ratio of 0.75 (0.61-0.93) p=0.0097 and PFS (8.3 months vs not reached yet estimated at 13.5 months i;e hazard ratio 0.43.
Safety
- no new safety signal with main relevant grade 3/4 AE being cardiac toxicities (6 vs 3%).

Susan Halibi, associate professor of biostatistics and bioinformatics at Duke University, presented the COU-AA-302 OS data in the context of the O’Brien-Fleming boundary, that graphically represents a curve, one side of which the drug is judged to be “ineffective,” the other side “effective.”

The slide below

In that case, why would the independent data monitoring committee (DMC) choose to unblind the study at the time it did the analysis, rather than wait a little longer until statistical significance might be reached?

  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (41,5 KB)

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Phase 1 study will assess dose limiting toxicity as a primary outcome measure. LFA102 is currently in Ph1 in the U.S and EU (Belgium; Italy; Spain) in patients with prolactin receptor-positive CRPC or prolactin receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer.
Protocol: LFA102 will be administered intravenously once every 4 weeks during the study. All patients will remain on treatment until they meet the criteria for study discontinuation.
Recruitment: approx.2 4
Start date: June 2012 - Completion date: Aug 2014
Location: 2 sites in Nagoya and Kobe
