item.title: MHRA Says that 'EU Equivalence' Could Cause Drug Shortages
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: T

Switzerland has become the first country to receive an "equivalence" rating from the European Commission for its regulations on APIs, however many of the biggest API manufacturing countries including India and China have still not even applied for an equivalence assessment.
Under the EU's falsified medicines Directive, whose provisions come into force on 2 January 2013, all APIs imported into the EU as of that date must have been manufactured to GMP standards that are at least equivalent to those of the EU. Only four other countries have so far applied for an equivalence assessment: Israel, Australia, Singapore and Brazil.
The large API producers such as India, China, South Korea, Japan, Taiwan and Mexico have not yet applied.
Source: Scrip 26 November 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Generic Prices in Europe: Evolving Trends and Their Impact on the Drug Industry
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In an attempt to generate savings, generics are increasingly being targeted by governments, which have found different ways to significantly lower their prices, as well as the prices of their originator counterparts. This report aims to provide pharmaceutical companies with a better understanding of the cost-containment policies directly affecting prices once generics enter the market, as well as how pharmaceutical companies usually react to those policies.

Key Findings
  • Governments usually combine different cost-containment policies to ensure prices drop significantly once generics enter the market.
  • Many governments are increasingly becoming suspicious that rather than being a source of cost saving compared with branded originator drugs, the prices of generics are actually higher than they should be, and their use is not generating as much in the way of savings as it should.
  • An awareness of the main cost-containment policies affecting prices and how to react to them is critical.
  • Several case studies demonstrate that a few competitors enter the pharmaceutical markets where conditions are too restrictive. In those cases, generic companies will tend not to enter those markets and originator drugs are often withdrawn from the market.
  • In Italy and Spain, generic prices are on average 16% and 13% below originator prices (in terms of retail prices), according to a selection of drugs from IHS Global Insight's international pricing data.
  • In some countries, generic companies are dropping their prices significantly below the required levels. For instance, our data show that the first generic of olanzapine has just entered the Austrian market (April 2012) and although only one company has entered the market so far, the price drop implemented is significantly larger compared with the minimum requested. This will put new competitors in an extremely difficult position.
With universal healthcare coverage in place in almost all European countries, ageing populations, and costly treatments, healthcare expenditure is steadily rising in all developed countries, and as such, making savings has become one of the top priorities for governments, notably for drugs.
Governments are not only becoming increasingly stringent on funding new drugs, but also on drugs that are genericised (generics and biosimilars). For the purpose of this report, and given the complexity of the biosimilars legislation, only generics will be studied. Large savings are expected in this area, notably with the great number of molecules that are coming off-patent this year (including irbesartan, candesartan, donepezil, esomeprazole, and montelukast) and in the coming years. Governments are increasingly becoming suspicious that rather than being a source of cost saving against branded originator drugs, the prices of generics are actually higher than they should be, and their use is not generating as much in the way of savings as it should.
Governments have found different ways to limit expenses: once generics enter the market, prices must drop significantly. Most governments also set the maximum levels at which patients will be reimbursed. Finally, in certain countries, exclusivity will be given to the pharmaceutical companies providing the lowest prices for a given genericised molecule. Governments also combine some of these cost-containment policies to make sure significant savings are achieved. On top of that, discounts are also largely granted, enabling prices to drop further. In parallel, several policies also directly target pharmacists or physicians in an attempt to raise generic penetration. Those policies will not be taken into account in this report, however.
The below table summarises the main policies used to lower prices in 24 EU countries. Generic companies and pharmaceutical companies willing to face generic competition must assess the different criteria used in each pharmaceutical market before implementing their pricing strategy.

Pricing Policies: First Tool Directly Lowering Prices

It is a well known fact that complex and usually time-consuming pricing procedures are in place for innovative drugs in all European countries. In an attempt to generate savings quickly, governments have commonly implemented pricing procedures that differ from the ones used for new and innovative drugs and therefore speed up generic market entry. Below are details of the different pricing policies used by governments in order to set generic prices.

Price-Capping Policies

When it comes to generic pricing, most countries have now implemented a price-capping policy. This is the case in 15 out of the 24 countries studied (more than 60%). Prices of new generics coming onto these markets, as well as off-patent products, must decrease either by set percentages that pharmaceutical companies must strictly apply, or by percentages indicating the minimum price drop that must apply. Those price cuts are in most cases directly linked to the price of the newly off-patent product. In a few cases, the price of the first generic entering the market is linked to the price of the originator, while prices of the subsequent generics are linked to the price of other generics already on the market. This is the case for instance in Austria.
These methods enable governments to speed up pricing procedures, and as such, generics quickly enter these markets. In France, for instance, generic prices are set in advance of patent expiry. Prices of the generics and off-patent medicines are published in the French Official Bulletin before the molecule loses its patent. One example of this is olanzapine, for which generic were set in July 2011, but market entry occurred around two months later.

Specific Percentage Price Drop

Most countries cap generic prices at a certain level. This is the case for instance in Belgium, the Czech Republic, Finland, Italy, Portugal, Spain, and Ireland.
Markets using this type of generic pricing policy can be divided into two groups: countries that cannot deviate from the pricing policy and countries where the percentage is capped to a certain level, allowing pharmaceutical companies to lower prices below that threshold.
In Italy and Spain, generic prices are on average 16% and 13% below the originator price (in terms of retail prices). These figures were determined on the basis of prices for 10 genericised active ingredients (source: PharmOnline International [POLI], 2011).
It is not uncommon, however, that in certain countries, pharmaceutical companies decrease their prices far below the required price drop. In Finland, for example, when generics enter the market, their prices should be lowered by at least 40% compared with the originator price. Nevertheless, an analysis of the prices from POLI shows that generic prices are set on average around 50% below the price that should already be applied (meaning 50% below the 40%). Nevertheless, prices of off-patent drugs do not necessarily drop. For instance, 15 months after generic versions of pramipexole entered the market, the price of originator drug Sifrol had not changed.
In those countries using a price-drop policy, when the maximum level of reimbursement is not set by law, there is a certain amount of flexibility in terms of pricing strategies. Complexity is caused in countries also implementing reference pricing for reimbursement. In this case, it is not rare to see the different competitors on the market bring their prices into line with the reference price, or even below.
In France, the regulations are strictly followed, with little room for manoeuvre. Once generics enter the market, originator prices must drop 20% (in terms of manufacturer prices) and generic prices must be 60% below the originator price before the 20% price cut applies. This rule is strictly implemented, as demonstrated with the following example: generics of Zomig (zolmitriptan) entered the French market in January 2011; as seen in table 2, price cuts are strictly implemented for all generics on the market. As a consequence, generics are all priced at the same level.

Table 2: Zolmitriptan Generic and Off-Patent Price Cut, France

Zolmitriptan 2.5 mg, 6 Orodispersible Tablets

Manufacturer Price Before Generic Market Entry (EUR)

Manufacturer Price After Generic Market Entry (EUR)

Price Cut (%)

Zomig

21.46

17.17

20.0

Generics

-

8.58

60.0

Source: POLI, April 2012
It should be noted that the French government is becoming more stringent as the percentages of price drops increased in January 2011. They were previously set at 55% for generics and 15% for originator drugs.

Specific Percentage Price Drop Linked to National Generic Launch Sequencing: Few Competitors on Markets

In a few countries—Austria, Hungary, and recently Greece, for instance—generic pricing is linked to launch sequencing. The first market entrant must drop its price as a percentage of the originator price, and the other entrants must then drop their prices to a lower level. In those cases, being the first generic to enter the market is crucial for generic companies. As such, they must ensure to file their dossiers for reimbursement and/or pricing as fast as possible in order to secure the first market entry, all the more so when generic prices are directly linked to the price of the generics that were previously on the market. This is notably the case in Austria.
In this market, specific price drops are requested and incremented over time, to ensure prices of genericised drugs decrease significantly over time.
  • The first generic must be priced 48% below the originator. After three months, the originator price must decrease by 30%, granting both the originator drug and the first generic product a three-month exclusivity period.
  • The second generic entering the market must be priced 15% below the first generic on the market.
  • The third generic entering the market must be priced 10% below the price of the second generic.
  • Eventually, all prices are brought into line with the price of the third generic on the market, including the originator drug.
For the company securing the first market entry, prices will not be as low as for the other generics entering the market (at least for a certain period); this will help the company generate market shares and brand equity. IHS Global Insight's pricing database, POLI, shows that prices of the first generic entering the market usually drop below the requirement. For instance, the first generic of olanzapine has just entered the Austrian market (in April 2012), and it should be noted that:
  • Only one generic company has entered the market so far.
  • The price drop implemented is significantly larger compared with the minimum requested. This will put new competitors in an extremely difficult position. As such, it is likely that only a few generic companies will enter this market now. Indeed, a small number of generic companies are usually on the market for each genericised molecule. For instance, 12 generic companies compete for the molecule venlafaxine in Austria, while this figure reaches 34 in Germany.
  • The price of the originator drug has not dropped yet, but it will over the next two months.

Table 3: Olanzapine Generic and Off-Patent Price Cut, Austria

Olanzapine15 mg, 28 Tablets

Manufacturer Price Before Generic Market Entry (EUR)

Manufacturer Price After Generic Market Entry (EUR)

Source: POLI
In Hungary, the price drops requested also decrease over time, but price drops are linked to the price of the originator drug. This means that even if being the first generic company to enter the market is a priority, the pricing strategy implemented by the company marketing the first generic will not be a significant barrier to market entry as is the case in Austria.
The rules that should apply in Hungary are:
  • The first generic entering the market must be priced 35% below the originator drug.
  • The second generic on the market must be priced 45% below the originator drug.
  • The third and subsequent generics must be priced 55% below the originator drug.
In practice, as soon as a drug loses its patent, several generic companies enter the market during the same month and usually implement a different pricing strategy, which commonly triggers a price drop exceeding 35% but rarely reaching 50%.

Table 4: Esomeprazole Generic and Off-Patent Price Cut, Hungary

Esomeprazole 40 mg, 28 Tablets

Nexium

Source: POLI
Several case studies also demonstrate that pharmaceutical companies of the newly off-patent drug tend not to lower prices and then withdraw their products from the market. This is the case for instance for Aprovel (irbesartan). The first generics of irbesartan entered the Hungarian market in January 2011. Three months later, prices of Aprovel dropped 10% (manufacturer prices), and the product was eventually withdrawn from the market in January 2012. Sanofi (France) kept its generic version of Aprovel (Irbesartan Winthrop) only. This is also the case for the example noted in the table above (esomeprazole). Prices of Nexium dropped by 38.5% only around one year after the first generics entered the market. Another strategy used by pharmaceutical companies is to withdraw from the market all presentations of the originator drug but one. This was observed for instance for two newly genericised active ingredients: montelukast and donepezil.

Table 5: Pramipexole Generic Competition

Country

Number of Generic Companies Competing for Pramipexole

Austria

9

Hungary

7

Germany

39

France

13

Italy

14

Spain

16

Source: POLI, 2012
In countries where generic launch sequencing is taken into account for pricing, the number of competitors on the market tends to be lower in comparison with other pharmaceutical markets. Indeed, pharmaceutical companies not able to secure their market entry among the first entrants face two main issues: low prices and low brand equity. For instance, 39 generic companies compete for the active ingredient pramipexole in Germany, while this figure drops to 9 in Austria and 7 in Hungary.

Free Pricing

Generic pricing is nevertheless free in a few countries—although prices are usually indirectly controlled at least with the setting of the maximum level of reimbursement—with prices mainly regulated by market forces. This is the case in 4 out of the 24 countries studied: Denmark, Germany, Latvia, and the United Kingdom. This method has proven to stimulate competition.
Germany is a typical example of a country using free pricing for generics. Pharmaceutical companies are free to set their own prices, leading to fierce competition. For instance, for the active ingredient pramipexole, for one identical presentation (0.088 mg, 30 tablets), retail prices range from EUR12.72 to EUR29.42, with an average price of EUR16.43 and 21 companies competing for this specific presentation. This case is not isolated and is observed for all the drugs that are genericised.
The same trend is seen in Denmark, and generally speaking in countries where free pricing exists. Pharmaceutical companies implement their own pricing strategies, which lead to a wide range of drug prices, and a large number of generic companies usually enter those pharmaceutical markets.
The UK is somewhat unique. Despite the fact that generic pricing is free, generic companies are nevertheless not allowed to exceed the originator's prices. With the Drug Tariff, the government sets the maximum level at which pharmacists will be reimbursed. This tariff, however, is an approximation of the market price, which is set at a higher level in a bid to allow pharmacists to achieve a reasonable margin. Nevertheless, this usually does not trigger a drop in listing prices. POLI data shows that generic prices in the UK are often found to be among the highest in the top five European pharmaceutical markets. This mainly lies in the fact that the UK government does not play a significant role in limiting drug prices and, unlike Germany, where maximum levels of reimbursement are set by the government as a basis for patients' reimbursement, maximum prices are used as a basis for pharmacists' reimbursement. It should nevertheless be noted that prices are eventually lowered (below the Drug Tariff price) as pharmacists usually negotiate discounts, enabling them to increase their margins. This policy does not allow the government to generate savings, as it does not have any impact on the Drug Tariff prices.

Same Procedure As Innovative Drugs

A few countries use the same procedure for generic pricing as they do for innovative drugs. These include Bulgaria, the Netherlands, Poland, and Sweden, most of which use international reference pricing.
This is not the case in Sweden, a country using cost effectiveness to set drug prices. A price cut is usually required for the off-patent medicine, then generics entering the market must lower their price if they want to provide a cost advantage.
This methodology significantly lowers prices, notably when the lowest generic price for one molecule in a basket of countries abroad is taken into account. Nevertheless, this procedure is more time consuming in comparison with a simple price cut. As a consequence, generic market entry in those countries is often delayed.

Reimbursement Policies: a Tool Used Indirectly to Limit Drug Prices

Governments have implemented two different policies in order to lower prices indirectly and limit pharmaceutical expenditure.

Maximum Levels of Reimbursement

One of the most common ways, used by a great number of governments, and notably in countries where generic companies can freely set drug prices, is to cap the maximum level of reimbursement. Around 60% of the countries studied use this tool as a cost-containment policy (14 countries). Companies keeping prices above the reference price are likely to lose market shares as patients in this case must bear the cost of the difference between the maximum level at which the drug will be funded and the price of the drug.
Governments use different ways to set those maximum levels of reimbursement. In some, the lowest generic price in the country will be used as a reference, while in others it will be an average of the product prices on the market or even an average of the product prices in a basket of reference countries. Prices of drugs significantly drop in countries using this cost-containment policy.
Nevertheless, table 6 demonstrates that even when governments set maximum levels of reimbursement, strategies employed by pharmaceutical companies can differ. In Italy, companies will tend to bring their prices into line with the reference price. Even if generics are priced below that level, the average price difference is only EUR6.62.

Table 6: Impact of Reference Pricing on Drug Prices in Italy and Germany
 

Italy

Germany

Generic Pricing Policy

Price Cut

(average price difference above EUR6.62)

(average price difference above EUR20.52)

(average price difference below EUR7.98)

Number of Presentations

Sources: POLI, 2012
In Germany, with free pricing, competition is fierce, notably as a large number of pharmaceutical companies always compete for each genericised active ingredient. In order to incentivise pharmaceutical companies to lower prices, Germany has implemented a policy that cancels patients' co-payments for drugs priced at least 30% below the reference price. As demonstrated by an analysis of the prices and reference prices of drugs—for which the maximum level of reimbursement is set—this policy does not seem to stimulate pharmaceutical companies to lower prices significantly. Indeed, only 8% of the presentations for which a level of reimbursement is set are priced at least 30% below the reference price.
Reference prices are also set in France, although maximum levels of reimbursement are set for certain molecules only, when generic market share does not reach a certain level. Maximum levels of reimbursement are called TFR in France. When drugs are included in a TFR, prices drop significantly.
In this case, the majority of pharmaceutical companies simply bring their prices in line with the maximum level of reimbursement. On a basket of 5,006 presentations for which the level of reimbursement is set by the French government, representing 119 active ingredients, prices were brought into line with the reference price for 75% of them (source: POLI). Prices were set at a higher level for 21% of them, including off-patent drugs and generics, and prices were set below the reference price for only 3% of the presentations.

Market Exclusivity for Cheapest Generics

This policy has been implemented in a few countries: Sweden, the Netherlands, and Germany. It basically consists of granting a period of exclusivity to pharmaceutical companies providing the cheapest generic alternatives.
In Sweden, since 2002, it has been mandatory for pharmacists to provide patients with the cheapest alternative that month for each genericised active ingredient. Recently, pharmacists have also been allowed to substitute the second or third cheapest generic alternatives. Each month, the Dental and Pharmaceutical Benefits Agency (TLV) publishes a list of the cheapest alternatives on the market with the specific mention of the cheapest one, as well as the two other options for substitution.
A survey carried out by the TLV in 2006 already demonstrated that following the implementation of the substitution policy, drug prices have fallen 15%. It was reported that for certain genericised active ingredients—statins, for example—prices fell 70%. Even if this policy encourages competition, and as such lower prices, it nevertheless triggers stock issues because each month, and for each genericised active ingredient, the cheapest alternative might change. This is the reason the government has now enlarged the substitution to the second or third alternative, in case the first one is not available in the pharmacy.
In the Netherlands, since 2007, most insurers have introduced what is called the preference policy, with varying specificities. Some insurers launch a call for tenders and will reimburse their insurees for the product winning the bid, while some others do not use tendering but will reimburse the product with the lowest selling price, with other insurers leaving it to the pharmacists to provide this product or give another one. Preference policies, unlike in Sweden, are usually valid for several years, preventing pharmacists from issues linked to stock management.
Some insurers—usually small ones—do not use the preference policy in a bid to attract people as they will have the possibility to choose the drugs they want.
Achmea, the largest insurer in the Netherlands, has also launched what is called the Integrated Efficiency Contract of Excellence for Pharmacists (IDEA) model. Pharmacists can choose this policy, and in this case they are free to choose which drug to provide patients with and will receive a fixed reimbursement tariff per package, regardless of the brand provided. It has been reported that most pharmacists having contracts with Achmea choose the IDEA model. Indeed, this model encourages pharmacists to negotiate discounts strongly in a bid to increase their margin.
In Germany, since April 2007, each individual healthcare fund (the GKV, an umbrella term for approximately 170 individually run health funds) is legally bound to launch calls for tenders for each genericised active ingredient. The company winning the bid will enter into an agreement with the GKV fund. As such, for each GKV fund patients are enrolled to, pharmacists have to supply the drug from the company that won the bid. Despite the fact that this policy also enables a significant lowering of prices, it also leads to significant stock-management issues, with pharmacists having to stock the different brands that are in agreement with the different GKV funds for each active ingredient.

Outlook and Implications

As seen with the different policies mentioned in the report, governments rarely use one cost-containment policy in order to lower drug prices once generics enter the market. Governments commonly use a combination of at least two policies, often requiring prices to decrease by a certain percentage and setting the maximum level at which patients will be reimbursed.
Using pricing procedures differing from the ones used for innovative drugs enables governments to speed up generic market access.
In order to implement their pricing strategy, generic companies must take the following criteria into account in each country:
  • What are the pricing procedures in each country and how will they affect the prices of the originator drug and generics?
  • Are maximum levels of reimbursement used as a way to lower prices and what are the strategies commonly used by the different operators on the market?
  • What are the discounts that can be granted and is the country using an exclusivity period policy?
Those three elements are crucial to determine which pricing strategy to adopt in each pharmaceutical market. For instance, in Austria and Hungary, pharmaceutical companies must ensure to file their dossier for pricing and reimbursement as quickly as possible, because being one of the first generic companies to enter the market is a determinant factor. If not, generic companies usually do not attempt to enter those pharmaceutical markets.
There are also countries where pricing strategy does not leave room for manoeuvre for pharmaceutical companies' pricing strategies. This is the case in France, for instance, where the rule set by law must be implemented strictly and pharmaceutical companies cannot deviate from it. Prices of the different competitors for one active ingredient are brought into line. Still the number of generics competing for each genericised molecule is not limited, demonstrating that pharmaceutical companies have found other ways to compete. It is indeed well known that in France, large discounts are usually provided for generics (although the Chatel law limits those discounts to 17%), enabling competition.
Nevertheless, most countries use a price cuts of a certain percentage, leaving more room for pricing strategies. In those countries, the number of competitors on the market is usually large and price competition fierce.
Setting the maximum level at which patients are reimbursed is also largely used by governments. Although this policy allows the significant lowering of prices, the strategy used by pharmaceutical companies will differ on a country basis. For instance, in Germany, generic companies usually lower their prices below the reference price, while in Italy, most pharmaceutical companies will bring their prices into line with the reference price or above it, but will rarely go below this level.
Finally, the exclusivity period used as a cost-containment tool by three countries is a method that seems to be effective in lowering prices. In exchange for the lowest possible prices, a given pharmaceutical company will be given exclusivity and its generic must be given to patients, ensuring drug uptake. Sweden was the first country to implement this policy, followed by the Netherlands and Germany. Despite the fact that this method usually triggers stock-management issues, other countries might be willing to implement it as a means to lower prices further.
Full report in PDF format @1
Source: Global Insight

item.title: re: Update on the Exelixis' Overall Survival Trial with Cabozantinib for mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Update on the Exelixis' Overall Survival Trial with Cabozantinib for mCRPC 
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing the COMET-1 trial which will be conducted in the U.S to assess the effect of cabozantinib compared to prednisone on OS in men with previously treated mCRPC with bone-dominant disease who have experienced disease progression on docetaxel-containing chemotherapy and abiraterone or MDV3100. The company is intending to go out to a large number of sites (>250) in EU and Asia Pacific.  ...
Exelixis has announced the completed submission of a rolling NDA to the FDA for cabozantinib to treat medullary thyroid cancer, its lead indication. The company has requested a Priority Review. Exelixis, began the submission of the NDA in December.

item.title: Medivation and Astellas Sponsor Expanded Access Program for Enzalutamide (MDV-3100) in the U.S
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The expanded access treatment protocol is being conducted while marketing approval of the drug is being sought. The companies announced the NDA submission on May 21, 2012.
Recruitment: ongoing for men with mCRPC previously treated with docetaxel (no age requirement)
Particpating Sites: approx. 75 centers in the U.S.
Timing: The study will end if the drug is approved for sale to the public by the country's health authority (commercially available) or if the sponsor otherwise decides or is required to end the study.

item.title: Sun Pharm. Appoints Teva Former CEO as Chairman of the Board
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has announced the appointment of Israel Markov, who was instrumental in transforming Teva. We see this move as strategic of Sun's aspirations to transform into a global generic company, and to accelerate the integration of Taro (acquired in 2010).
  • - joined Teva in 1995 and led the company’s global expansion, managing over 12 acquisitions.
  • - under Mr Makov’s leadership, Teva became the global leader in generic pharmaceutical industry and a global leader for MS.
  • - holds a B.Sc. in Agriculture and M. Sc in Economics from the Hebrew University, Jerusalem.
In 2011, Sun Pharma and Merck announced the creation of Sun-MSD JV to develop, manufacture and commercialize new combinations and formulations of branded generics for the emerging markets (Please see PharmaWorld9261: Sun Pharma & Merck Form Partnership To Target Emerging Markets).

item.title: Update Status of Repros' Proellex(R) for Endometriosis and Uterine Fibroids (UF)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: FDA has requested an integrated safety analysis of completed studies of the oral anti-progestin prior to commence any additional trials. Repros plans to submit this document over the next few weeks, and expects to start Ph2/3 for endometriosis if allowed by the U.S agency.
Proellex(R)-V (vaginal delivery formulation) in Ph2
  • - Studied under a separate IND and not affected by the oral program.
  • - Enrollment of the ZPV-200 trial is nearing completion (planned for end of June).
  • - Subjects who complete the ZPV-200 study will be recruited into a one year open label safety trial in order to begin to build toward NDA safety.
Proellex(R) (oral formulation) in Ph2
  • Repros expects to complete and report the Ph2 results in Q4 2012.

item.content:encoded:
Comment: No new large competitor studies were presented at the WCNR - but two interesting Allergan sponsored spasticity trials were presensented by Theodore Wein (Montreal) who is a member of the Global Stroke Community Advisory Panel and George Sandrini (Italy) presented a study in PD patients with Xeomin.

item.title: ValiRx' Androgen Receptor-Derived VAL-201 to Enter Ph1 for PCa
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: VAL-201 has been shown to be highly effective against prostate and breast cancer cell lines and mouse xenografts. The life science company has started the regulatory filing process towards a ph1 trial application in the UK and Europe.
VAL-201 significantly inhibits the proliferation of aggressive tumours and decreases the spread and development of secondary tumours by up to 50% at projected therapeutic doses.
The latest studies have also shown a positive effect in the estrogen pathway in women, thereby providing good potential for the development of ovarian and breast cancer therapeutics. The compound also has shown efficacy as a potential treatment against endometriosis or hormone induced abnormal cell growth in women.

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to Agencia Efe, among the most affected are three hospitals from the Comunidad Valenciana, three from Andalucia and Castilla y Leon, and two from Leon La Mancha.
According to Agencia Efe:
  • Roche decided to impose stricter rules to 12 of the hospitals that were failing the most with payments across Spain.
  • Minister of Health Ana Mato announced the she will monitor supplies in the hospitals so as to make sure patients are not affected by drug shortages as a consequence of Roche's decision. Spanish hospitals are reported to have run up a debt of around EUR500 million (USD626 million) with Roche.
Despite the recent reforms announced by the Spanish government to tackle healthcare debt and reduce the debt in order to be able to review the situation and keep up to date with payments, Spain needs to engage in a stricter repayment plan with the regional councils in order to be able to cope. Although a new financial mechanism to avoid systemic breakdown has recently been announced in order to cope with payment delays to pharmacies and hospitals, this is still too recent to be able to assess its effects in the short-to-medium term. Roche's move is understandable from the perspective that at least 80% of Roche's revenues in Spain come from hospital supply.
Source: GlobalInsight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Dongkook Registers Octreotide In Peru
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Our partner Sanofi Peru has informed Ipsen that Dongkook has registered its octreotide 20mg formulation as a generic in Peru.
Thanks to Harold Dumont (Endocrinology Franchise Marketing) we have learnt that this generic product has already won some small tenders and that first experiences did not satisfy physicians expectations in terms of efficacy or safety.
At last year's CPHi meeting, it was noted that this 20mg formulation was under registration in Brazil and also expected to be launched in Mexico this year (see DKPHybrids77: Key Takeaways From CPhI Frankfurt October 2011).

item.title: Bid Speculation Circles Diabetes Company Amylin
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Shares in Amylin have leapt by over 8% as a report on Bloomberg claimed that both Sanofi and Merck have made initial takeover bids for the diabetes drug specialist that markets and manufactures the GLP-1 analogues Byetta and Bydureon.
Reportedly the offers on the table are at least $25 a share valuing the company at mmore than $4bn. Last month it was rumoured that Amylin rejected a bid from Bristol Myers Squibb of $22 a share.
BMS is expected to return with a higher offer and Takeda has also indicated that it may make a bid.
Source:www.bloomberg.com

Comments
As the auction for Amylin enters the last leg 5 companies are reported to be still interested in acquiring the company for a pirce tag of around $4.5bn. Interested parties reportedly include Novartis, Sanofi, BMS, Merck and AstraZeneca. Final bids are expected by the weekend.
Source: Rueters

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: ECE Intelligence Part 2 - Cushing's & NET & Pituitary Adenoma Data
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This second report from the recent ECE meeting highlights the growing interest in sub-clinical Cushing’s disease, a potential new treatment for CD in the form of Novartis’s LCI699 and some soft intelligence on its new Sandostatin LAR device. Also featured is radiopeptide targeting for neuroendocrine tumour visualisaiton, data demonstrating the increasing usage of temozolomide and some scientific data highlighting novel developments in pituitary adenomas and differences in internalisation between octreotide and pasireotide and somatoprim (Aspireo).
Sub-Clinical Cushing's Disease - Diagnosis and Risk Factor Implications
Novartis's POC Data With LC1699 in Cushing's Disease
LC1699 is a 11 beta-hydroxylase CYP11B1 inhibitor that Novartis acquired when it purchased. Speedel in 2008. It is a potential new treatment for all forms of Cushing's syndrome including Cushing's disease.
In the study all 12 patients achieved the primary endpoint at day 70 and 11/12 patients had normal urinary cortisol at day 70. Urinary cortisol returned to baseline within 2-weeks of the washout at the end of the study. Many were controlled with 20mg or less.
At the end of the presentation, the question of hypokalaemia was raised and whether these patients would need to take a concomitant therapy to control this. Dr Bertagia stated that it was something that was being considered but an alternative could be K+ supplementation. The possibility of hyperandrogenism in women associated with the increased testosterone was also queried but apparently no clinical evidence of hirsutism was seen in the 8 females includes in the study albeit the duration of the trial was very short.
Soft Intelligence Regarding New Sandostatin LAR Device
Gathered both at the congress and from Anna Jonasson (Business Unit Manager in Sweden).The new device will be introduced in Scandanavia this summer together with a handful of other markets and then elsewhere in all other international markets towards the year-end. Features of the new device include:-
  • A new diluent and vial adaptor
  • Not a pre-filled device but better than Novartis's current offering
  • Easier to mis with a shortened mixing time (5 mins)
  • A smaller needle gauge (21 gauge)
  • A smaller volume of injection 2 vs. 2.5 mls (useful it was claimed for thinner patients) - still intramuscular
  • A safety needle that can retract once used ( a button is pressed to retract the needle).
  • Price is expected to be the same.
New Developments In NET
Radiopeptide Targeting For Neuroendocrine tumour visualisation
The use of radiopeptide targeting for visualisation of neuroendocrine tumours is an area of increasing application. Emanuel Christ gave a very interesting presentation on GLP-1 imaging for localisation of pre-operative localisation of benign insulinomas
Growing Enthusiasm For Temozolomide
New Developments In Pituitary Adenoma - Cytokines & Other New Genes In Pituitary Adenoma (E Arzt Buenos Aires)
Eduardo presented data highlighting the role of BMP-4 in the proliferation of prolactinomas and corticotrophs. He noted that retinoic acid can be used to treat Cushing's disease and presented data showing how this acts via BMP4. He also highlighted a paper highlighting the interaction of SSAs with the BMP4 pathway and conclulded that BMP4 should be a new target for the treatment of pitutary adenomas.
In Vitro Comparison of The Activity of Octreotide & Pasireotide In GEP-NET (Novartis Sponsored Research)
One of the final symposia of this year's ECE meeting focused on somatostatin receptors in the pituitary. Schulz from the Institue for Pharmcologie Und Toxicology Jena University, highlighted research efforts to develop mAbs to detect SST2 and SST5 receptors in real-time which gives an idea of presence but not necessarily functionality. No photography was allowed during the session but there were some interesting observations. Namely that:-
  • All cells expressing GH expressed SST5 receptors but not all expressed SST2
  • All ACTH cell expressed SST5 but not SST2
Using a fret based probe to measure cAMP Schulz can identify cells which will respond to individual agonists. His work has also looked at phosphorylation of specific residues on the SST2 and SST5 receptors and shown that mutation can impede internalisation.
Phosphorylation of octreotide is similar to somatostatin but that of pasireotide is considerably less. Somatoprim (DG3173 Aspireo) looks like octreotide but it does have activity at the SST5 receptors similar to that of pasireotide. Schulz concluded therefore that Somatoprim has the combined activity of octreotide and pasireotide.
Interestingly in a recent clinical paper in the European Journal of Endocrinology, Ursulla Plockinger and co-workers demonstrated the activity of somatroprim (DG3173) in human GH secreting adenomas even in octreotide non-responsive tumours (see Endocrinology6725: Profile of A New Somatostatin Analogue DG3173).

item.title: Medicis Sued by Revance Therapeutics Over RT001 Agreement
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Bloomberg is reporting that Medicis is being sued by Revance Therapeutics for reneging on a 2007 buyout agreement tied to the development of its transdermal toxin RT001.
Revance officials contend in a Delaware Chancery Court Lawsuit that Medicis executives have refused to acknowledge that Revance has hit pre-specified development targets, covered by a 2007 agreement, that necessitate Medicis making a choice as to whether acquire Revance, pay a licensing fee for rights to the toxin or loose the option to either.
Revance lawyers are apparently claiming that by disputing the development target Medicis is effectively preventing Revance from raising critical investment funds or finding alternative partners.
Revance's claim is based on discussions with the FDA which earlier this month gaive Revance the authorisation to proceed to phIII evaluation of RT001.
That clearance should under the 2007 agreement have triggered Medicis’ obligations to decide whether it wanted to buy Revance, pay for an exclusive license to RT001 or allow Revance to seek out other partners.
Medicis officials have refused to make that call, demanding instead that Revance “engage in additional lengthy regulatory activities,” according to the suit.
Revance executives contend that Medicis officials are dragging their feet in honoring the agreement “in an attempt to starve Revance to the point that Medicis can obtain Revance’s technology for a bargain price,” the lawyers claim in the suit.
www.bloomberg.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: 1st Data Demonstrating A Potential Treatment Biomarker For Gastric Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Amgen has identified a potential predictive biomarker of response to treatment with Rilotumumab (AMG102) and is preparing to move into phIII development for advanced gastric cancer.
Analysis of a previously reported phII study of rilotumumab in patients with locally advanced or metastatic gastric or gastroesophageal cancer has shown that treatment in combination with chemotherapy improved median overal survival (OS) in patients whose tumours exhibited high MET expression.
The addition of rilotumumab to chemotherapy in patients with gastric tumors with high MET expression improved median OS from 5.7 months to 11.1 months (HR = 0.29, 95 percent CI, 0.11 - 0.76). Conversely, in patients with gastric tumors with low MET expression, the addition of rilotumumab to chemotherapy was associated with a trend towards unfavorable OS (HR = 1.84, 95 percent CI, 0.78 - 4.34).
These results have led Amgen to plan a Phase 3 study to confirm the efficacy of rilotumumab in advanced gastric and gastroesophageal cancer with high MET expression.
Rilotumumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody designed to inhibit hepartocyte growth factor /scallter factor (HGF/SF): MET pathway.
Full results of the biomarker study will be presented in an oral presentation at ASCO next weekend
source: www.amgen.com

item.title: Update on the Exelixis' Overall Survival Trial with Cabozantinib for mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing the COMET-1 trial which will be conducted in the U.S to assess the effect of cabozantinib compared to prednisone on OS in men with previously treated mCRPC with bone-dominant disease who have experienced disease progression on docetaxel-containing chemotherapy and abiraterone or MDV3100. The company is intending to go out to a large number of sites (>250) in EU and Asia Pacific.
Recruitment: approx. 960 participants
Start date: June 2012 - Completion date: March 2014

Comments
Exelixis has announced the completed submission of a rolling NDA to the FDA for cabozantinib to treat medullary thyroid cancer, its lead indication. The company has requested a Priority Review. Exelixis, began the submission of the NDA in December.

item.title: WCNR Intelligence Part 1 - Allergan's Spasticity Support Initiatives
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Thanks to Beth Elliott (CI Department) who was in attendance we have an extremely detailed and useful update on all these points.
Key Trial Information
Allergan apparently will proceed with a planned phase III Botox Cerebral Palsy trial in the USA and are in the process of starting recruitment. In addition, in planning is a multiple sclerosis patient trial focused on the treatment of lower limb (abductor) spasticity to improve ambulation.
Allergan’s Symposia
Entitled ‘Ensuring Quality Care and Support After Stroke: A World Stroke Campaign Symposia’.
Capacity in the hall was 500 with an expected 376 persons attending although on the day, the hall was only half full.
At no time during the symposia was Botox mentioned, rather the main objectives of the symposia as highlighted by John Olver in his introductory speech were to highlight: -
· The growing need to improve long term management of stroke (>3 months after stroke) through active involvement of all healthcare professionals involved in the care of stroke survivors – focusing on a multidisciplinary approach.
· To examine the role of sustained and customised rehabilitation in facilitating neurologic and functional recovery
· To discuss the clinical evidence supporting early and long term post stroke interventions
· To review procedures and tools, such as best practice guidelines and post stroke checklists that help ensure quality care and continued support for stroke survivors
· To raise a ‘call to action’ for improved long term stroke management
John Olver, also introduced the Advancing Care and Treatment of Long Term Stroke (ACT) Initiative which was borne from the Global Stroke Community Advisory Panel (GSCAP) that Allergan created and supports.
Note: This strategy of implementing a global advisory panel was also seen in Migraine.
The mission of this initiative is to improve the quality of long-term stroke management for stroke survivors living with post stroke complications through the implementation of advocacy and educational tools.
GSCAP is made up of a group of global, multidisciplinary experts
The key activities of the group to date are listed below. Along with the five review articles published, three more are in press and this same symposia will be presented at the World Stroke Congress in October 2012 (Brazil). The slide library will be distributed in the ‘very near future’. It is assumed that they will be available at www.strokecampaign.org
David Good’s talk on sustained and Customized Rehabilitation Maximises Brain Recovery focused on stroke impairments and implications, mechanisms and trajectory of brain injury and recovery, historical vs current thinking (residual capacity for neurologic recovery) and the potential role for customized and sustained rehabilitation in neurologic recovery.
He noted that 1/3 of stroke survivors still have moderate or severe impairment five years after stroke
Historically, we believe that most of the recovery seems to occur in the first 30 - 60 days and then plateaus after this. It is now clear that this belief is only partially true, recovery does happen early on but can also happen much later.
Various computational models of motor recovery have been defined with the goal of gaining insight into the concept of residual capacity and functional potential in stroke survivors. These models, if accurate have shown that brain networks may have greater capacity for post-stroke recovery, with estimates of up to 50%-80% potential residual capacity not previously realised. He suggested that if we can access/harness this, there are huge ramifications for latent rehabilitation.
There are a number of rehabilitation programmes available and these should be aimed at patients with residual capacity if possible.
Dr. Good then went on to discuss motor recovery potential and pyramidal tract damage followed by treatments which could aid in enhancing motor function in chronic stroke patients
The next speaker Katharina Sunnerhagen concentrated on evidence-based support for post stroke interventions. She reviewed the topics shown below and provided an evidence rating (low, moderate, strong) on the strength of data available. She highlighted that large amounts of data are available but is not being used effectively in daily practice.
Specifically for Botulinum Toxin, she presented the following:
She concluded the talk by stating the importance of a management plan for stroke rehabilitation, utlising the vast amounts of recent data that is currently under used
The penultimate talk by Anthony Ward entitled Processes and Tools Ensure Quality Care and Support After Stroke reviewed data from the stroke registries, highlighted rehabilitation unmet needs, and focused upon initiatives to improve long-term stroke management and the development and implementation of the Post Stroke Checklist (PSC).
He noted that whilst there are a number of ongoing stroke initiatives around the globe that there are no internationally accepted quality standards for longer-term post stroke management. Although, healthcare providers and stroke organisations are implementing strategies/guidelines which include references to longer-term stroke management, there is still a need to understand the patient review processes (in primary care and specialist centres).

This paved the way for the introduction of the PSC (generated by GSCAP), which addresses the issue of providing a continuum of care and patient reviews which are not wholly addressed in the strategies/guidelines .

The checklist is made up of 11 domains with one question attached to each domain. Depending on the answer, the practitioners will be directed down a clinical pathway (which may change from country to country). This checklist empowers the patient, allows the primary care team to know what they can do themselves and if they need to refer patients to more specialist centres. It takes 10-15 minutes to complete and will be available via mobile devices at a later stage.

The checklist will be carried out by the stroke survivor themselves at 3,6, 12 months and then annually thereafter. The patient will also be reminded to complete the checklist by their nurse/Doctor (at a later stage, mobile devices will remind the patient). Once the patient has completed the checklist, the nurse/Doctor will review the checklist with the patient to discuss if the issues are important enough to move forward on to specialist care.

During the pilot (UK, Singapore and other countries), the group also tested the value of the checklist with the patients and practitioners and have uncovered key leanings to date.

Speaking with Dr.Ward afterwards, Beth established that the checklist will be published in the autumn with the aim of getting it in as many journals as possible including Stroke, BMJ as well as local/regional community nurse/therapist magazines. They are aiming for the checklist to be launched around July 2013.

The final talk was by Prof Stephan Davis on behalf of the World Stroke Campaign introducing the 1 in 6 campaign. It has been translated in multiple languages and the aims and milestones are as follows:

Other Allergan activities during the congress:

Along with supporting the development of the PSC, it is clear Allergan wants to be ‘at the table’ when countries/stroke organisations are collating or updating guidelines. It held an invitation only European Delegates Meeting which was an informal group discussion led by Anthony Ward. The objective was to look at the implementation of evidence-based guidelines, compare the situation in the different countries of Europe and discuss proposals for a European strategy in neurological rehabilitation.
Anthony Ward started the discussion by showing a few slides on the various EU guidelines followed by a short talk by Prof. Heinrich Binder from Austria outlining the use and adaptation of guidelines for clinical practice in Europe. Once the talks concluded they held an open discussion on proposals for a European strategy in neurological rehabilitation. No consensus was reached but topics of the discussion revolved around what information is already available, what questions need to be asked, where and how to store the information. Dr. Ward then proposed that the 19 delegates in the audience become a ‘quasi think-tank’ to which he will type up the minutes of the meeting and will forward these to the delegates with other thoughts/opinions to which the think tank can act as a sound board.
In addition, Marion Walker from the UK is in talks with the WSO and supported by Allergan to introduce a European or International patients bill of rights.
Finally, it is understood that Allergan was in late stage discussions with an orthotics company but pulled out at the very last minute.

item.title: re: NCPE Ireland Rejects Zytiga for Reimbursement in Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
NCPE Ireland Rejects Zytiga for Reimbursement in Prostate Cancer 
Comment: Following a pharmacoeconomic evaluation completed on May 22nd, the National Centre for PharmacoEconomics (NCPE) believe that, at the submitted price, the drug is not cost-effective for patients with mCRPC who have received prior docetaxel-based chemotherapy. We assume that J&J might be forced to discount the price of Zytiga as it did after consultation with NICE.  ...
Since April 2012 J&J is in price negotiation with German health authority. Decision is awaited in Sept. J&J expresses incomprehension about the price comparison of Zytiga with chemotherapy. Until final price determining in Sept Zytiga is 100% reimbursed with a price of 5.449,91€. Total sales since launch (Oct 11 - Mar 12): 37,1 Mio € (source IMS data).
Claudia Schmczyk-Krüger

item.title: Allergan to Start Ph3 of Botox for Urinary Incontinence (UI) in MS Patients
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Allergan sponsored trial with Botox which will be conducted in approx. 184 patients with at least 3 episodes of UI over a 3-day period and a history of multiple sclerosis (MS). Primary endpoint will assess the number of UI episodes.

Start date: June 2012 - Completion date: May 2014/June 2015

Protocol: Botox will be administered into the detrusor at Day1. A second treatment, if applicable, will be administered at the earliest 12 weeks after the first treatment.

Locations: US; Belgium; Canada; Czech Rep.; France (Garches); Poland; Portugal; Russian Fed.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Publication Highlights Medy-Tox Prevalidation Test as an Alternative to LD50 Assay
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Medy-Tox performed a prevalidation of the compound muscle action potential (CMAP) assay to determine the potency of BoNT-A. Results published in the online version of Toxicon (2012 May 18) suggest that the assay is an alternative method to the LD50 potency test, and meets the requirement of the 3 R's (in particular Refinement and Reduction).
The rat CMAP test is straightforward, highly reproducible, and can directly determine the efficacy of toxin preparations through their inhibition of neuromuscular transmission. Thus, this method may be suitable for pharmacology studies and the quality control of toxin preparations (Kaketsuken; Toxicon 2010 Feb-Mar; 55(2-3):407-14 Epub2009 Sept 22).

The 3 R's are guiding principles for the use of animals in research.
  • Replacement: Alternative methods can be used that do not involve experiments on animals.
  • Reduction: The number of animals used for each test will be minimised.
  • Refinement: Animal distress (i.e. pain/discomfort) is minimised before, during and after the test.
Toxicon 2012 May 18 - http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22613167

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: NCPE Ireland Rejects Zytiga for Reimbursement in Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Following a pharmacoeconomic evaluation completed on May 22nd, the National Centre for PharmacoEconomics (NCPE) believe that, at the submitted price, the drug is not cost-effective for patients with mCRPC who have received prior docetaxel-based chemotherapy. We assume that J&J might be forced to discount the price of Zytiga as it did after consultation with NICE.
Background Please see Oncology8279: NICE Reverses Opinion And Agrees To Fund Zytiga Under the NHS.
In the economic submission, the cost effectiveness of Zytiga 1,000mg once daily in combination with prednisolone 10mg/day for the treatment of patients with mCRPC who have received prior docetaxel-based chemotherapy was considered. There were two comparator therapies included in the evaluation: prednisolone 10mg once daily, and a combination of mitoxantrone (12mg/sq m every three weeks) and prednisolone 10mg/day.
In the base-case analysis, the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) for Zytiga plus prednisolone versus prednisolone monotherapy was found to be EUR135,454 (USD172,945) per quality-adjusted life year (QALY), while the ICER for Zytiga plus prednisolone versus mitoxantrone plus prednisolone was EUR160,388 per QALY.
All ICER values, including those for a subgroup of patients who had received one prior chemotherapy regimen, exceed the cost-effectiveness threshold levels considered by the Irish Health Service Executive, i.e. EUR45,000 per QALY and EUR20,000 per QALY. Furthermore, the NCPE calculated that the treatment would have a cumulative budget impact of EUR9.84 million over the first 5 years.
Source: Global Insight

Comments
Since April 2012 J&J is in price negotiation with German health authority. Decision is awaited in Sept. J&J expresses incomprehension about the price comparison of Zytiga with chemotherapy. Until final price determining in Sept Zytiga is 100% reimbursed with a price of 5.449,91€. Total sales since launch (Oct 11 - Mar 12): 37,1 Mio € (source IMS data).
Claudia Schmczyk-Krüger

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New Trials of BOTOX for Ped. UL and LL Spasticity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Newly listed in clinicaltrials.gov, the four Ph3 trials will assess different units of IM injections of Botox in approx. 1,500 participants to be recruited in the U.S.
Study Details NCT01603602
Recruitment: approx 412
Completion dates: April 2015 / May 2015
Subjects will receive IM injection of BOTOX either 3U or 6U per kg of body weight into specified muscles of the upper limb.
Location: US
Study Details NCT01603615
Recruitment: approx 360
Startd date: Aug 2012 / Completion dates: Sept 2016
Subjects will receive intramuscular injections of botulinum toxin Type A into the upper limb muscles and/or lower limb muscles at a minimum of 12 weeks apart for a maximum of 5 treatments. Treatment dosing will be according to investigator judgment not to exceed a maximum of 10 U per kg of body weight (10 U/kg) per treatment.
Location: US
Study Details NCT01603628
Recruitment: approx 412
Start date: June 2012 / Completion date: MARCH 2016
Subjects will receive IM injection of BOTOX either 4U or 8U per kg of body weight into specified muscles of the lower limb
Location: US
Study Details NCT01603641
Recruitment: approx 350
Startd date: Aug 2012 / Completion date: July 2017
Subjects will receive intramuscular injections of botulinum toxin Type A into the lower limb muscles and/or upper limb muscles at a minimum of 12 weeks apart for a maximum of 5 treatments. Treatment dosing will be according to investigator judgment not to exceed a maximum of 10 U per kg of body weight (10 U/kg) per treatment.
Location: US

item.title: Dose-Titration Trial of Xeomin for Spasticity in the Leg and Arm
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph3, which purpose is to determine whether IM injections with increasing doses (from 400U to 800U) of Xeomin into muscles of the leg and/or arm are safe and effective. Primary endpoint will assess occurence of AEs.
Recruitment: approx. 150 participants with upper and lower limb spasticity of the same body side due to cerebral causes.
Start date: May 2012 - Completion date: March 2014
Design: prospective; open-label; non-randomized; single-arm; multi-center study.
Location: 5 sites in Gemany are currently recruiting.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Lilly's Once-weekly GLP-1 Analogue Reports Postive Cardiovascular Risk Data At Hypertension Meeting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lilly's has reported postive phII data in a non-inferiority study evaluating 24-hour blood pressure control of its invesitgational phIII once-weekly GLP-1 analogue Dulaglutide. The data was reported at the Annual American Society of Hypertension Meeting.
It was noted that cardiologists and hypertensions specialists are increasingly involved with evaluating the cardiovascular effects of diabetes medication.
Both dulaglutide doses evaluated in the phII study were shown to be non-inferior compared to placebo at week 16 for mean 24-hour SBP, which was the primary objective of the study. Since the NI criterion was satisfied, superiority testing was conducted, and the 1.5 mg dose demonstrated statistically significant reductions in mean 24-hour SBP compared to placebo.
  • Dulaglutide 0.75 mg: -1.07 mmHg (97.3% CI: -2.83, 0.68)
  • Dulaglutide 1.5 mg: -2.79 mmHg (97.3% CI: -4.58, -1.00)
Similar results were observed for comparisons at week 26.
The study also had several secondary objectives, including effects on mean 24-hour diastolic blood pressure (DBP, or pressure when the heart relaxes between beats) and mean 24-hour heart rate. For mean 24-hour DBP, the NI criterion (2.5 mmHg) was met for both dulaglutide doses compared to placebo at weeks 16 and 26.
For mean 24-hour heart rate, the 0.75 mg dulaglutide dose met the NI criterion (3 bpm) at both weeks 16 and 26 compared to placebo (1.62 bpm [97.3% CI: 0.32, 2.92] and 1.26 bpm [97.3% CI: -0.13, 2.64], respectively). The 1.5 mg dose did not meet the NI criterion at either week 16 (2.84 bpm [97.3% CI: 1.52, 4.16] or week 26 (3.50 bpm [97.3% CI: 2.10, 4.91]). This effect on heart rate is consistent with what has been observed for other compounds in the GLP-1 agonist class.
Both doses of dulaglutide demonstrated statistically significant reductions in HbA1c (average blood glucose levels over a three-month period) from baseline, compared to placebo, at weeks 16 and 26.

Both dulaglutide doses evaluated were shown to be non-inferior compared to placebo at week 16 for mean 24-hour SBP, which was the primary objective of the study. Since the NI criterion was satisfied, superiority testing was conducted, and the 1.5 mg dose demonstrated statistically significant reductions in mean 24-hour SBP compared to placebo.

  • Dulaglutide 0.75 mg: -1.07 mmHg (97.3% CI: -2.83, 0.68)
  • Dulaglutide 1.5 mg: -2.79 mmHg (97.3% CI: -4.58, -1.00)

Similar results were observed for comparisons at week 26.

The study also had several secondary objectives, including effects on mean 24-hour diastolic blood pressure (DBP, or pressure when the heart relaxes between beats) and mean 24-hour heart rate. For mean 24-hour DBP, the NI criterion (2.5 mmHg) was met for both dulaglutide doses compared to placebo at weeks 16 and 26.

For mean 24-hour heart rate, the 0.75 mg dulaglutide dose met the NI criterion (3 bpm) at both weeks 16 and 26 compared to placebo (1.62 bpm [97.3% CI: 0.32, 2.92] and 1.26 bpm [97.3% CI: -0.13, 2.64], respectively). The 1.5 mg dose did not meet the NI criterion at either week 16 (2.84 bpm [97.3% CI: 1.52, 4.16] or week 26 (3.50 bpm [97.3% CI: 2.10, 4.91]). This effect on heart rate is consistent with what has been observed for other compounds in the GLP-1 agonist class.

Both doses of dulaglutide demonstrated statistically significant reductions in HbA1c (average blood glucose levels over a three-month period) from baseline, compared to placebo, at weeks 16 and 26.

The most frequently reported adverse events were gastrointestinal (including diarrhea, nausea and vomiting). This is consistent with other GLP-1 agonists.

Source: www.lilly.com

source: www.lilly.com

item.content:encoded:
Astellas & Medivation Announce Format of The MDV3100 Presentations At ASCO 
Comment: Astellas & Medivation have jointly announced the data that will be presented at ASCO on MDV3100 either in oral, poster or during a symposium, which in addtion to more data from the AFFIRM trial will include data on neoadjuvant use in high risk localised prostate cancer, comparative phII data versus bicalutamide and phI breast cancer data.  ...
Comment: Astellas and Medivation have today announced that Medivation has filed an NDA for enzalutamide (formerly MDV3100) for the treatment of post-docetaxel CRPC, requesting a priority review. If granted the FDA goal for completing the review is six months.

item.title: Novel Oral Octreotide Formulation Receives US Patent
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Aegis Therapeutics has been awarded a new US patent providing broad protection for different pharmaceutical compositions of octreotide including oral, buccal and metered dose nasal spray formulations.
Patent No 8,133,863 covers highly stable octreotide formulations incorporating Aegis's Intrvail/Protek excipients. They stabilize, prevent aggregation and reduce unwanted immunogenicity of protein and peptide therapeutics while avoiding the oxidative damage caused by polysorbate surfactants currently found in manhy protein injectable drugs.
Back in April 2011 Aegis reported in a press release that scientists at Albany Medical College had demonstrated that the oral bioavailability of the Aegis formulation surpassed that of the injectable formulation in male Swiss webster mice. The research undertaken was published in the journal Regulatory Peptides (1)
Source: www.aegisthera.com
1)Regul Pept. 2011 Apr 11;167(2-3):233-8. Epub 2011 Feb 15

item.title: Lundbeck and CHDI Foundation Announce Research Collaboration
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lundbeck has announced a collaboration with an international network of scientists to investigate its preclinical candidate for Huntington's Disease.
CHDI is a privately funded biomedical research organisation that works with an international network of scientists to develop and discover new therapies for Huntington's disease.
The CHDI network will conduct preclinical studies with and investigative compound from Lundbeck evaluating its activity on P2X receptors, receptors that may be implicated in the development of Huntington's disease.
Source: lundbeck.com

item.title: Bavarian Nordic Announces PhII Data & Status of PhIII PROSTVAC Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Bavarian Nordic has announced positive interim data from a Phase II trial in 34 evaluable CRPC patients with bone metastases previously treated with docetaxel. It also noted that it expects to complete enrollment in its 1200 pt phIII PROSPECT trial in 2013.

PhII Study Data

ProstVac in combination with Quadramet (samrium based radioisotope used to control pain in patients with confirmed osteoblastic bone leisions) led to a PFS rate at 4 months, the primary endpoint, of 29.4% vs. 11.8% for Quadramet alone.

Median PFS was 117 days for ProstVac plus Quadramet vs. 60 days for Quadramet alone. Additionally, 4 of 17 patients receiving ProstVac plus Quadramet achieved a >

ProstVac plus Quadramet was well tolerated with a similar toxicity profile to that of Quadramet alone. The trial plans to enroll 68 patients to receive 1 mCi/kg IV Quadramet on day 8 and then every 12 weeks with or without ProstVac given on days 1, 15 and 29 and then every 4 weeks.

Bavarian Nordic also stated that it expects to complete enrollment in 2013 of about 1,200 patients with metastatic CRPC who have failed hormone therapy in the Phase III PROSPECT trial of ProstVac. This study will be the subject of a "Trials in Progress" abstract, at ASCO which is designed to provide an opportunity for members of the research community to present ongoing trials, foster collaboration, and discuss correlatives and novel trial designs.

Details of both studies to be presented are shown below:-

  • "Interim analysis of a phase 2 randomized clinical trial of Samarium-153 (Sm-153) with or without PSA-TRICOM vaccine in metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) after docetaxel", abstract number 2526, Poster Discussion Session, Developmental Therapeutics - Clinical Pharmacology and Immunotherapy from 8:00 AM to 12:00 PM CT on Saturday June 2, 2012.
  • "Prospect: A Randomized, Double-blind, Phase 3 Efficacy Trial of PROSTVAC®", abstract number TPS4699, General Poster Session, Genitourinary Cancer from 8:00 AM to 12:00 PM CT on Sunday June 3, 2012.
Bavarian Nordic will also be hosting a PROSTVAC® update and reception on Monday, June 4, 2012 in Chicago, Illinois. The principal investigators for the PROSPECT trial, James L. Gulley, M.D., Ph.D., Director of the Clinical Trials Group at the Laboratory of Tumor Immunology and Biology at the National Cancer Institute (NCI), and Philip Kantoff M.D., Professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School, will be joined by members of the Company's senior management team to discuss this next-generation prostate cancer vaccine.
source: www.bavarian-nordic.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New LHRH-targeted peptide Enters PhII Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Esperance Pharmaceuticals has announced the start of a phII multi-centre trial in patients with ovarian cancer with EP-100 , a targeted membrane-disrutping peptide (tMDP) designed to seek and destroy cancer cells that over-express LHRH receptors on their surface.
EP-100 is the lead candidate from Esperance's Cationic Lytic Peptide technology programme.
Hecto Alila , CEo claims that based on sucessful phI and preclinical studies, Esperance believes there is compelling rational for the study of EP-100 in ovarian cancer. Phase I results will be presented in poster form at ASCO Abs 3060. Results from preclinical studies it is claimed show that the drug can regress established tumours in breast, prostate, ovarian and endometrial cancer.
Study Design
The study will initially enrol 5-8 patients in a dose confirmation phase before expanding the cohort to 40 patients randomised in a 1:1 ration to receive either weekly doses of 80mg/m2 paclitaxel or the same regimen of paclitaxel plus twice weekly EP-100 for 3 of 4 weeks during each of six cycles.
Primary outcome will be objective response rate and secondary outcome measures QO, duration of response, time to progressoin and follow-up for survival.
Source; www.esperancepharma.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Express Scripts Survey Highlights Specialty Medicine Cost Concerns
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A large survey undertaken by Express Scripts of phamacy plan managers in the US, has found 36% of managers citing concerns about the growing cost of specialty medicines. Specialty drug spending in the US last year rose by 17.1% versus 2.7% for overall spending on medicines. It is suggested that programmes will be put in place over the next two years to contain such spending.
For employers with more than 25,000 members, 58% named specialty costs as their top worry.
Tim Wentworth from Express Scripts is reported on Reuters as saying that whilst specialty medicine spending makes up less that 30% of its clients overall drug spending it is the fastest growing component and something they want to look at ways of containing.
Seemingly the vast majority of survey respondents expect to institute programms that require members to try the lowest cost drug that is appropriate before starting on a new drug - so called step therapy - in the next two years.
Source: Reuters

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Prolor May Seek Partner to Market hGH-CTP
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Prolor has enough cash to conduct late-stage studies of hGH-CTP, in adults with growth-hormone deficiency as well as mid-stage testing in children President Shai Novik said
Novik also said that when you look at the marketing and sales channels, it would make much more sense, even if we develop it on our own, to partner with someone, at least for distribution and marketing purposes.
Bart Classen, an analyst at Summer Street Research Partners, said that any of the companies making short-acting hormone could be interested in buying them...there’s definitely a strong chance that the company will be acquired or partner up with a number of the larger companies who would have a natural interest in this product.
See also Endocrinology6930: Developments With Long-acting Growth Hormones
Source: Bloomberg 16 May 2012

item.title: USA: Allergan Announces R&D Expansion in New Jersey
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan will build a $12 million research and development facility in Bridgewater, New Jersey. reportedly to support expansion of indications for Botox like therapy.
Allergan has a smaller facility in Bedminster, where it employs 20 people. The new, 93,000-square-foot facility will bring nearly 400 new jobs to the state.
The company chose the site in New Jersey because of the local talent pool in the pharmaceutical and medical device industry, as well as its proximity to hospitals and universities, said spokeswoman Cathy Taylor.
The facility will be part of SJP Properties' Somerset Corporate Center campus, a series of energy-efficient office buildings in Bridgewater. Allergan first said it was considering expanding in New Jersey in November, when it was awarded a $14.9 million grant from the New Jersey Economic Development Authority through the Business Employment Incentive Program.
Star Ledger 17 May 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Unprecedented Abiraterone Data Released Ahead of ASCO
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Mary-Ellen Taplin at a press briefing yesterday announced that a phII study evaluating neoadjuvant abiraterone in patients with localized high-risk prostate cancer eliminated or nearly eliminated cancer in one-third of men after 6-months treatment.
She spoke at a press briefing that precedes the annual ASCO meeting, where the data is to be presented.
Specifically, 34% of men treated with abiraterone for 6 months had either pathological complete response (pCR; 3/29) or near pCR (7/29).
This was superior to the results in men treated with abiraterone for only 3 months. Only 15% of these men had either pCR (1/27) or near pCR (3/27).
All of the men in the study also received standard hormone therapy for 6 months and underwent prostatectomy after completing drug therapies.
The difference in response between the 2 study groups was not statistically significant, but the response rates among the men who received arbiraterone for six months are unprecedented, according to Dr Taplin the study's principal investigator. Essentially one third of the patients have minimal or no tumor when they go to the OR.
Historically pCR rates have been 5% or less with traditional hormone therapies when employed in the neoadjuvant setting and ofter in patients with localized disease of lesser risk than evaluated in the abiraterone study.
A randomized phase 3 trial that validates the current study findings is needed next but is not currently planned. Another phase II study investigating the novel androgen signaling inhibitor, MDV3100, in the neoadjuvant setting for high risk prostate cancer is underway and a clinical trial evaluating the addition of the investigational drug ARN509 to abiraterone and hormone therapy is being developed.
source: Medscape news

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Sanofi's Update on Lyxumia Its New GLP-1 Agonist
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sanofi has filed for approval of Lyxumia in the EU and will file for approval in the US in Q412. It is also claiming that it will be the first GLP-1 agonist so far and the only GLP-1 agonist that will have a cardiovascular outcomes trial demonstrating a perfect safety profile (a big question surrounding any new diabetes drugs).
Management claims that the drug has shown a consistent A1c reduction and weight loss, a pronounced effect on post-prandial glucose compared with Victoza (Novo Nordisk) and has a very favorable safety profile with a low-risk of hypoglycemic events.
Its administration also involves s a simple one-step injection with a pen device. This it was emphasised is viewed as important as healthcare reform goes forward. In view of the epidemic in diabetes patients, it is seen as important to make drug administration for diabetic patients simpler and simpler for the primary care physician to initiate and maintain therapy.
Sanofi will have three positive trials on top of basal insulin, a treatment paradign now very frequently used It is also developing a combination product that will allow vaiable dosing of Lantus (insulin) with a fixed dose of Lyxumia . This it was suggested represents a big opportunity as there are 8 million patients on Lantus or other basal insulins but in terms of being properly controlled the number is only 4 million. So, there is an opportunity for Lyxumia to improve control by bringing down A1c further.
