item.title: mTOR-Inhibitor TORISEL® Disappoints In PhIII Renal Cancer Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pfizer has announced that its Phase 3 INTORSECT study, evaluating the mTOR-inhibitor TORISEL® (temsirolimus) in patients with advanced renal cell carcinoma whose disease had progressed on or after SUTENT® (sunitinib malate) therapy, did not meet the primary endpoint of prolonging progression free survival when compared to sorafenib.

Although PFS was numerically higher in patients treated with temsirolimus, the difference was not statistically significant.

Moreover, overall survival, a secondary endpoint in the study, showed statistical significance favoring patients randomized to the sorafenib arm.

Adverse events in this study were consistent with the known safety profiles for both drugs. Full efficacy and safety data from this study will be presented at ASCO.

Despite this outcome Pfizer noted that :-

“TORISEL continues to be an important part of Pfizer’s portfolio of therapies for advanced kidney cancer. This trial advances our knowledge about TORISEL in RCC. TORISEL remains an important drug for treatment of advanced kidney cancer based on its pivotal study in first-line patients with poor prognostic risk,” said Dr. Mace Rothenberg, senior vice president of clinical development and medical affairs for Pfizer’s Oncology Business Unit.

Source: www.pfizer.com


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: NICE Reverses Opinion And Agrees To Fund Zytiga Under the NHS
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: After further consultation between NICE and J&J during which J&J has agreed a revised patient access scheme with the Department of Health which makes abiraterone (Zytiga) available at a discount price, NICE has agreed to recommend the use of the drug for the treatment of post-docetaxel CRPC.
The size of the discount has not been disclosed at the request of the manufacturer. The list price of abiraterone in the UK is £2,930 for a 30-day supply of 120 tablets.
Other Information Used By J&J During Negotations
Further information on a subgroup of patients that may receive the most benefit from the drug was also provided: patients who had previously been treated with one docetaxel-containing chemotherapy regimen. The manufacturer also submitted further information on the number of patients for whom abiraterone is licensed, enabling the drug to be considered under NICE's end of life criteria.
The draft guidance is now with consultees, who have the opportunity to appeal against it. Until NICE issues final guidance.
Source: www.nice.org.uk

Comments
On June 28th, NICE issued its final guidance recommending abiraterone (Zytiga, Janssen) in combination with prednisone for mCRPC post docetaxel.
Information provided by Janssen enabled the committee to recommend the drug for use on the NHS.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Developments With Long-acting Growth Hormones
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Within the last week both Prolor and Versatis have reported progress with the development of their long-acting hGH products. Prolor reported interim phII data at the ECE meeting and Versartis has announced the completion of enrollment in a 50 patient PhI trial.
Prolor has reported promising phII data demonstrating that once-weekly HGH-CTP leads to an average IGF-1 levels within the normal therapeutic range in 88% of patients at 4 months (n=42).
The phase II study is a randomised open-label comparative dose finding, safety, tolerabiltiy PK & PD trial conducted in adult GHD patients. Dose selection for phII of the study was based on IGF-1 levels during the initial 4-week stage I of the study. IGF-1 levels were measured during stage II every 2nd week on day 4 after injection.
Patients received once-weekly hGH-CTP at an initial dose containing 50% of the equivalent cummulative commercial dose that a patient would normally inject over the course of 7 days.
Given the potency observed Prolor believe that the drug MOD-4023 has the potential for twice monthly administration.
Next Steps
Vera Popovic (Serbia) who presented the data noted that a phIII adult study is in planning and will be initiated in September this year. It will include a follow-up period of between 6-18 months. The study will be undertaken in countries such as Hungary, Czech Republic, Slovenia and Slovakia.
Versatis has completed enrollment in a 50 patients double-blind placebo controlled international phI trial evaluating singel ascending doses of subcutaneous VRS-317.
Versatis has rights to develop VRS-317 from Amunix.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Savitex Gains Approval In A Further 10 Countries
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: GW Pharma and its partner Allmiral have announced that the mutual recognition process is now closed and they have received approval for Savitex to treat spasticity in a further 10 European countries.
Savitex is already available in the UK, Spain, Germany and Denmarkt and launches are currently in preparation for Italy, Sweden, Austria and the Czech Republic.
Closure of the mutual recognition process now means that approval has also been granted in Belguim, Finland, Iceland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal and Slovakia. Launches are expected in these countries from the end of 2012 onwards.
GW Pharma is due to report its interim figures for teh 6 months to March 31st on the 22nd May. Last reported sales as of November 2011 were £4.4m (see Neurology6111: GW Pharma Reports Strong Uptake Of Savitex For Spasticity).
Scource gwpharm.com

item.title: ECE Intelligence Part 1 - Key Data From The Novartis & Pfizer Satellite Symposium
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novartis’s Symposium “Taking The Next Step” provided a strong message about pasireotide’ s (Signifor) superior disease control in both Cushing’s disease and acromegaly against the background of a challenging treatment paradigm and unmet need despite current treatments. Hyperglycaemia was described but not discussed as an issue. Filing for 1st line treatment seems a certainty. Preliminary results in non-responders were not so impressive. Pfizer, by contrast, focused on metabolic control raising the question of why you would use a new drug like pasireotide when you can use a more established choice like Somavert that is not associated with glucose abnormalities.
Novartis Symposium
The symposium was chaired by Anna-Marie Calao and included presentations from Paolo Cappalanca (Naples), John Wass (Oxford) and Ilan Shimon (Israel) and was organised into two sections one focused on Cushing’s disease, the other on acromegaly.
The latter included the first detailed presentation (other than earlier that day) of Novartis’s phIII acromegaly data generated from one of the largest trials ever undertaken in such patients.
John Wass set the scene by highlighting some morbidity and mortality statistics from New Zealand which strongly suggest that tight biochemical control reduces mortality to the age adjusted norm
He noted how surgical expertise is critical to the success of transphenoidal surgery and how success rates with both surgical and medical therapy has improved over time but how there is still scope to do better in terms of biochemical control (data from the UK Acromegaly register)
John Wass emphasised how early open studies in patients previously treated with SSAs had shown a high level of control with octreotide LAR (up to 70%) but how in more recent studies which had included treatment naïve patients (including one with lanreotide treatment) lower levels of efficacy had been observed. Summarising he listed the variables that have affected outcomes in previously reported trials. And emphasised how an improvement in biochemical control rates is needed to increase life expectancy in acromegalic patients.
Anna-Marie Calao followed focusing initially on real-world levels of IGF-1 control with pegvisoment and combination therapy.
Details of the design and the results of the first pivotal phIII pasireotide study in acromegaly then followed. The primary endpoint of this study was to determine if pasireotide LAR s superior to octreotide LAR in providing full biochemical control.
The results in terms of primary endpoint are shown below both in post surgery and treatment naïve patients:-
As control of GH levels was similar it appears that it is the superior control of IGF-1 that leads to this overall superiority in terms of control as tumour volume control is also similar.
Then came the interesting point , the comparative safety profile. With the exception of hyperglycaemia safety data is similar to octreotide LAR but as the detailed fasting glucose data shown below shows treatment with pasireotide LAR does increase levels relative to baseline.
After the 12 month double-blind phase patients could switch therapies in an extended blinded 25 –week follow-up. Data from the first 19 weeks of this period was shown illustrating that 21% of patients previously uncontrolled on octreotide LAR achieved biochemical control when switched to pasireotide LAR compared to 2.6% switching from pasireotide LAR to octreotide LAR (see attached poster). Interestingly, high HBA1c levels reverted towards baseline levels on switching to octreotide
A second study in inadequately controlled acromegaly patients remains ongoing and is scheduled to complete in June 2013.
Anna-Maria summarised her presentation as shown below. When questioned about how best to deal with the hyperglycaemia, she suggested that data has shown that the addition of a DPP-IV inhibitor or GLP-1 analogue is the best solution but that metformin could also have some efficacy.
She was also asked if one had a new patient with acromegaly what should one prescribe as a first-line therapy. She hesitated and then suggested that given the 20-years experience with octreotide LAR that this is still likely to be very helpful for many patients but that pasireotide does look to be the more powerful drug. She added if could manage the diabetes then I would go for pasireotide. So for now she concluded one should start with experience but as time goes by she believes more will use pasiroetide as experience grows.
Finally when questioned post the event Ilan Shimon stated that Novartis was likely to file for 1st line usage given the superiority shown and the no of de novo patients included in the trial. His expectation was that approval is likely to be similar in terms of label to that of the recently approved Cushing’s disease indication i.e. for whom surgery is not an option or for whom surgery has failed.
Turning to the other presentations, this time on Cushing’s disease, these similarly focused on the challenges, comorbidities and unmet need before highlighting some case studies illustrating the benefit of pasireotide therapy and the outcome of the phIII pasireotide trial presented last year at the Pituitary Meeting and ENDO.
Some of the key slides shown are highlighted below:-
The CI Department would like to acknowledge the valued input of Antoine Clermont (Medical Advisor Endocrinology Franchise) in helping to compile this report on Novartis's PhIII data.
Pfizer Symposium
Pfizer’s symposium was well attended and focused largely on the metabolic consequences of medical treatment of acromegaly. It was co-cjaired by Ezio Ghigo (Turin) and Christian Strasburger (Berlin).
Ken Ho (Brisbaine) focused on the metabolic perturbations of acromegaly concluding the following points as shown:-
Whilst Philippe Chanson (Paris) gave an interesting presentation on body composition changes associated with the treatment of acromegaly both in terms of the reduction in extracellular fluid and the positive impact on various co-morbidities and changes in fat and lipid metabolism.
One of the key sessions of the symposia, however, was that given by William Drake (Barts UK) which included a powerful slide showing the impact of diabetes on acromegalic mortality. He reviewed various sets of data including a meta-analysis demonstrating the overall lack of impact of SSA therapy on glucose metabolism plus data showing that pegvisoment improves glycaemic control and could be particularly beneficial for patients with diabetic acromegaly. He then turned his attention to pasiroetide, noting its potential to be diabetogenic and suggesting that this aspect of the drug’s profile needs further evaluation.
.

item.title: Merz Starts Negotiations to Acquier Pierre Fabre's Filler
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: With the prospective transaction, kicked-off on May 9th, Merz intends to acquire Glytone(R) filler range. Following the acquisition of BioForm Medical in 2010, this new project would further advance Merz' strategy in aesthetics.
Merz would become the owner to the WW rights to the Glyton(R) hyaluronic acid fillers and to the rights outside the USA for the brand`s other products.
Glytone® was acquired by Pierre Fabre in the U.S in 2002 and launched in E.U in 2008.
It includes:
- a complete range of products of dermatological dispensing sold mainly in the U.S
- professional products used in aesthetic dermatology - glycolic acid peels, injectables with acid hyaluronique used for the filling of wrinkles and the repulpage of lips - sold exclusively outside the U.S

item.title: Takeda Mid-Range Plan Includes Approval of TAK-700 in All Geographic Regions
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On Friday Takeda announced details of its mid-range plan FY12-14, highlighting the significant R&D effort underway in six different therapeutic areas, the greatest investment being in oncology and cardiovascular/metabolic medicine. Recruitment to its two phIII trials with TAK-700 in CRPC will be complete this year, with the company now anticipating approval in FY2014. Meanwhile, from a LCM perspective, Takeda is developing a 6M formulation of Lupron for prostate and breast cancer in Japan.
Development Status Of Other Products Of Note

item.title: Astellas - FY2011 Results - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Astellas reported modest FY sales growth of +1.6% but with reduced R&D expenses operating income up 10.4%. A filing for MDV3100 in the post-decetaxel CPRC setting will be made this month.
Sales of its main urology products grew by +3.8%, whilst Eligard in Europe registerd a similar increase to generated €127m.
Geographically sales in emerging markets accounted for 6% of consolidated sales and continue to generate strong growth +14% YOY ex forex. Astellas is continuing to expand its business in China and Russia.
Management highlighted some key milestones in 2011, which included:
  • the August 2011 of the group's new iOAB drug Mirabegron:
  • the NDA filing of Eligard in Asian Countries;
  • the favourable results for MDV3100 from the AFFIRM CRPC post docetaxel trial NDA/MAA filing for which is in preparation and will be filed this month and next with a priority reveiw sought in the US; and
  • the favourable results for tivozanib in the TIVO-1 renal cell cancer study, the NDA/MAA for which is also in preparation.
Enrollment in the PREVAIL pre-chemotherapy trial should complete this month apart from in a few select Asian centres. Whether the study will report out at the interim stage remains to be seen as it has a co-primary endpoint of PFS and OS, the event rate for which is being independently monitored.
On June 6th, Medivation and Astellas announced the completion of 1,680 patients in the PREVAIL (pre-chemo) trial apart in a few Asian centres, to gain additional information on this specific population.
Additionally, management announced plans to host an R&D Meeting on its oncology pipeline on July11 th in Japan.

item.title: GSK to Test Botox for Strabismus in Japan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph3 trial will evaluate the efficacy of single-dose injection (1.25U or 2.5U) with GSK1358820 (Botox). Primary outcome will assess change from baseline in strabismus angle.

Secondary objective is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of repeated-dose treatment with GSK1358820 in patients with strabismus.

Start date: May 2012 - Completion: May/Nov. 2013
Recruitment: approx. 66
In 2005 GSK and Allergan entered into Botox deal for Japan and China.

item.title: New Designs for Pre-filled Syringe to be Patented
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Revolutions Medical, a company mainly engaged in the design and development of retractable safety needle devices, has filed an international patent application under the Patent Cooperation Treaty (PCT) directed to novel proprietary designs for pre-filled and non-pre-filled vacuum based retractable syringes.
Advantages: improve safety and ease of use; reduce the cost and complexity of manufacturing (with Yeso-med in China).
October 1999 - a report released by the Emergency Care Research Institute (ECRI) entitled “Sharps Safety and Needlestick Prevention”, found that all of the safety syringes offered by the major syringe companies have significant limitations or are not acceptable as safety devices.
In its Feb.20 2011 report, Frost and Sullivan listed 9 companies offering safety syringes
For company information, please visit http://www.revolutionsmedical.com/

item.title: Exelixis's Development Plans For Cabozantinib Highlighted At The Deutsche H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Exelixis noted that it has three phIII trials in medullary thyroid cancer with cabozantinib winding down and plans to submit a rolling submission later this quarter. Two pivotal tirals in prostate cancer are also ongoing but a number of combination studies with key products such as abiraterone and MDV3100 are planned with a view to facilitating development in earlier treatment settings.
Medullary Thyroid Data
Cabozantinib has demonstrated a nearly threefold increase, improvement in progression-free survival over placebo with a hazard ratio of 2.8, a highly statistically significant outcome. The full dataset from these trials will be presented in a oral presentation at ASCO next month.
Prostate Cancer
One study, preliminary data with which was reported late last yearm, that will be updated at ASCO this year is a low-dose study run by Dr. Matthew Smith at Mass General in Boston. That study is investigating starting doses of cabo at 40 milligrams and 20 milligrams, using bone scan response as the initial sign of activity, but then following out for other markers of activity as well.
Exelixis is claiming that these data are critically important to its prostate cancer program for two reasons. One, it's helping to qualify the initial starting dose for the pivotal COMET trials, but it also may potentially facilitate the company's ability to move into earlier lines of therapy in prostate cancer as well as in combination.
In terms of combination studies, Exelixis recently announced two combination studies with cabozantinib, one with Abiraterone and the second with Taxotere. This week it also announced that it is in discussions to do a combination study with MDV3100. It views these trials as critically important to move beyond the metastatic setting into earlier lines of therapy as well. Additionally, it noted that it also has ISTs looking at various other areas; one in particular is looking at bone mets associated with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.
From https://www.exelixis.com, see original source.

item.title: NICE Maintains its Decision Not to Approve Jevtana(R)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NICE's decision not to recommend this drug means that men in England with advanced prostate cancer have to access it through the Cancer Drugs Fund.
See Oncology8065: J&J's Zytiga (abiraterone) Too Expensive for National Health Service (NHS).
Prostate cancer patients, their families and charities are now waiting for NICE to issue their decision on abiraterone, which is due imminently.

item.title: Theratechnologies' Second Generation GRF Peptide Enters PC Phase
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to the company, TH1173 exhibits superior pharmaceutical properties than tesamorelin. It is a shorter peptide with better physical and chemical stability. FIM is planned in Q1 2013. Potential future indication could include growth hormone replacement in growth hormone deficient patient populations.
Bioavailability
Combined with the company's internally discovered formulations, the drug bioavailability could be improved from 5% to 95%.
Administration
Dr. Krishna Peri, VP, Research, noted that studies have confirmed the potential for sub-cutaneous administration, as well as non-invasive delivery of TH1173 via nasal and dermal routes.
Patent
A patent application is currently pending and, if granted, will provide protection beyond 2030.
  • - treatment of abdominal obesity in growth-hormone deficient patients,
  • - muscle wasting related to certain chronic diseases
  • - mild cognitive impairment
  • - growth hormone replacement in growth hormone deficient patient populations
TH1173 is unpartnered and wholly-owned by Theratechnologies.

Comments
The US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) has granted a patent for the drug, providing for patent protection >2030. Of note, TH1173 is unpartnered.
Drug Clinical Program
The PC phase is completed. Results, including those from 7-day and 28-day toxicology trials, warrent the pursuit of clinical stage.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Bayer to Evaluate Influence Treatment with Visanne on the Endometriosis Related QoL
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The data will be collected using a special patient questionnaire (Endometriosis Health Profile 5, EHP-5). Primary outcome measures will assess percentage of patients who show an improvement of the EHP-5 items, and mean changes of EHP-5 items. Many locations in Ukraine and the Russian Federation have been selected to recruit approx. 3000 women having endometriosis related pain as leading symptom.
Start date: May 2012 - Completion: June 2014
The study will also:

- be used to describe the basic disease status and demographic characteristics of patients searching treatment by a gynecologist because of their endometriosis.

- give insight into the typical diagnostic measures the physicians in different countries are using in the field of endometriosis.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: BMS Highlights Immuno-oncology Programme at Deutsche Bank H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a rare expose of its exploratory pipeline, Francis Cuss Senior VP R&D presented an update on the portfolio, highlighting what it sees as the gem amongst the early portfolio namely anti PD-1. A signficant amount of new data on this drug will be forthcoming at ASCO, including data on its use to treat renal cancer. Comments on the use of Sprycil in CRPC and phIII data with Brivanib in HCC in 2H12 were also of interest.
Francis Cuss noted:-
"We have a large pre-clinical through to Phase II portfolio which has about doubled in size over the last five or six years. But as I said, it's not just about the numbers; it's about the quality. Of course today, I don't have enough time to go into detail here, but I would like to focus on a couple of areas that we think are particularly interesting, which we believe will have an impact over the next few years in terms of our pipeline, our Phase III pipeline. The first area is immuno-oncology. I think it's fair to say we believe we are leaders in this area with the approval and marketing of YERVOY. We believe we lead, certainly in terms of the area, expanding it beyond malignant melanoma with Phase III studies, life-cycle managed studies, ongoing (including CRPC)."
But we also have behind that a whole series of different assets looking at different aspects of immuno-oncology.... Anti-PD1, PD-L1 is a pathway – another inhibitory pathway. The CTLA-4 pathway is one inhibitory pathway that cancer cells use to stop the immune system getting rid of them. PD1/PD-L1 is another one. And we are very excited about this particular pathway. We will be presenting data at ASCO in June not just in malignant melanoma , but also in renal cell carcinoma and non-small cell lung cancer.
"There've been traditionally those tumors which have been considered immunogenic like malignant melanoma (sic) [myeloma] (8:07), but others which haven't like non-small cell lung, and we believe we're extending with PD1 the opportunities into more tumor types. Beyond these individuals as monotherapy, we also have a longer-term aspirational goal to find ways to put these drugs together to further enhance response rates. We know pre-clinically that ipilimumab and PD1 synergize, and we have ongoing studies in the clinic to see whether that is reproduced."
With regard to SPRYCEL he commented:-
the hope will be here that we will show significant benefit. We do believe with SPRYCEL because of its profile and SARC activity and its bone activity that we will actually be showing significant benefit after hormonal failures. But that's probably, I think, about 18 months away before we will see that. That's ongoing. There's certainly a good pre-clinical reason to expect it might have benefit, but of course as always it'll be heavily dependent on the data.
From http://www.bms.com, see original source.

item.title: Medicis's Comments About The US Facial Aesthetics Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During its quarterly earnings call, Medicis made a number of positive comments about the uptake of Dysport and the outlook for facial aesthetic sales which are highlighted below.
It noted that total revenues for facial aesthetic products grew by 6% during the quarter, with Dysport experiencing its strongest first quarter demand since the product was launched (+8% in units sold).
Responding to a question about promotional levels and the profitability of Dysport, Jonah Shacknai, noted:-

"Well, it's actually been pretty flat to slightly up. And I think given the fact that the market was deluged with free samples of competitive products, particularly the Merz product, it's actually pretty good. I might add that the brand was more profitable this quarter than in quarters previously, I think reflecting our promotional mix as well as customer mix. So I think we're pretty pleased with the way Dysport is doing, it's a highly established product, highly recognized.

We just returned from one of the major aesthetic plastic surgery meetings held in Vancouver, Canada, just got back. And it's clear that Dysport and its competitor Botox are really the two established, well-regarded brands. And then really others are not predicted to play a significant role in the market. So I think that's pretty good news and obviously we are intensifying our promotional activity in the field. I think customers understand we're a great company to do business with, both because of Dysport and the Restylane family, and we continue to charge forward.
He went onto note:-
"I think the legal difficulties that at least one company has faced certainly curtail their promotional activities until the end of an injunction, basically. And we'll have to see what their plan is coming back from that. It's obviously a very, very challenging position to be in for them."
Source: Medicis Q1 Earnings Transcript

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Breakthrough Drugs May Find Pathway To US Approval Becomes Easier
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Reuters is reporting that the US may speed up the approval of breakthrough drugs as part of the new FDA user fee bill necessitating shorter or fewer trials to gain approval.
The proposal suggests that experimental drugs that show a big effect in early developmental trials for treating serious or life-threatening conditions should get a faster and cheaper path to US appproval.
Similar comments with reference to the EMA's position were recently raised at a Bioindustry Association meeting in London (see PharmaWorld9866: A Potentially New Adaptive Development Programme For Innovative Drugs).
Dr Janet Woodcock, Head of the FDA's Drug Division is quoted ass saying that the FDA nees more flexibility to bypass "business as usual" when it sees unepected effects or when a new medicine can substantially help patients

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Takeaways from Medivation's Q2 2012 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside its financial results, the company indicated that the purpose of its recent meeting with the FDA was to discuss the post-chemo NDA that it will be filing with enzalutamide (formerly MDV3100). In addition, Management reported it has a clear strategy for registration in Japan in pre and post chemo settings. When it comes to the breast cancer indication (Ph1 ongoing), it was highlighted that the patient population are women who have failed prior hormone therapy.
Regarding the sales reps, Cheryl Cohen (CCO) outlined that the company is recruting and 'just getting top-quality candidates in the oncology space'.
As this trial is operationalized by Astellas, the company does not have control over the timeline, and no guidance to provide at this point of time.
This PREVAIL trial will be used as a global registration study in the chemo-naïve population, and according to L. Seely (CMO) that includes 'registration in Japan'.
"In the post-chemotherapy space, we do have a bridging study ongoing in Japan in the post-chemotherapy population. And so we have an opportunity to discuss with Japanese authorities the combination of the AFFIRM study and the bridging study. So there is a strategy there as well".
During the quarter, Medivation initiated a Ph1 study evaluating the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetics of enzalutamide in combination with docetaxel in approx. 18 men with advanced prostate cancer.
Management indicated that "... When we talk about sequencing, we are crystal clear that the number one drug in the sequential is enzalutamide. So that is the foundational treatment you will see moving forward. And then there are a number of combinations which are of great interest to the medical community with MDV3100 as the foundational therapy. So I do suspect you will be seeing other combinations in that regard. But today we are just announcing that there is a docetaxel combination study, and that largely is because we expect to have approval in the post-chemotherapy space, and we expect to get approval in the chemo-naive space when that PREVAIL data are there. And this will just provide the data to continue to dose MDV3100 -- or enzalutamide through chemotherapy.
Expected Events
Clinical Pipeline

  2. ScreenCapture2.jpg  (55,9 KB)

item.title: Novartis Presents PhIII Acromegaly Data At ECE Meeting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novartis has reported final results from its first phIII trial of pasireotide in acromegaly at the ECE meeting in Florence, demonstrating that the drug is more efficacious than Sandostatin LAR in terms of achieving biochemical control of acromegaly. This was anticipated (see Endocrinology6875: 1st Indication of Pasireotide Results In Acromegaly & NET) as was the high incidence of diabetogenic side effects also reported.
Top-line Findings
1) The study, the largest underataken in an acromegaly population, met its primary endpoint demonstrating that significantly more patients treated with pasireotide (31.3% of patients experienced full control of their disease (defined as the combination of both GH <2.3ug/l and age and sex matched normalised IGF-1) than those taking octreotide LAR (19.2%) (p= 0.007).
2) The level of GH control was similar to Sandostatin LAR but control of IGF-1 was better leading to the overall improved response profile.
3) Tumour control was similar with both agents.
4) In terms of adverse events the drug was reasonably well tolerated with the exception of hyperglycaemia which occurred in 28.7% of patients in the double-blind randomised phase of the study compared to 8.3% with Sandostatin LAR.
Results from an extension phase of the study out to 19 weeks were also reported.
Full Report To Follow
Full results of the trial and the manner in which it was presented by Novartis during its satellite symposium will be reviewed in full in an upcoming report from the congress. Suffice to say that the focus was on highlighting the unmet need that exists for new agents given the level of control achieved with existing SSA is only "20 to 25% in patients naive to previous SSA therapy."
Signifor (pasireotide) was approved two weeks ago by the EMA for the treatment of Cuhsing's disease but Novartis has yet to file for approval of the acromegaly indication. It has a further phIII switch trial that is ongoing. Regulatory submissions are slated for this year but the precise timing was not disclosed.
Scource: ECE meeting Florence & novartis.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Virtual Reality-Based Cystoscopy Simulator for Urologists Injecting BOTOX® for nOAB
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Touch of Life Technologies' Cytoscopy Simulator was developed to support Allergan's commitment to educate and train urologists on the proper technique for injecting BOTOX® to treat incontinence in adults with nOAB.
ToLTech products are based on realistic visualizations from the National Library of Medicine's Visible Human Project® and next generation data.
The newest product is a Cystoscopy Simulator to train urologists to inject medication in the bladder wall to treat incontinence for certain patients.
Characteristics
... "The cystoscopy and injection trainer manipulates image data to simulate the look and feel of a human bladder so that the physician/user actually 'feels' the resistance to the needle as it penetrates the detrusor muscle of the bladder wall," said Vic Spitzer, CEO of ToLTech. "The bladder is the proper volume and is inflated to the appropriate wall tension that would exist in candidates for this procedure ...".
From http://www.toltech.net/index.htm
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (37,2 KB)

item.title: Sandoz Supports FDA's Draft Guidance on Biosimilars
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dr. Mark McCamish, Head of Global Biopharmaceutical Dev., will present at the May 11 FDA public hearing on draft guidances related to the development of biosimilar products. His message will focus on
  • One science-based standard for all biologics.
  • Biosimilar clinical studies are only confirmatory
  • Interchangeability
Dr McCamish will highlight a recent study conducted by the IGES Institute in Berlin, which showed that by 2020, 8 countries in the EU could save a cumulative total of between EUR 11.8 billion and 33.4 billion through the use of biosimilar medicines.
  • Novo Nordisk, Genentech and Amgen have expressed concerns with 39 companies as of April 17th having commented on the guidance.
  • Some such as Teva are in favour of the new guidance.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: FDA Lifts Hold on GTx' Capesaris for Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company will test the drug as a secondary treatment for patients who have not responded to initial treatment.
The company plans to start a mid-stage trial during Q3 2012. It will test 3 lower doses of Capesaris in 75 men with mCRPC.
See Oncology8214: GTx Strives To Move Forward With Capesaris Development.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: No Earnings Growth Till 2014 for Actelion
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has forecast flat core earnings in 2012, and reports that new medicines and cost cuts would take time to offset falling sales of Tracleer (for PAH), the drug that brings in most of its revenue.
Actelion's priority is to expand its leadership in the market for treating PAH, with Macitentan and Selexipag.
Actelion will refocus its future R&D activities towards specialty markets. Actelion's current clinical pipeline in immunomodulation and antibiotics provides the company with an opportunity to build a second specialty business franchise.
Refocusing of Actelion's research and development efforts into specialty areas is expected to result in lower and more targeted R&D spending, as well as lower overhead costs.

  2. ScreenCapture2.jpg  (51,8 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Almirall Heavily Criticises Spanish Government's Pharma Cuts
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Almirall's president Jorge Gallardo disclosed in a recent press conference that the pharma cuts undertaken by the government will negatively impact on the country's industry and cost it EUR5 billion (USD6.5 billion) in the short term. According to Gallardo, cited by El Economista, these "short-term policies" will lead to many pharmaceutical companies in the country closing down due to a lack of resources.
Gallardo's overview on the future of the Spanish pharmaceutical industry seems to paint a realistic picture of the industry's situation in the country, given the further cuts in healthcare and pharma recently announced by the government and the protests triggered by them. The Spanish government recently announced a further EUR2 billion in cuts to healthcare and pharma for 2012, cuts that will mostly affect the pharma industry given the fact that austerity measures aimed at cutting drug spending are expected to remain in place.
From: GlobalInsight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan's Model of Success
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In an interview in 'Life Science Leader' magazine . David Pyott, president and CEO, attributes some of Allergan's growth to the company's extreme success at securing a high proportion of regulatory approvals around the globe. Pyott says that success is due to three things: Allergan's business model, expertise through specialization, and an enormous attention to detail.
The full interview can be seen at: http://lifescienceleadermag.epubxp.com/issue/63926/17
Source: Life Science Leader May 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Dendreon Reports Modest Quarter Growth of Provenge
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Q1 sales of the prostate cancer vaccine rose 6.5% versus the prior quarter. The company expects Q2 sales to still grow by low single digits.
Dendreon reported it was encouraged by growth in large community urology and oncology accounts, and sait 84 new accounts used Provenge in the first quarter.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Botox Assessed as Potential Therapy for Low Anterior Resection Syndrome (LARS)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan, in collaboration with the Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM) will start a POC trial in approx. 23 participants diagnosed with LARS, for which current treatments are often ineffective. Primary endpoint will evaluate efficacy of intra-rectal (or intra-colic) injection of 100U of Botox.
Completion date: March 2013 / August 2013
Location: Canada
LARS is frequent after treatment for low rectal cancer. Increased bowel frequency and urgency with rectal spasms and incontinence have deleterious impacts on QoL in a third of the cases.

One possible physiopathology hypothesis suggests an ongoing spastic process; different mechanisms have been postulated. These include alteration of normal anorectal sensation with loss of the recto-anal inhibitory reflex (RAIR), decreased rectal compliance and reduced rectal capacity as well as sphincter damage secondary to preoperative chemoradiation therapy or during surgery.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Erythropoietin Tested as a Potential Therapy for Cerebral Palsy (CP)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: LG LifeSciences in collaboration with Minyoun Kim (M.D) has started a Ph1 clinical research for children with CP. Primary endpoints will assess safety.
Recruitment: approx. 10 (6 months to 3 years)
Start date: March 2012 - Completion date: May 2012
Location: Korea
Many experimental animal studies have revealed that erythropoietin is useful to repair neurological injury in brain. The main mechanism of erythropoietin is supposed as follows; neuroprotection effect, angiogenesis, and anti-inflammation

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Update on Cabozantinib Timelines for Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside the results of Q1 2012, management gave an updated overview of the COMET program, and highlighted that Dr Smith's Investigator Sponsored Trial (IST), evaluating cabozantinib at lower doses, could support the use of the drug in earlier lines of therapy or in combination with other compounds for CRPC. Combination studies with abiraterone and MDV3100, included in the cabozantinib development programs, are progressing well.
COMET-2, with a focus on pain palliation came online in December.
Management reported it expects to initiate COMET-1, the overall survival trial in CRPC, in Q2 2012. "If these trials are successful, cabozantinib will demonstrate an ability to control pain in patients with CRPC, and prolong overall survival".
When questioned on enrollment and timelines of COMET-1, management answered it hopes to complete the enrollment in about one year. "We are intending to go out to a large number of sites, up to 250 sites in various different parts of the world including Europe, the U.S., Asia-Pacific".
When it comes to IST, management reported that a new Phase 2 IST has been initiated in chemotherapy naive patients with CRPC.
Management looks forward to the initiation of multiple combination studies with cabozantinib, including the recently announced combination studies with docetaxel and with Abiraterone. The company is also planning a Ph1 trial of cabozantinib in combination with MDV3100.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: J&J Starts Development Of Abiraterone For The Chinese Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: ClinicalTrials.gov is listing a new J&J sponsored trial with abiraterone in China which will be conducted in 290 patients with chemonaive metastatic CRPC. The trial commenced in March.
The trial highlights J&J's strategic intent to enter the Chinese market with abiraterone (Zytiga).
The study will be undertaken in 6 Chinese centres in the cities of Beijing, Guangzhou, Hangzhou, Jinan, Tianjin, and Wuhan. An additional 3 centres in Malaysia and Vietnam will also contribute patients to the trial.
The randomised study will consist of a screening phase (within 28 days prior to randomisation), a treatment phase of 28 day cycles until disease progression and a follow-up phase during which patients will be contacted every 3 months up to month 60 in order to obtain survival data.
Primary Outcome Time To PSA Progression
Secondary Outcomes Overall Survival, Time to initiation of chemotherapy, PSA response rate, ORR, Time to pain progression plus change in ECOG performance scale and safety.
Timelines
The study started to recruit in March and should complete in terms of primary endpoint in February 2013. Final study completion will be February 2014.
Clinical Trial Identifier

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Genomic Health Announce First Diagnostic Partnership
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Genomic Health has announced a strategic alliance agreement with OncoMed for biomarker research and discovery using its next generation sequencing. The company develops biopsy-based genomic tests that examines patient's tumor tissue at a molecular level for six different types of cancer. The 'Oncotype DX Prostate' is expected to be launched in 2013.
Genomic Health will apply its sample preparation, high-throughput sequencing and bioinformatics capacity to identify potential biomarkers in the Notch and Wnt pathways from freshly resected breast, prostate, colon and lung tumor samples provided by OncoMed.
Focus on 'Oncotype DX Prostate'
This test will be intended to identify those patients with indolent prostate cancer who can be appropriately managed with active surveillance and those who are likely to have aggressive prostate cancer and should be treated with surgery or radiation therapy up-front.
Genomic Health is on track to complete the validation study of Oncotype DX Prostate in 2H12 for potential launch in 2013.
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (59,5 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Cabozantinib Development Program Expanded Through NCI-CTEP Collaboration
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The collaboration will allow Exelixis to increase the number of indications and disease settings of cabozantinib in a cost-efficient manner. Under the Cooperative Research And Development Agreement (CRADA) with the NCI's Cancer Therapy Evaluation Program (NCI-CTEP), 3 groups of initial trials have been approved. Details are provided below.
  • 4 randomized Ph2 trials have the potential to demonstrate cabozantinib’s utility in 1st-line renal cell carcinoma, 2nde-line hepatocellular carcinoma, platinum-resistant or refractory ovarian cancer, and 2nde-line non-small cell lung cancer
  • Additional non-randomized Ph2 trials in ocular melanoma and non-small cell lung cancer are expected to further expand the data sets from earlier studies which demonstrated the antitumor activity of cabozantinib in these settings.
  • Single arm Ph2 trials are planned to explore cabozantinib’s potential in endometrial cancer, bladder cancer and sarcoma.
  • Ph1 combination trials in additional tumor types are planned as well as a trial to evaluate cabozantinib in pediatric malignancies.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Lexicon Q1 Earnings - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lexicon continues to highlight the good progress it is making with its 5 pipeline products. Quarterly revenues however. fell by 50 percent to $0.3 million and its net loss increased by $0.3m to $29.9 million, or $0.06 per share. As of March 31, 2012, Lexicon had $253.7 million in cash and investments.
When questioned about LX1032 and the company's strategic thinking with regard to partnership, Pablo Lapuerta, Senior Vice President of Clinical Development and Chief Medical Officer replied:-
"Our plan is -- as I think we talked about previously, we're planning on taking that forward. We have been talking to people about potential partnerships but our base line plan is to take that forward on our own and that continues to be our objective."
With regard to a phase II carcinoid syndrome data meeting with the FDA, management confirmed that the meeting was now scheduled for the end of June and that results from its phII POC ulcerative collitis study are expected early Q4, with randomisation running a bit ahead of schedule.
Most of the call was spent discussing the potential for LX4211, which in addition to showing promise in Type II diabetes has also produced some interesting data in an animal model of Type I diabetes, sufficient to merit moving forward with a POC study. The company is in the process of seeking regulatory advice on the size and shape of its phIII programme for LX4211 but realises the costs will be of the order of several $100m and therefore it remains committed to working with a partner on on this product.
Source:www.lexgen.com

item.title: Update on Ferring's Degarelix Status in India
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ferring told Scrip that it is moving towards the potential launch of degarelix late 2013/early 2014, and expects to market the drug in India through its domestic subsidiary. According to the company, the pricing strategy has not yet been set.

item.title: Novartis to Create the #1 Global Generic Dermatology Company
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The $1.525 billion acquisition of privately owned Fougeras Pharm. makes Sandoz the #1 generic dermatology medicines company globally and in the U.S..
- to help cope with the loss of its own drugs that are going off-patent.
- a growing number of dermatology creams and ointments are losing patent protection, making companies such as Fougera a source of growth.
The company operates under three brands: Fougera, PharmaDerm and Savage Lab.
Fougera has 45 products and PharmaDerm, the speciality drug company has 17 brands.
2011 sales: $429m in a US dermatology generics market estimated at $2.1bn.
Focus: acne, dermatitis, eczema, Fungal Rash, psoriasis, rosacea, actinic keratosis (AK) and external genital warts (EGW).
The US generic dermatology space is very attractive, and competitive.
On May 3 2012, Zydus filed ANDA with the FDA for generic version of Medicis' Solodyn (for acne).
Last February, Valeant completed divestiture of generic dermatology products to Mylan.

item.title: Allergan - Weak Aesthetic Picture Contrasts With Strong Therapeutic Toxin Sales
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan's Q1 figures released today revealed an underlying sales increase of 10.4%, +12.2% in the specialty pharma business vs. 2% in medical devices. Botox therapeutic sales remain bouyant but facial aesthetic sales in general were down, predominantly because of a significant downturn in the filler business.
Aesthetic Downturn
Dermal fillers declined significantly in the United States, offset by strong double digit growth internationally. Sales in Q1, 2011 grew a spectacular 48% versus first quarter of 2010, and represented the first time that facials aesthetic sales were sequentially higher than the high point of a fourth quarter.

In the US, the swing was explained in terms of the timing of our so-called duet dividends promotion, whereby Allergan provided incentives to physicians and rebate coupons to their patients to combine orders and treatments of JUVEDERM with BOTOX.
In 2011, all orders for this successful promotion were in the first quarter. This year, the promotion commenced in the middle of April and is expected to last throughout the second quarter. In Q2 Allergan claims to have seen a strong response to this campaign. The 2012 campaign, was after the XEOMIN cosmetic launch at the American Academy of Dermatology which took place in the middle of March. Furthermore, physician office inventory of JUVEDERM was drawn down as the new syringe size was launched, (the 1 ml at the same price as the former 0.8 ml syringe, which will no longer be commercialized in the US market).

Excluding the the channel inventory swings created by the company, management estimated that the US market in Q1 grew in the low double digits, sequentially market share was flat in Q1, at about 39%, but up 200 basis points from Q1 of 2011.
Botox Franchise
Sales growth was 9.4% in dollars and 10.5% in local currencies with greater double digit growth in the therapeutic side of the business, due to the recently approved indications of chronic migraine, neurogenic over active bladder and in the U.S., upper limit spasticity. Cosmetic growth was "more modest" due to Xeomin's sampling and its capture of 7 to 8% market share.

Regarding its worldwide market share for all neuromodulators in Q4, 2011, the last period for which the updates are available, Allergan estimates that BOTOX enjoyed just over 76% share, down about 300 basis points from Q4 of 2010 as competitors entered new geographic markets.
Allergan is now claiming that as of March its BOTOX cosmetic volume share moved up to 78% from 75% in February, gaining both against DYSPORT and XEOMIN. The key driver it appeats was the media and promotional launch of the BOTOX ten-year anniversary campaign which enabled patients to capture a discount across three treatments in a market which in Q1 was growing at a double-digit rate.

In the therapeutic segment growth was reportedly particularly strong in the United States, Canada, Latin America and Asia Pacific. In Europe, by contrast Allergan claims to have been impacted by government mandated price cuts
In the US, BOTOX therapeutic market Allergan is claiming that its share remains very high at 93%, with the remaining 7% being shared fairly equally by DYSPORT, Myobloc and XEOMIN. About 5,000 individual physicians of the approximately 10,000 neurologists in the United States have now been trained on Botox injections for migraine with 50% of practicing neurologists apparently having injected at least one patient for chronic migraine in the past month. An unbranded DTC campaign for patient awareness of the condition in September of last year, and in addition, Allergan has been placing BOTOX branded print advertisements in women's magazines since February.

In the US, in the core movement disorders area, which includes the upper limit spasticity indication, Allergan also reports that it continues to enjoy double digit growth.
Regarding the Neurogenic overacting bladder launch just over 1,000 individual physicians have so far been trained. Regarding insurance access, 60% of commercial lives enjoy policy coverage. 82% of Medicare lives and 96% of Medicaid lives. It was noted that the next key event in the group's urology franchise is the expected approvals for idiopathic over active bladder by both FDA and the European authorities in 2013.
Full Year Guidance
Finally in terms of its full-year guidance management decided to keep the 1.75 and the $1.8 billion revenue estimate for Botox, claiming that it will try to provide more accurate guidance with its Q2 figures. Given the level iof XEOMIN inventory in channel which still had to be used up there was little positive impact of Xeomin's withdrawal on BOTOX sales in Q1 but is expected to provide a benefit during the remainder of the year and additionally a small benefit to JUVEDERM sales.
Source: www.Allergan.com

item.title: Prana Biotech Commences PhII Huntington Disease Study
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
The development of Prana's library of Metal-Protein Attenuating Compounds ('MPACs') commenced with the observation that Prana's first proof-of-concept MPAC - clioquinol ('PBT1'), abolished Alzheimer's-like changes in the brains of genetically engineered mice. Subsequent work demonstrated a significant reduction in cognitive decline in a pilot phase IIa study in Alzheimer's patients receiving PBT1. Due to an unrectifiable manufacturing impurity, PBT1 was retired and immediately succeeded by an improved and novel MPAC – 'PBT2' , the leading candidate to arise out of Prana's unique drug discovery platform. PBT2, while sharing a similar mechanism of action to PBT1, demonstrates superior technical and medicinal properties.
From http://www.pranabio.com see original source.

item.title: Vernalis ' A2A Antagonist to Enter Ph2 Trial for Parkinson
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The outcomes of the Ph1 study have shown that the drug has good safey and tolerability profile. POC trial is planned for H2 2012.
- Experts believe that A2A receptor antagonists could have advantages over conventional dopaminegic strategies. They may be able to help restore motor function in patients with Parkinson’s disease, without side effects such as nausea and dyskinesia often associated with current treatments.
- Few A2A receptor antagonists in development
The drug was partnered with Biogen Idec in 2004, but Vernalis regained the programme in April 2011.

item.title: New POC Trial of Medy-Tox' MT10109 Versus Botox(R) for Cervical Dystonia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph2 study with Medy-Tox' HSA-free botulinum toxin preparation, planned to start next month in Australia. The primary endpoint will assess the number of AEs.
Recruitment: approx. 60
Start date: June 2012 - Completion dates: Feb. 2013 /April 2013
Ongoing trials with MT10109 in Aesthetic (See Neurology6149: New Study of Medy-Tox' s New BTA Formulation Versus Botox(R) in Glabellar Frown Lines).
